name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I am sure most of us still know exactly what they did on 26 April 1986. This day has deep into everyone's memory: 30 years ago, on 26 April 1986, the reactor block number 4 of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant exploded in the former Soviet Union – in the Soviet Republic of Ukraine. There was a total meltdown, what is called a super-GAU, a tragedy with incredible consequences: radioactive material was thrown into the atmosphere, large parts of Russia, Belarus and Ukraine were contaminated, the radioactive cloud moved to Central Europe and up to the North Cape. To this day, the exact number of people who have fallen ill and died as a result of radiation is disputed; it is likely that the figure will never be determined in detail. Estimates of health impacts and deaths vary. But no matter what the order of magnitude, these orders of magnitude are dramatic. Tens of thousands are thought to have died, and in some estimates hundreds of thousands of deaths. Few have remembered that so-called liquidators – mostly young men – were sent into this disaster without protection and without warning in order to contain it. It is probably thanks to these people that things did not get any worse. But many of these people, these heroes, paid for their efforts with their lives. In the region, hundreds of thousands of people have had to leave their homes and give up their homes. Many families had to be resettled, communities were torn apart. To this day, soils and food in the region remain polluted. Many people still suffer from the aftermath, even the children born many years after the disaster. Chernobyl, as a ruin, certainly remains a monument to the disaster – and Chernobyl remains a problem. The dismantling of the nuclear plants is extremely complex both technically and financially. The new protective cover, for example, which is intended to replace the 1986 temporary protective jacket, will not be completed until 2017 at the earliest and will cost between 1.5 and 2 billion euros. In the European Union, the decision on the use of nuclear energy is the responsibility of the Member States. But nuclear clouds and radiation certainly know no national borders. That is why our efforts to ensure safety and prevention must not stop at national borders. At European level, therefore, the Fukushima nuclear disaster has, i think, rightly been used as an opportunity to subject 145 European nuclear power plants to a comprehensive risk and safety assessment. Beyond partisan and national disputes – there are many different views on the use of nuclear power – we must, in any case, also in remembrance of this disaster, agree that we must ensure that nuclear power plants in Europe and in our surroundings are safe. That is the warning and certainly the mission that this Chernobyl super-GAU triggered 30 years ago and the Fukushima disaster a few years ago. Ladies and gentlemen, we in the European Parliament must also take this task very seriously. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on The Report by Georgi Pirinski on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control on the Annual Report 2014 of the European Investment Bank (EIB) (2015/2127(INI)) (A8-0050/2016). First of all, I welcome the President of the European Investment Bank, Mr Werner Hoyer, and his staff. Welcome, Mr President, and ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur. –  Mr President, let me first of all welcome President Hoyer, thank Commissioner Moscovici, and simply convey my very deep gratitude to all those who worked on this report. As you have seen, this is a comprehensive analysis, it takes a lot of technical work. So both to the shadow rapporteurs, and to all those from the secretariats that worked on this report, I would like to extend my very heartfelt gratitude.  Now as to the substance, in the light of the extraordinary challenges confronting the European Union and Member States at present, it is even more urgent that the Bank fully commits to implementing its core task: to support projects that contribute to the balanced development of the internal market and to social, economic and territorial cohesion. The fact that in 2014 the EIB successfully implemented one of its most ambitious business plans, amounting to EUR 80.3 billion, is undoubtedly a most important achievement. However, virtually 60% of all projects signed in 2014 were allocated to the top five EU economies. In this regard, there is an urgent request for the Bank to substantially step up its technical assistance and financial advice in order to overcome insufficient project-generating capacity and low levels of borrowing in some Member States.  The draft resolution also notes the lack of meaningful follow-up to previous Parliament resolutions. In this regard, I would like to highlight some such issues and invite President Hoyer and Commissioner Moscovici to respond.  Regarding transparency and work with intermediaries, already in 2013 Parliament called on the EIB to refrain from cooperation with financial intermediaries having a negative track record in terms of transparency, tax evasion or aggressive tax planning practices and abusive transfer pricing, or concerning substantial local ownership. It also encouraged the EIB to make funding contingent upon the disclosure of country-by-country tax-relevant data and called on the Bank, jointly with the Commission, to establish a stringent public list of criteria, ensuring the proper selection of financial intermediaries. Regarding Parliament-Bank cooperation, Parliament repeats its call for regular dialogue between its relevant committees and the Bank, similar to the practices with the ECB, and strongly encourages that an interinstitutional agreement be concluded without further delay. As to Bank supervision, another previous call envisages putting in place effective prudential banking supervision of the EIB. Regrettably this and other calls have not been taken up by either the Commission or the EIB so far. As for the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the draft resolution specifically calls on the EIB to ensure that the EFSI is not indirectly used as a means of increasing the EIB’s capital, to regularly review the Bank’s involvement in EFSI, and to show that the conditions on additionality laid down in Article 5 of the EFSI Regulation have been met. So far it remains to be demonstrated that the Fund is in fact generating additional investments beyond the usual financing arrangements. I do trust that this resolution will contribute to further enhancing the key role of the EIB, as the bank of the European Union, in achieving the Union’s strategic political objectives in the immediate future and in the longer-term perspective.

name: Werner Hoyer
text: President of the European Investment Bank. – Mr President, it is a pleasure and an honour to be back at Parliament and to report to you about the Annual Report for 2014 and to respond to the remarks by the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, whom I thank for his great work and very good, close cooperation with the services of the Bank and myself.  Having said this, let me start by expressing my appreciation for the support you, as the European Parliament, give us to ensure that the EU bank will continue to deliver benefits for the EU economy and for EU citizens, as well as contribute to common European objectives in our external activities.  Let me recap on what we have achieved since 2014, the year under review. Our plans were ambitious both in form and substance. Higher volumes of traditional lending and advising activities were and are still needed to make an imperative contribution to European goals and to respect the EIB’s ongoing responsibilities as the EU bank. At the same time the EU bank took upon itself an unprecedented challenge and gladly accepted to play a central role in the Investment Plan for Europe, a role which required a quantum change in the business, in the bank’s business profile, for some years to come.  After the crisis began in 2007, we increased our lending by 60% in two years. Following up with a EUR 10 billion capital increase in 2012, we increased lending by EUR 60 billion, supporting an extra EUR 180 billion of investment not, as was foreseen, by the end of 2015 but already in March 2015. Above target and ahead of time.  The Investment Plan for Europe, the Juncker Plan, with its three pillars, is another exceptional response to exceptional needs. Negotiations between the Council, Parliament and the Commission to finalise the regulation were concluded in May last year. That was in record time and we are very grateful for that.  The Plan consists, of course, of three elements. We only talk about one normally – the EFSI, the European Fund for Strategic Investments – backed by a EUR 16 billion EU budget guarantee and EUR 5 billion of cash from the European Investment Bank in order to increase the risk-taking capacity of the EIB Group.  I take it from the rapporteur that we do indeed have an obligation to demonstrate that, with this additional manoeuvre space, we are targeting investments which make a difference and which are additional to what we would have been able to do, at least on this scale, under normal circumstances. And I think we can prove that.  Then of course we have the enhancement of our advisory capacities within the framework of the European Advisory Hub, and the third pillar is all about removing barriers to investment and structural reforms.  Let me take the opportunity to update you. So far the EIB Group, that is both the EIB and the European Investment Fund (which supports smaller businesses) has approved through EFSI financing an amount of EUR 11.2 billion to more than 220 projects in 25 Member States, which will trigger an overall additional investment in Europe of over EUR 82.1 billion. In other words, although the institutional setup was only completed at the beginning of this year, we have also done more than 25% of the volumes we have promised within three years. So you can see that the pace of our delivery has taken up speed.  Very importantly, the Advisory Hub is also proving to be a successful initiative, having as of March 2016 received and processed 108 requests, of which 87 are project-specific. Simultaneously a network of partner institutions keen to work in cooperation with the Hub is being established across the EU. Fifteen memoranda of understanding have been signed with the national promotion institutions, with an additional seven in the pipeline.  The Investment Plan for Europe is important for our economy but Europe also has global responsibilities and the Council, the Commission and sometimes Parliament remind us of that as well. We need to ensure that in future the EU bank will have the necessary personnel and financial resources, instruments and platforms to support EU external policy and development efforts, all the way to climate policies in particular.  While EU Member States already provide considerable official development assistance to the nations, the challenges in the developing world need a more coordinated approach and the financial instruments that we use to leverage private capital within the European Union every day. As such I foresee a situation where we will reach the limits of the bank’s current 10% level for activities outside the European Union.  First among these current pressing issues is the EIB’s response to the refugee crisis and how the EIB can contribute beyond what is already being done both in Europe and in the region of the Middle East and North Africa. We have proposed to our board that the EIB could do more both in Europe, to finance the infrastructure needed to cope with the new arrivals, and outside Europe, on private sector development in countries of origin and transit. We are currently actively working on concrete proposals that will be presented to the European Council in June, as we have been asked to do.  We also look forward to continuing our very close cooperation with the Commission in this crucial effort. A final word about our parliamentary responsibility, our responsibility vis-à-vis Parliament: for me, as a parliamentary veteran of 25 years, it goes without saying that Europe’s citizens expect and deserve parliamentary oversight for their bank. Therefore it goes without saying that I am ready, just like my colleagues are, to report to Parliament and its committees and parliamentary groups when you so wish.  Your bank, the EU bank, is nowadays the world’s biggest international financial institution in terms of lending volume, operating in many different sectors in parts of the world. Over past years we have been delivering approximately EUR 70 to 80 billion a year of investments in sound and sustainable projects, mostly inside the EU and increasingly also in our partner countries. We will continue to do so, including by using the additional firepower under EFSI, because we have to address the huge investment needs.  The last year has been particularly intense and challenging, with the EIB under sharp scrutiny because what we do matters, and people and parliaments care. The message we get from your report is one of support, encouragement and urgency, and I take the remarks also on transparency, the remarks on NCJ policies, very seriously and I think we will report to the relevant committees separately on this very issue.  Let me assure you that we are willing to live up fully to our institutional responsibilities and will continue to exchange with you regularly on our activities and their impact on the ground. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, Mr rapporteur, Mr President of the EIB, dear Werner Hoyer, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of our discussion today is a number. Investment in Europe is 15% below pre-crisis levels. It is imperative that the European Union close this gap in order to return to more robust growth and to strengthen its global competitiveness. That is the whole point of the investment plan for Europe. Your report rightly underlines the role of the EIB - our bank, the bank of Europeans - as a catalyst for investment on our continent and, by extension, it is its support for the economic recovery that you have welcomed. Of course, we share and I personally share that appreciation. The investment plan has seen a real increase in strength in recent months since the EFSI regulation came into force less than a year ago. The number of projects, as well as their geographical coverage and sectoral distribution, have continued to increase. I mean here that the EIB Group and the EIB itself, the European Investment Fund have approved more than 200 EFSI-guaranteed transactions in 25 Member States. These projects are already expected to generate more than 82 billion investments, more than a quarter of the overall plan target, which is to be achieved in three years. So it's a good rhythm. The objective is indeed increased coverage of countries and sectors. Your report is an opportunity to go back in more detail on this ramp-up and on the progress that is being made.  I will focus in particular on three of the detailed aspects of your work, namely support for SMEs, tax aspects and external actions. A word first of all on the operational level. The Commission is currently building an electronic portal for European investment projects designed to be easy to use. This portal will provide investment projects with visibility to potential international investors. Similarly, in collaboration with the EIB, we have also set up a European investment advisory platform, operational since September 2015, which offers project owners a single entry point for technical assistance or advice. Your report talks at length about the role of SMEs, the main source of growth and employment in Europe. Three brief remarks on this subject. First, a quarter of the new investments generated by the EFSI will benefit SMEs and mid-sized enterprises. In practical terms, we are talking about EUR 75 billion over three years. This means, in fact, that this plan is not a 'big business' plan or an 'infrastructure' plan, it is a plan that is geared towards the whole European economy.  Under the SME component of the EFSI, this is my second thought, access to finance for SMEs has improved significantly thanks to tools such as COSME, such as InnovFin, and, more recently, the guarantee facility for the EU programme for employment and social innovation. The EIB's mandate for venture capital has also been expanded.  In total, and this is my third thought, 125 transactions were signed by the EIF under the SME-EFSI component at the end of March 2016. More than 122,000 SMEs and mid-sized enterprises in 19 Member States are expected to benefit. Again, we find the same characteristics: geographical and broad sectoral coverage.  A few words then of a subject that is particularly close to my heart and which your report evokes, namely the fiscal dimension.  In January 2016, the Commission, as you know, adopted a new package against tax evasion, which contains proposals for stronger EU-wide action against tax evasion and evasion. In this context, the Commission is closely monitoring ongoing developments in the EIB's policy on combating tax evasion and evasion. On this point, I want to acknowledge the expertise of the EIB, under the authority of President Hoyer. This allows the bank to promote transparency and tax efficiency alongside the Commission. The last aspect I wanted to talk about in more detail is external actions. Like Parliament, I welcome the renewal of the mandate for 2014-2020, providing a guarantee from the Union to the tune of EUR 27 billion. We will establish a mid-term evaluation report by the end of 2016, which will measure the overall implementation of the current external mandate and consider a commission proposal for an update of Parliament's and council's decision on the external mandate.  In particular, it will be a question of measuring the coherence of this mandate with the EU's foreign policy geopolitical context. This revision of the mandate will also be an opportunity to analyse the possible activation of the optional amount of three billion euros.  At the same time, the EIB integrates its operations into a broader framework that promotes complementarities. This is particularly the case with the refugee crisis, which we talk about very often with Werner, and I know the importance, the size, the role of the EIB and its involvement in this area. While we are both aware of the limitations of the EIB's mandate, we appreciate its willingness to take part in the development of Community resources, both inside and outside the Union. I will end by mentioning a point of methodology. The Commission, of course, welcomes the approval in 2015 of the EIB's new transparency policy. Transparency, openness and accountability are key concepts for the European Union. We appreciate the EIB's commitment to comply with the EU's transparency initiative and to follow international best practices in this area.  In total, I want to say here, in the presence of its President, I see how the institution is changing and how much - which was the political intention of those who thought of the Juncker plan and then launched it - it is capable of supporting companies that take risks more than in the past. For it is, for the most part, private investment. All this is underway, and it is a great success for Europe if we succeed in achieving this collective success. Ladies and gentlemen, you have noticed that our February 2016 forecasts for growth to accelerate to 1.9% in 2017 for the euro area. But we have also stressed - and I will repeat this next week, as we will present our outlook for the spring - that this acceleration would clearly depend on a rebound in investment. Investment is still the weakest link in European growth. For the Commission, and for Europeans for that matter, this rebound is of paramount importance. In this sense, the Juncker plan is more than a signal, it is an engine.  We therefore share this House's determination to materialize, to further increase this rebound. I think that this work that is currently being done on the Juncker plan is very encouraging for the Europeans and the Commission, which is a co-author. I would also like to acknowledge the exemplary work done by the EIB.

name: Daniele Viotti
text: Deputy to the draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking in place of Mrs Gardiazabal, the budgetary rapporteur for this report, and I apologise if I am not as precise and punctual as you would have been. In the meantime, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, for his excellent report. The European Investment Bank is, of course, a key asset of the European Union, all the more so now that it has been tasked with managing the operational side of the Juncker plan. But more powers also mean more transparency and more accountability.  Greater transparency means transparency towards the citizens with regard to management and careful monitoring by Parliament as well. Careful responsibility means greater responsibility and to be aware of the objectives of the European Investment Bank with regard to small and medium-sized enterprises, with regard to the management of the Juncker plan, as was said, but also in relations and its external dimension, operating more effectively in the areas of the world that must also be stabilised from an economic and financial point of view.  I will end by saying that we hope that there will be ever greater cooperation between the European Investment Bank and the national investment banks – in the case of Italy, the Deposit and Loan Fund but, of course, the national investment banks in all countries. We need strong investment from the EIB to return to growth after eight years of stagnation, after eight years that are truly very mortifying for the European economy.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, for his report and, addressing Mr Moscovici and Mr Hoyer, to say that the basic idea of our committee's opinion is that we urgently need more investment and a shift to sustainable development. Especially in countries plagued by a great recession, high unemployment, a large reduction in investment, such as my country, Greece which, moreover, also faces the additional problem of refugees, as Commissioner Moscovici rightly noted. The persistence of blind dogmatic austerity harms both the economy and democracy but also social and regional cohesion and needs more effective and combined action by the European Investment Bank, the 'Juncker Fund' as it was called, and private capital and structural funds, in order to have a stronger shift in growth and, Mr Moscovici, the last thing Europe needs at the moment is instability or destabilisation in Greece.  That is why I call on you and ask the Commission to play a more active role, so that unrealistic demands of the IMF, the International Monetary Fund, which threaten the south-east of Europe with instability, do not allow us to relive the adventure of the last summer.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the REGI Committee. Mr. President, expectations are high, Mr. Hoyer, of the European Investment Bank. Expectations of medium and small enterprises are high, expectations of many urban and rural areas, local and regional authorities are high. The crisis in many countries has been going on for too long and that is why expectations are directed towards the European Investment Bank, in support of the public sector and the private sector, rightly very high.  For example, many eastern European countries, Croatia from which I come, need big investments. Our expectations go towards what you put forward earlier, the reform you are making at the European Investment Bank itself and trying to finally have the synergy of cohesion policy, the financing of the European Investment Bank and the Juncker Fund as part of your bank or our bank. We need to take advantage of this synergy and we expect to get significant results on this synergy.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you started by saying that you have high expectations. I also have high expectations from the EIB. In the light of what the Commissioner and the EIB representative said: do you consider that what has been done and changed so far has really improved? Or do we find that SMEs again have obstacles in accessing structural funds and, of course, funds through the EIB?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Madam Advocate, I agree with you that there are still large administrative barriers. However, this report is for 2014 and we know that in the meantime in 2015 and this year the European Investment Bank has made a number of administrative changes.  However, what is an additional problem is that in some Member States we have major additional barrier problems within the Member States of the European Union. And that's where we have the problem of getting funding for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Brian Hayes
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I want to welcome the report by Mr Pirinski and thank him for the work we did. I also welcome to Parliament President Hoyer, on behalf of the European Investment Bank. The EIB is Europe’s bank. It must be part of our recovery and it plays an increasing role in long-term European investment which, as Commissioner Moscovici pointed out, is EUR 15 billion down in public and private terms from the start of the crisis.  Now the priorities of this Parliament in obtaining more public-private models of funding, more solutions for long-term investment, and the emergence of a genuine Capital Markets Union, all point to a new era, to the future-proofing of the EU economy. In all of that, the EIB plays an increasingly active role. What is particularly encouraging for countries like my own, which have gone through terrible adjustment programmes and seen a massive fall-off in public and private investment, is that when confidence is restored and when a country is turned around, the EIB’s investment significantly improves new investment opportunities in countries such as Ireland.  Now 2014 was a very significant year for the Bank. I welcome especially, on behalf of the EPP Group, the fact that SME lending in 2014 was EUR 25 billion, which was a significant improvement on previous years. Obviously the EIB plays a crucial role in the success of the EFSI Juncker Investment Plan, and the great challenge we face is to realise the private sector contribution, given the capital from the EU budget and the EFSI itself. While over EUR 20 billion was released for strategic investment in 2014, we have to be more ambitious now at this especially important time for Europe. Across the EU the private sector has cash-rich balance sheets which we need to find a way to unlock for all our investment needs.  Finally, I want to agree with President Hoyer when he said repeatedly that he wants further engagement with the European Parliament. We need to find a means of doing that for the satisfaction of this Parliament and its committees and the EIB, and the satisfaction with the integrity of the entire process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – How do you think that this report, if adopted, is going to influence the European Investment Bank to adopt, eventually, a new lending strategy towards the Member States?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the adoption of this report looks back on 2014 and sets out what we need to do as a European Union because we recognise, as is in the report, the fall-off of investment in public-private capital. That is not going to be helped by politically picking and choosing projects. We have got to get behind projects which make Europe more competitive and improve employment and growth prospects. The only way that can happen is to have a strong governance arrangement at the Bank, whereby projects that actually succeed – which make the Bank stronger and Europe stronger –are the projects that we should support. We should not politically intervene in that, because that would be to the detriment of Europe’s long-term growth potential.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: ceist “cárta gorm”. –  Tugaim faoi ndeara go bhfuil tú ag caint ar infheistíocht a dhéanamh i seirbhísí poiblí, ach mar sin féin i dtaobh an Junker Plan mar shampla níl aon bhanc poiblí againn in Éirinn, mar is eol duit, agus tá sé an-deacair ar dhaoine teacht air seo mar airgead breise agus fiú amháin teacht ar airgead ón EIB.  Conas a déarfása go bhfuil an rialtas in Éirinn – nuair a bheidh rialtas againn ag deireadh an lae – chun aghaidh a thabhairt ar an dúshlán seo? Féachann sé domsa go bhfuilimid ag cur airgead agus infheistíocht isteach sna bainc commercial seachas sna cinn phoiblí, agus mar sin níl an t-airgead ag dul go dtí na háiteanna inar chóir dó a bheith ag imeacht.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Ms Ní Riada, in a funny way we actually have public banks in Ireland because one of our banks is 95% owned by the state and there is a direct obligation on that bank, which now has a new mandate with the EIB, to use EIB funds for SME lending. There is also an obligation, I think, to use the potential of the EFSI and Juncker Plan to get behind big projects. And if I can be critical of Ireland here, like other small countries, I wonder are we seeing the magnitude of projects coming forward from countries like my own and other small Member States? If one listens to some of the reports recently from the EIB there is an argument that we need to be more ambitious for the bigger projects, the bigger projects that can transform economies, that can make economies more competitive, that actually make a difference when it comes to making a difference for the European Union. I hope that whatever government is in place in Ireland over the course of the next file will follow that advice.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question. You use an interesting phrase, the term ‘future-proofing’. Surely it has been proven that the efforts of the EU to future-proof against market forces are often hopelessly impotent, and, indeed, sometimes counterproductive, by the failure to deal with the steel crisis, an issue which incidentally I was appalled to see was kicked into the long grass earlier on in this session. But does that not show that any effort to future-proof against market forces is beyond the capability of even a Union of this size?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I don’t think so, because if you read what the entire ambition of the EIB is – and I am not speaking on their behalf, but I have read the reports closely – future-proofing means that we invest in the long—term sustainable approach. So it is very important in the future, for instance, that we invest in projects which have a systemic importance to energy supply, that we invest in green technology and that we try to anticipate the problems that are coming down the track. That can only be done with an eye on the future, because we live in a society that is radically changing. We have got to make sure that the technologies we have in place get this kind of support from the EIB. I think there is a willingness on the part of the Bank to do that. Maybe after all these questions I might even apply for President Hoyer’s job myself.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Mr Pirinski, again, for a report made with enormous rigour and a cousin, an excellent report. And I would also like to thank Commissioner Moscovici for clearly saying that the outstanding subject in Europe is investment: there are some people, even in this House, who still think that these are costs and not benefits.  And that is a little impression which then comes to us, Mr. Hoyer; that is the problem we have with regard to how you are doing, that is, how the European Investment Bank is doing, taking into account the investments that are coming from the European budget.  In other words, we are increasingly under the impression – and the citizens with us – that the Union budget is getting smaller and that its capacity for subsidies, direct aid – in short, funds – is being reduced and, on the other hand, a part, which is increasingly in our interest, passes or is transferred to its bank, to the European Investment Bank.  There was already a recapitalisation from the Member States in 2009 – EUR 232 billion – and in 2013 with great pain from our hearts, and you know this because even some of your compatriots and their own political group fought to the end to prevent funds coming out of the CEF and Horizon 2020 for the guarantee that the EIES or the plan needed , which at the time we called the Juncker Plan, and yet finally this Parliament was adopted, and I was one of the people who fought for you to have precisely the guarantees necessary to multiply.  This was one of the mandates: multiplication, a kind of miraculous multiplication, through guarantees, to achieve 315 billion to precisely mobilisation European development and, secondly, to mobilisation of private initiative.  And there are some reproaches regarding how it has been worked, even though you now come up with a beginning, we would say, of results.  We did not like that, with the haste and little participation before the adoption of the EIE FEIE by the European Parliament itself, there were some mistakes such as the Beaver project, which you know well and which we will still have to talk about in the Committee on Budgetary Control.  We also continue to have ongoing complaints from SMEs and local administrations that the projects you generate or manage have to be projects of a huge amount. And to generate jobs, as you know very well, small businesses and small administrations are necessary. And finally: the little transparency and accountability, which is why I ask you to agree to follow Mr Pirinski's recommendation, made in paragraph 80 of the report, to receive questions from parliamentarians as a normal practice, and also in relation to the interinstitutional agreement with the Commission and the Court of Auditors , in paragraph 78. I think we could improve a lot more with that.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I simply have a political issue. This report calls for more European integration and more federalism. So, dear, do you agree, like the European Commissioner, Mr Moscovici, to create a European super finance minister, so that, once again, you can go beyond the sovereignty of states?

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Ferrand, I am really delighted with Commissioner Moscovici for the time being, with the way he is carrying finances and the European message on investment in other areas. Therefore, I at the moment, at least, have no need for a finance super minister; upside down, almost nothing but the title sometimes makes me a little scary. I would prefer better cooperation between Commissioner Moscovici, who works enormously well, and Mr Hoyer and the Member States; to make a little more case for Mr. Moscovici. I think we'd all win with it.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would first like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Pirinski, for a very interesting report. But I see a real problem. In 2014, almost 60% (59.4%, to be precise) of European Investment Bank-signed projects were allocated to the top five EU economies, while the other 23 Member States received only 30.3%. This means that the Bank should definitely implement a more balanced lending policy towards Member States. A more balanced, fairer policy is of high importance because of the intensity of both the current and the long-term challenges facing the Union at the moment. Finally, my political group finds this policy strange and unfair, and we cannot support this resolution.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I am glad that you started by referring the first, to the first, to the first, the first, to the fact that there is an over-concentration of the funds granted to the first five Member States. I had an amendment and a proposal addressed to Mr Juncker. My question is why there was no vote in Parliament, when I asked for the geographical criterion, which should be taken into account for a balanced distribution. What is your and your group's views?

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much for this important question. Of course, the issue of geographical criteria and geographical balance is very important, not only with regard to the European External Action Service – which we have had a problem with for years, I will recall – but also with regard to the European Investment Bank and many other issues.  I think that the European Parliament should be more open to the needs of the thirteen new Member States of the European Union that joined the Union after 2004. And I think that would be very good when it comes to, I will say so, the authority of the European Union in these countries.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – Europe is currently at a standstill. Cohesion policy died for lack of means. The budgetary treaty and economic governance prevent national states from being able to move forward with policies to relaunch their economies. In short, we are at a stalemate and there are no prospects within the Framework of the European institutions that we can have a relaunch of economic growth based on sound foundations. In this context, these EIB results, with around EUR 75 billion invested and 400 companies supported, represent only one drop of water in relation to the investment gap and what needs to be done.  We do not have information on the geographical distribution of this investment and the aggregation of SMEs with mid-cap companies, which can reach up to 3,000 workers, does not allow us to assess the contribution of this support to social and territorial cohesion. What we are observing and what we have, particularly in juncker's plan, where the EIB plays an important role, is that cohesion objectives weigh little on a European Union increasingly at the service of large enterprises and capital.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I want to limit my intervention to the fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance. To this end, Mr Pirinski's report contains a whole series of brilliant recommendations, including the recommendation to the European Investment Bank to improve the quality of information on the final beneficiaries. There is also a very explicit demand from Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control to the EIB to more effectively prevent transactions involving financial intermediaries with a negative score in terms of transparency, fraud, corruption, organised crime, money laundering and activities that have harmful social and environmental consequences. Well, Mr Hoyer: what will you do with these recommendations? Do you take it to heart? What will you do to ensure that these recommendations are taken into account in the coming year? Thank you.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, thanks to the EIB all British taxpayers seem to do is fund loans to export British jobs to countries including Turkey, China and Russia. Let us take a look at steel, a hot topic in the UK, on which the Commission has admitted its responsibility for banning rescue and restructuring aid unless it is driven by the market, i.e. not state aid.  So why then are British steel workers subsidising foreign steel companies in the form of soft loans totalling GBP 80 million? One of these companies mentioned as having loans under consideration is the Wuhan Iron and Steel Corporation, the world’s eighth largest producer based on tonnage. Its products now are subject to 36.6% anti-dumping tariffs. The loan was to reduce the cost of energy. One of the main complaints of Tata is the high cost of energy in the UK. Another plant, in Guangdong, was given EUR 35 million in the interests of improving energy efficiency. The EIB has been making loans to state-owned Chinese steel companies who are then able to sell back to the EU below cost price, and our own UK Government has been powerless to stop it.  This situation has been branded insane by a director of a UK steel company although the words I would use are ‘an absolute disgrace’. The North of England in particular is suffering from higher and higher unemployment, lower wages and fewer career opportunities, yet our own taxes are being given to Chinese steel plants, which has helped put our workers on the dole. We should have learned from the loan to Ford, which cost this country thousands of jobs, but clearly we just keep giving our money away.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her work Mr. President! Commissioner Moscovici, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his Unlike the previous speaker, I have to say that I find the ECB's 2014 annual report quite impressive, even though I myself am very much committed to the steel industry and to all the issues that have just been mentioned. The report is impressive, and this is also reflected in Mr Pirinski's report, because one thing is clear: the European Investment Bank is important in overcoming the investment gap that we have had since the financial and debt crisis broke out, and the figures in the report are an expression of this. In 2014, the EIB lent 80.3 billion, 7.9 billion of which went abroad and went to third countries. Of course, President Hoyer, as you yourself mentioned, this maximum 10% limit is unlikely to last in the future, especially with regard to migration. If I look at the fact that a billion has flowed into Ukraine from a 3 billion package in 2014, it is probably also questionable how this can continue. What I liked very much is also the record volume that you had in 2014 with small and medium-sized enterprises. I believe that you have supported 285 000 small and medium-sized enterprises and secured 3.6 million jobs, which is important. However, I have one criticism: EFSI. In Austria, a project has so far been approved, which is the Bruck wind farm. The competent bodies, the banks, the investors are whining. Please make sure that more projects are implemented in Austria as well.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, the European Investment Bank provided EUR 80 billion in aid in 2014. This is only 3% of the eu's total investment amount of 2 700 billion, i.e. on the basis of this ratio, it can be said that the UNION's failure in economic policy should not be att to the EIB. However, looking at aid policy, it is a telling fact that 60% of the projects concluded by the Bank in 2014 were directed to the most developed five Member States, with only 30% of the remaining 23 Member States going abroad. Since 2008, it has been clear that the convergence process between the central countries and the peripheral countries, especially between the new Member States, has stalled and even the differences have started to increase.  In the future, the bank's lending activities should be much more strongly translated towards underdeveloped areas. This would require in advance a strategic programme that would set out the focuses that would best help the underdeveloped areas to catch up, and subsequently develop the Investment Bank's support policy in accordance with this strategy.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is very important that the European Investment Bank, as the bank of the Union, contributes to social and economic cohesion.  However, we must remember that the EIB is a financial institution. It is a bank. It needs to take into account the viability and feasibility of investments. It cannot act as a money allocation body. Let there be no misunderstanding about this. When the rapporteur speaks about the concentration of allocation of EIB-signed projects and suggests that ‘the bank should implement a more balanced lending policy towards Member States’, he always speaks from a certain political perspective, as well as a defined Member State perspective, as do some other Members of this Chamber.  I hope – I do not know but I hope – that everyone in this room can agree that the EIB needs to put great emphasis on the effectiveness and efficiency of investments, as well as on accountability. EIB investment decisions should not be made on the basis of national financing needs, but on a careful assessment of predicted viability, effectiveness and efficiency of budgets.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President, I would first like to thank Mr Pirinski for his excellent report, but it is to you, Mr President Hoyer, that I wish to address today. You represent an institution in a quasi-monopoly situation on the guarantees of the financial instruments of the European Union. The billions brewed by your bank are those of European citizens. I wanted to make this reminder in the preamble to reaffirm that you are a bank, of course, but you do not represent a bank like any other. Your bank is, above all, dedicated to satisfying the public interest. I will therefore take advantage of this debate on the 2014 balance sheet to anticipate, too, the balance sheets 2015, 2016 or even 2017, which are the years of implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments of the Juncker Plan. This investment plan, we socialists and democrats have clearly called for it, aware of the investment deficit that Europe has suffered since the 2008 crisis. Today, after a year of implementation, we have some concerns. We wanted a plan to allow for additional investment in Europe. However, in 2015 we see EIB activity comparable to that of 2012, i.e. around EUR 80 billion. Has the sacrifice of the EUR 8 billion in the EU budget been helpful? In other words, by the end of this year- 2016 - will we have reduced the annual investment deficit, currently estimated at around EUR 300 billion, and to what extent? Parliament voted to set up a dashboard to select projects based on their social and environmental added value. I also wanted to know if it was used in the selection process and, more specifically, how you evaluate job creation during the selections, because, in Paris as in Brussels, I meet innovative project owners and job creators who have their cases rejected because they are too risky. However, Mr President, we have provided EUR 16 billion in guarantees from the EU budget so that you can maintain your triple A while investing in riskier projects. Do you consider yourself to have fulfilled your part of the contract? Mr President, we have entrusted you with a heavy responsibility, as we are aware of this, but we are also accountable for the results. That is why we are waiting for specific answers.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Today, we absolutely need a stronger European investment climate. Should the European Investment Bank play an important role in this? Yes, of course, but then we also have to face the reality, which is that the EIB is not a charity. The EIB is a European investment bank. We must not lose sight of this financial aspect, because the EIB can only do what it does if we consider that AAA rating to be dear. If we put them at risk, we are also jeopardising the loans with which we can finance these projects. I do not think that is always clear in this report. The report also mentions the EIB as a convergence machine. It is as if the European Investment Bank should only invest in regions and countries that are doing less well economically. I think that's wrong. The EIB must also look at stronger regions where large projects are in the pipeline that cannot finance these regions or Member States alone, because they too have major investment needs. Thank you very much.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the EIB is mostly about big investments in big projects. It raises its funds on the international money markets. Here, though, I have a few very pertinent points for you, Mr Hoyer. The major source of employment across the EU are SMEs – small and medium enterprises. The best way to grow our way out of the malaise currently afflicting the EU is through expanding our SMEs. The cheapest source of money in the EU at the moment is the ECB. Given all the above, I suggest the EIB should lower its sights a little and, in a proactive way, open its arms and its coffers to SMEs. I suggest also, rather than go to international money markets for its millions, the EIB should go to the ECB for funding at negative interest rates.  If there are some rules preventing that, I am sure the same ECB will find a way around them. After all, they managed it in Ireland in 2010 when they found a way around their own rules and the use of Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) to create EUR 31 billion to bail out failed creditors of two failed Irish banks. The same EUR 31 billion is now in the process of being destroyed and taken back out of circulation at the insistence of the same ECB. Not very good for investment in Ireland really, is it?

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, what can a bank like the European Investment Bank achieve? This year’s report from Parliament includes suggestions for improving the bank’s performance in several areas. It could help us crack down on tax avoidance by ending loans to companies registered in tax havens and providing full transparency on beneficial ownership. It could help us to fund the transition to a renewable energy future, and be a catalyst for making industry more sustainable. Indeed, the parliamentary report includes a Green demand to boost investment in sustainable industry.  But the EIB is currently funding projects that do the reverse. In the UK, the Bank is investing GBP 500 million in the construction of incinerators, including the deeply unpopular incinerator in St Dennis in Cornwall. To stop such destructive investment, we are calling for stronger environmental assessment of projects and a full audit of the skills of EIB Board members to assess whether they are suitably qualified to make judgments about the environmental impact of projects seeking EIB funding.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: Madam President, in times of recession, EIB action has become one of the few sources of economic growth in Europe. The EIB remains a functioning institution, but this is without counting on the creation of the Juncker Plan, the EFSI, which must promote The Eurocrats to the peoples who are victims of their ultra-liberal economic policies. I would like to remind you that this plan foresees EUR 315 billion in new investments in Europe, with an additional 60 billion investments from the EIB.  My fear is therefore that, in order to display politics, EFSI funding will be substituted for those of the EIB. The total amount of EIB loans will thus decrease over a 4-year horizon in favour of EFSI loans, which are much more expensive. We will therefore be extremely vigilant about maintaining the level of EIB loans, which we do not want to see replaced by EFSI loans.  The Juncker plan must demonstrate its true effectiveness.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Hoyer, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has I do not want to join the possible praise here. I would ask you, President Hoyer, to come to a real transparency offensive and real accountability. We would like to believe that the Investment Bank is of course also very important to us, but the way we receive information really cannot go on. In the Committee on Budgetary Control, it is already noticeable when we report that we are asking questions and then not getting an answer. And if we get an answer, we won't get any more at the latest when inquiries. In other words, the first question I would like to ask is: what is happening now with the Pirinski report? Questions have been raised there, and it would be nice if we could get written answers to them. Incidentally, I have already given up hope that there will be answers here. I believe that what many colleagues have touched on, namely unequal funding in many Member States, must indeed concern us. If we have five Member States – top economies in the EU – that receive 60% of EIB projects, there is certainly a good case for this. But here it is very obvious that these are also mainly take-away effects, also in view of the favourable interest rates that the local economies find. I would also like to ask you what about renewable energies. We have less than 1% of new Member States in an area that is also very important to the EU. So, what about that? Financial instruments with EU money are of great concern to us. Where do we find statements about what is being done here and how? It would be important for us to see that EIB projects, like others, are tainted with fraud. What is the plan here, and how do you approach it? Thank you very much for your answers.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Thank you very much, Madam President. Mr Hoyer, whatever is said, I share Mr Pierre Moscovici's view. Simply put, the European Investment Bank is our success.  We have three institutions that we can compare relatively: the European Investment Bank, the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. And from this point of view, you employ by far the fewest people, you have the most projects, the closest you work with the European Union, with us, to achieve the goals that are important to us in life.  Mr Pirinski's report, a very important note, points to those moments when this good bank can be even better. And here please all these comments on transparency really take seriously. These methods of cooperation, avoiding doubts – because the bank often does not deserve to be multiplied – are crucial. Let me draw attention to three of these moments: the Juncker Plan. We very much expect and as to the methodology of the example of project bonds and the way in which we would submit these projects. I am speaking on behalf of a new member who is a large client, and I myself have almost 30 years of experience working with the European Investment Bank. For almost a decade, in the early 1990s in government, he was now here in the European Parliament.  The second area is small and medium-sized enterprises. There is undoubtedly such a problem, because in Poland people even ask: and how to get information about the availability of the project? Will anyone want to talk to me, it's such a small, stupid project – fifteen million euros, where to go? This information is missing and Here I would like to ask you: let us supplement this information. And finally, the third area is infrastructure and this European one, and cohesion funds, and Connecting Europe, but here the European Investment Bank will not replace anyone, and you are good.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the role of the EIB, that is to say the European Investment Bank, is to finance projects to stimulate growth and employment in the Member States of the Union. In 2014, the EIB financed 285,000 small and medium-sized enterprises, securing 3.6 million jobs, signing contracts for 413 projects within the Union. In addition, under the climate action objective, it financed 84 environmental projects, while the ECB has already purchased EIB bonds on the secondary market, with the aim of quantitative easing, thereby enhancing the EIB's liquidity.  But that's not enough. Eurobonds for major infrastructure projects need to be institutionalised, and it is necessary that European funds be invested in productive investment in the primary sector, infrastructure, tourism and research, while reducing unemployment at the same time must be a primary objective of the EIB, especially in countries affected by poverty and unemployment, such as Greece, which needs support for refugees. , but above all, a new 'Marshall Plan' is needed in order to be able to recover and escape the vise of the troika.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: –  A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom comhghairdeachas a dhéanamh leis an Uasal Pirinski as an tuarascáil a chuir sé le chéile. Tá sár-obair déanta aige air. Caithfear féachaint ar an tslí ina ndéantar measúnú ar obair an BEI i gcomhthéacs na n-institiúidí idir-rialtasacha agus mholfainn go dtabharfadh an BEI aird faoi leith ar an leibhéal bochtanais atá againn, agus ar an dífhostaíocht agus míchothromaíocht atá ag méadú. Táim ag impí orthu straitéis réadúil a chur i bhfeidhm láithreach a chuirfidh infheistíocht i dtograí a bhfuil tionchar sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta acu, mar thosaíocht, agus spreagadh a thabhairt don gheilleagar.   In Éirinn, táim ag impí ar an BEI cabhair faoi leith a thabhairt dóibh siúd gan baile, gan dídean. Tuigim gur chuir an BEI billiún euro ar fáil do rialtas na Breataine chun cúnamh a thabhairt dóibh le tithíocht shóisialta. In Éirinn, tá an easpa tithíochta práinneach agus tá seisear daoine nua gach lá cláraithe mar dhaoine gan dídean.  An bhliain seo 2016, céad bliain tar éis Éirí Amach na Cásca, ní féidir linn glacadh leis go bhfuil páistí agus leanaí ár dtíre fós gan baile. Mar sin, glaoim arís ar an BEI infheistíocht a chur ar fáil do thithíocht shóisialta ar bhonn daonnúlachta agus, níos tábhachtaí fós, an fhreagracht sin a bhrú ar rialtas na hÉireann.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Hoyer, Commissioner Moscovici, welcome. Mr Hoyer, my group has always been concerned about the Bank's issues of transparency and fraud. In the report of which I was rapporteur the previous year we pointed out and we continue to have funding problems in places like Italy, such as Slovenia. We continue to call for the non-financing of projects under research and to please make public at once the properties or beneficiaries of such projects. I would also like to remind you of a few questions about the Beaver, which you yourself described as a project which ended in disaster at an appearance you made in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. We continue to ask you, as we asked in the report that was voted on earlier, to do something so that Spanish taxpayers do not have to pay in the electricity bill the financing of this failed project. The Spanish Congress recently approved the need to dismantle the plant. I would also like you to participate in some way, helping that this could be done, and also that, at once, please respond to the complaint made by the Platform for the Defense of the Sénia Terres on this issue in the Claims Mechanism and on which you do not yet have an answer. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Urtasun, I would like to ask you if you do not think that Mr Hoyer should also inform us of the way in which the European Investment Bank is using the 'golden clause' so as not to further impair economies where there is an excessive deficit; if you don't think we'd need to be given that information too because, for now, we don't have it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, very briefly, I share the Member's assessment and I think the point she pointed out was relevant.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, President Hoher, certain negative aspects of this report are a signal of a serious breach of the Treaties of the European Union. It turns out that, in the current tensions, the mechanisms at the disposal of the European Union do not function in accordance with the purpose of their existence. Given that the only reason for which this prestigious institution exists is to reduce the economic gap between Member States, I believe that it is necessary to set out in detail in the EIB reports how, through the work carried out, this requirement so important for all of us citizens of the European Union has been fulfilled. I recall that, as presented in the report, 60% of the projects started were awarded to the states with the highest five economies and the remaining 40% were awarded to the other 23 Member States. I do not see how this way of financing so-called European projects can help to bridge the gap between the economies of the Union. It is not fair for an institution belonging to all Member States to finance exclusively the same great powers of the Union, to the detriment of the other Member States.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, President Hoyer, more than half of the funding provided by the European Investment Bank ends up in just four of the twenty-eight countries of the European Union: Spain, Italy, France and Germany. At the same time, the level of funding for my country, Greece - which is on a programme - has, over the last ten years, halved. Greece is, Commissioner Moscovici, among the 'examiners'. And the question is simple: how easy is it for a small or medium-sized company to ask the European Investment Bank for money? Very difficult, that's the answer. It is well known that Greece's economy is at high risk. How will the European Investment Bank succeed in mitigating this risk? The Juncker plan, for example, guarantees risk and can be an answer for small and medium-sized enterprises. Another response was the EIB trade finance facility signed in 2013 to provide the European Investment Bank with commercial banks. But a lot has changed since then. Now Greece needs, more than ever, an injection of liquidity. Simplified access for small and medium-sized enterprises to the financing of the European Investment Bank is needed. It is a great need and we must make it easier for Greek companies to invest. We need to reduce the impact of the crisis paid for by the private sector and that is why we must take special care, through the European Investment Bank, for countries that are on a programme.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam Presidents, entrepreneurs and public companies often say that they are professional, fast and that communication is easy for the EIB and EIB employees. On the other hand, they indicate that there is too little possibility of direct financing and it all comes down to guarantees, and they are then hampered again in their financial markets by the conditions for reaching the source of financing.  The EIB should better target its services in the Member States taking into account the large diversity in development, but also in the financing conditions of undertakings. I expect the EIB to report in more detail in the following periods on the results and role in the implementation of cohesion policy, including answers to questions about how much participation in total national funding actually is and whether funding can be extended to entrepreneurs.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the scale and complexity of the tasks that the EIB is called upon to carry out require a renewed commitment to rewriting a governance plan that strengthens it, not only as a financial institution, but also as a bank where knowledge and good practice are based. Its ability to address Member States and economic actors is an added value to the management of European funds, in order to finance projects to accelerate recovery and increase productivity.  The 2014 report is a good one, but the importance of amplifying process transparency and the intensification of technical assistance and financial advice should be emphasised, enhancing the ultimate goal of homogeneous growth in the Member States through uniform accessibility to forms of funding.  I regret to note that there have been many cases of financing for financially unsustainable projects on a subject that is dear to me, such as climate action, with delays that are difficult to recur in comparison with ambitious environmental sustainability projects.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – The European Investment Bank plays an important role in the European, both financial and investment, space. Its mission is relatively clear, but sometimes the question is whether this mission is carried out as was intended at the beginning of its establishment. We draw attention, in a way, on the one hand, to the issue of not only transparency but transparency, but, on the other hand, to prioritisation and, of course, to the criteria and criteria on the basis of which bank decides which projects to finance. However, I think that this bank, together with other financial resources, can and represents a great resource for actually evocation of many, including economic, issues in Europe, especially here, of course, small, medium-sized enterprises, but also issues that are directly... only indirectly touching. I am talking about environmental protection, including social issues and, of course, those important things that force people to leave their homes because of all these issues and then also, on the other hand, to represent a social burden.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot deny this: there are still grey areas in the EIB's work, starting with the leverage effect on investment. There is a lack of transparent data, there is no trace of precise details. So also as far as EFSI is concerned: are we waiting for the rabbit to be pulled out of the top hat? Magic, however, is in danger of being paid dearly if the money needed for the Juncker plan is also issued by China, which, coincidentally, would unfortunately like to be given market economy status, with deleterious effects in Europe.  Then there is the EIB's support for a great many lines of credit for banks: are these actions really going to support small and medium-sized enterprises? With what financial instruments? Will we not again be faced with the great finance that takes oxygen away from the real economy? In addition, we have heard in here about the circular economy, about paradigm shifts, but as long as the EIB supports projects such as TAP, incinerators, relifiers, oil refineries, there will be no real transition from fossil to renewable.  Finally, I would like to point out that the EIB was created almost 60 years ago to support the political objectives of the European Union and that the only union that is totally lacking is that of the citizens.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Investment Bank is the largest public bank in the world, that is, the one that provides the most funding in the world: we are talking about 75 billion investments. However, the citizens must be aware that this European public bank, in which the money of 28 European Member States flows, finances, as the eighth country, Turkey, a country that is outside the European Union.  These funds, as far as we are concerned, should finance, for the most part, European projects with very high added value and sustainable from both a social and environmental point of view, so not those infrastructure projects that are still based on fossil fuels and resources that are not renewable. So invest absolutely more, in addition to what you already do in innovative startups and SMEs, because those that give more added value over time.  In addition, economic assessments: the ones you make, must be made with realistic prospects. We cannot allow motorways to be financed without cars and trains, for example, without passengers, and therefore all works, such as castor, such as the Mestre passer-by, such as Brebemi in Milan, must be condemned because they are unsustainable works and we must no longer go down that road, especially with the new infrastructure investment programme.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank you for the very fruitful, quality and very serene debate we have had today, which shows that we are really dealing with a project of general interest.  The current economic and financial situation requires determined political action. We are convinced that the EIB's activities are a crucial component of the European Union's efforts to restore sustainable growth and employment levels in Europe, particularly through the partnership between the Commission and the EIB in the implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe, the 315 billion euro Juncker Plan.  I once again welcome Parliament's report on the EIB's activities and welcome the continued fruitful cooperation between the Commission and the EIB.  A few words on two topics that have often been mentioned: transparency and the fight against tax evasion, cohesion and convergence. I will also talk about Greece, since this subject has been raised, even if it is not quite in the scheme, but I know that Werner Hoyer is very interested. On transparency and tax evasion, I recall that in January 2016 the Commission adopted an anti-tax evasion package, which reflects the discussions that have taken place in the OECD and the G20 - this is called the BEPS - but also the discussions in the European Parliament on the fight against aggressive tax planning.  For the Commission , as I said at the informal Ecofin Council in Amsterdam eight days ago - we had to go further and this package was a whole, a global package that had to be adopted as such. I really, and rightly, count on the Dutch Presidency to achieve this. In this context, the Commission is working intensively with the EIB to explore how EIB policies could evolve to reflect the new measures we will implement. On cohesion and convergence, let me be clear. We want the convergence of the European economy, that of the euro area. That's our priority. The eurozone is a tremendous success story. It has been able to protect the economies that have made this choice, but there remains a dynamic problem, which is also a problem of equitable sharing. The EIB and the Juncker Plan are major tools for the recovery of the European economy, but we cannot have a political criterion in the choice of investments.  Of course, it is better, of course, that the EIB and the Commission are working on them are desired- and that the selected projects cover a whole range of sectors. Of course, it is desirable - of course, the EIB and the Commission are working on it - that all countries should be affected by the Juncker plan and I think it is very good that we already have 22, 23 or 25 countries that are already the subject of projects.  But logic was a logic of projects. It's a quality job. It is a matter of encouraging those who know how to innovate and those who know how to carry projects within the sectors that are the priorities of the Juncker plan. Projects, I want to say here, must be chosen for their own merits. They have to prepare for the future and, moreover, it is not a service to a particular country to think that you have to have some form of credit dusting. There are capacities for invention and innovation in all the countries of the European Union, regardless of their size. That is what needs to be sought. A word about Greece, since the subject has been raised, I do not want to shy away from it, we are in the news. In my view and in the sense of the Commission, we are really in a condition of getting close to an agreement. There are probably a few steps to take, but a lot has been done and we must not pretend that this is a new crisis that is brewing, when we have come very close in defining the necessary measures and necessary reforms.  I am hopeful that we will reach this agreement quickly. In any case, this is what the Commission will tackle with great determination. We must work on this subject with great composure, with great objectivity and with a shared will that a reformed Greece, a strengthened Greece regain growth and be able to create jobs.  On this point, of course, the Juncker plan and the action of the EIB, which is a major contributor, are returning to their full role. Yes, we need growth all over Europe, all over the eurozone and for that we really need to ensure that the reforms come to Greece, quickly, very determinedly. In conclusion, I would say that the Juncker plan, for us, is on track, in the sense that the projects funded - and that's the test - are really additional projects, in the sense that they are riskier projects than before. I usually say , Werner Hoyer knows - that the main criterion for the success of the plan is not so much quantitative as qualitative. The question is: Is there a culture change? Is there a culture change in the economies, with the capacity to carry projects, and a culture change in European policies, in what we do in the Commission, in what we do with the EIB, to ensure that it is the risk that is encouraged?  We must remain vigilant, it is not a question of giving in complacency. I think that the Juncker plan does not exhaust the whole subject and I tend to think that, if it succeeds, what I want and what I believe, it will have to be extended. This is not a three-year affair, but a much longer matter. Our investment deficit will not end in mid-2018.  But, without being complacent, I frankly believe that with this plan we are working usefully to fill the investment gap that Europe is suffering from. This is once again the key if we are to raise our level of potential growth, raise our effective level of growth, create many more jobs, reduce unemployment.  This is our common objective on all the benches of this House, in the Commission, in the Bank and in the Member States. That is why, once again, we are facing a debate that I see as a debate of general interest.

name: Werner Hoyer
text: Président de la Banque européenne d'investissement. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs, laissez-moi commencer par adresser un grand merci à M. Pirinski pour son rapport et à M. le commissaire Moscovici pour sa coopération très étroite et fructueuse ainsi que son soutien, dont nous bénéficions toujours. I think that more than 40 Members of the European Parliament have taken the floor today, and I am expected to respond to each and every detailed question – I beg your pardon; this will not be possible. I promise you that each issue that has been raised today will be responded to by our services or by myself within the next couple of days or weeks, because you deserve the answers. Let me concentrate on around seven points which I would like to raise. Firstly, I would like to thank Mr Liberadzki – I think he is not here anymore, but I would still like to thank him – because he pointed out that this is the EU’s bank, and we are the EU. If you mandate a bank in Europe or outside Europe with jobs that need to be done on behalf of Europe, then you are well advised to give that job to the EU’s bank – to those whom you can control, steer and have an influence on, and whom you can require to stick to the principles and criteria which the European Union sets for lending and the granting of guarantees. In this context, I would like to say that Greece is of course a country of specific preoccupation for us, because we have seen over the last few years how difficult it is. We are the bank that was the strongest there before the crisis; we stayed there during the crisis – as the only one, practically; and we are very active now that the crisis is, hopefully, soon over. We have even changed the business model of the bank for the case of Greece a little bit – our other centralised model for lending and granting of guarantees is not deployed in Greece any more, because we have strengthened our presence on the ground as we want to reach the customers, the clients, the companies and the corporates directly with our personnel. Thirdly: transparency, NCJ policies, and everything that has to do with that. We have received the message and understood Mr Pirinski, and we will follow it up. We support the Commission with all their efforts in this field. This is going to be very difficult in detail, because sometimes you move between the legitimate and the legal; sometimes the devil is in the use of illegitimate but legal means, and that sometimes poses very difficult challenges to a bank and to many other actors. Sometimes you wish the legislator would step in and clarify the situation – not only what is legal, but also what is legitimate. Next point: the interinstitutional agreement. I completely agree that it is high time to bring it to a conclusion – I talked to several members of the leadership of this European Parliament today – and we are resolved to bringing this to a conclusion very soon. I want to have that done before the summer break, because this issue should be discussed in substance after the summer break when we have analyses of what the first year of the Juncker plan has brought. The key thing is – and it has been raised by several people – that we must make sure that we have a balanced approach to all Member States of the European Union. What does that mean? Well, of course, the EU bank does not have quotas – that is completely impossible, because we go for economically viable and sustainable projects and we observe criteria which are also ecological and of course social, and if these projects do not appear on the list of proposals, then there will not be such a programme. We will not give grants just in order to be present in the country if there is not a good project. But let us look at the realities, and I would like to remove the myth of a lack of balance in the activities of the bank in the European Union. If you look at the total investment supported in 2015, the four countries with the highest percentage of activity are Latvia with 13.8% of GDP, Slovakia with 12.9%, Greece with 11.4% and Slovenia with 11.4%. At the end of the list you find Romania with the 0.3%, Bulgaria with 0.3%, Ireland with 0.3% and the Czech Republic with 0.4%. Now let us go to the exposure of the bank: where is the Bank the most exposed? Well, the highest exposure is in Cyprus at 15.3% of GDP, Slovenia at 11.7%, Portugal at 11.0% and Hungary 9.9%. At the end of the list are Denmark at 1.1%, the Netherlands at 1.7%, Germany at 1.7% and the UK at 1.9%.
