This is the reality, and it shows the balance sheet of the bank as an expression of the spirit of solidarity in this European Union. Anything else is a myth. On the question of steel production in China: what we have heard today in the European Parliament, unfortunately, is complete nonsense. The bank has never had – and does not have – any steel project in China, and the only one that has ever been brought to our attention as an idea by the Chinese has been rejected by us. So it is a propaganda thing that we have heard here today; it is not supported by facts. I would like to conclude by saying, on social questions and social housing, that this is a very important point that we have sped up quite a bit, also in connection with the migration crisis, because migration solutions must not go to the detriment of those people in need who also need social housing. So, therefore, we see this as one big area where we have done some considerable stepping—up of business. More can be done, however, also in combination or in cooperation with the Member States or regions that are interested in that. Probably, in some countries, it is not really known on the national level what we do on the regional level, in particular when it comes to migration and to social housing. Finally, I would like to say: don’t overdraw our capabilities. When the bank was founded in the 1950s in the Treaties of Rome, nobody would have thought that we would one day be an SME Bank. But nowadays we need this tool because of lack of access to finance for SMEs, and we used it for over 300 000 SMEs last year. That is 30% of our business volume. An additional business volume percentage of 27% is expected to go into climate—related lending. Of course, everybody thinks that 11.15% or more of lending should go into innovation and research and development. If you add that up and then come also to the question of digitalisation, which we have not touched upon here today but which is the key ingredient for preserving or restoring Europe’s competitiveness in the next couple of years, you easily end up at above 100%, and that cannot work either. We have to have a balance in this respect as well. We are trying to achieve this with your help.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, may I join in the evaluation of this discussion as one that has been particularly interesting, substantial, substantive, and, I believe, indicative of the further actions that should be taken on behalf of the Bank, the Commission and Parliament – all of us. Permit me to highlight three issues. The first, of course, has to do with investment. Commissioner Moscovici has pointed out that this, after all, is the weak link in the expectations for a more rapid upturn in the growth rate and, in general, improving the employment and growth situation.  There is one aspect which I would like to address at the very beginning, which has to do with cohesion and the distribution of investment resources. It might be true in relation to GDP, but the relationship – 60% to 5% and 40% to 23% – is  a simple reflection of the facts of the signatures in 2014. Those are the facts. The disappointments that have been voiced are a reflection that there is not a feeling that the activities of the Investment Bank are addressing vigorously enough those parts of the European Union where the crisis has had its severest consequences. One of my colleagues has said that this call for a greater spread of resources goes against the activities of the Bank as a bank. He has even challenged me by saying that the point I made is the product of political and country prejudices. I would simply like to refer to Protocol 28 to the Treaty, connected to Article 3, which has to do with cohesion, and which very clearly states that the contracting parties: ‘reaffirm their conviction that the European Investment Bank should continue to devote the majority of resources to the promotion of economic, social and territorial cohesion and declare their willingness to review the capital needs of the European Investment Bank as soon as this is necessary for that purpose.’  I would say further that, after all, in these countries receiving far fewer resources there are a sufficient number of viable, profitable and effective investment projects, which, however, require on-the-spot additional active engagement by the Bank and the services of the Commission in generating them in the proper investment mode. This also has to do with the concerns relating to ecology and social aspects. This cannot be, so to speak, a ‘business as usual’ development of projects. I see that my time is up so I will name only two other urgent considerations. One was voiced by my colleagues from the Committee on Budgetary Control. I have heard President Hoyer commit to giving answers as soon as they are ready. I would invite the President to ask for a meeting of the Commission and really take the initiative in addressing questions which have been on the table for a number of years.  The third consideration has to do with the interaction with Parliament. Again, I believe that there is room for a rapid conclusion of the interinstitutional agreement and for the introduction of a regular process of parliamentary oversight, where the Bank can make its case and give information and we can work out a positive way of going forward. I would like to thank President Hoyer for his words regarding the report, as well as Commissioner Moscovici and all those who took part in the debate.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 28 April 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In view of the economic context we are experiencing, the European Union decided in September 2014 to launch an investment plan. In this context, the EIB must prioritise investments that accelerate recovery and increase productivity while encouraging youth employment, innovation and SMEs!  However, launched in July 2015 to revive the European economy, the Juncker Plan is slowly starting. The plan aims to inject 315 billion euros into the European economy in 3 years and create one million jobs. But according to figures provided by the European Commission, only 7.5 billion euros have been disbursed by the EFSI since its inception.  At this rate, it can be estimated that EUR 45 billion would be financed over a three-year period, or only about two-thirds of the 63 billion announced in the Commission's projections. That is why we have insisted in this report that all means be put in place to finance projects related to support the EU's political objectives.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The main task of the EIB, the EU Bank, would be to provide financial support in the interests of the Eu ropean Union. In 2014, it financed 285 000 small and medium-sized enterprises and concluded contracts totalling 413 projects within the EU, worth EUR 69 billion and 92 new non-EU projects, worth EUR 7.98 billion. In addition, in the same year, the EIF committed EUR 3.3 billion in equity investments and guarantees to small businesses. Unfortunately, there are still some serious weaknesses in the EIB. aggressive tax planning. I would also remind you that the EIB has been ranked 16th in terms of transparency on a ranking of 17 organisations since the 2014 Aid Transparency Index (ATI).

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – At a time of increased economic problems in many EU Member States, no one can question the positive role and potential of the ESP to support and promote growth through financing in Member States that are really suffering from a lack of liquidity and cheap money. I believe that the EIP should focus exclusively on financing projects and businesses that create new jobs. Unemployment in the EU is rampant and is unfortunately rising dramatically. I therefore believe that the fight against unemployment should be a priority for the EU, and by extension for the ESP. I also note that to date the model of operation of the ESP is creating bureaucracy that is not in line with its objective, which must be direct and effective intervention and financing of enterprises and economies of Member States. I think it is very important that the EIP itself carries out a direct evaluation and financing of enterprises. The fact that the EIP does not directly finance businesses creates unnecessary bureaucracy and, possibly, because of this, the results are often poor.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – We discussed today the annual report on the European Investment Bank for 2014. It is indeed surprising how, at a time when the economic crisis has exacerbated social and economic disparities as well as the existing divergences between Member States, the European Investment Bank has chosen to channel 59.4% of all funding for projects to the eu's top five economies, while the share of the other 23 Member States has risen to just 30.3%. Especially for Greece, the country whose economic crisis has affected more than any other, bank financing for the same period amounted to only 1.2% of all financing. Even more paradoxical is the fact that Turkey currently ranks first among eib beneficiary countries outside the EU, absorbing around 3.5% of the EIB's total loans, which is an indirect reward for the authoritarian Erdogan regime, which is inseally violating human rights at home and acts as an international troublemaker abroad. The European Investment Bank must adjust its priorities if it is to meet its critical development mission.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The EIB is one of the strongest players in the EU when talking about investments in big-scale projects, providing direct funds and guarantees to governments and private and public enterprises. But a state of play where the EIB hides who the ultimate beneficiaries or the beneficial owners are, where the EIB continues to fund projects which are under investigation by OLAF or national authorities for fraud or corruption cannot be further tolerated. We demand that the EIB finally ends those practices.  The EIB must have a policy of zero tolerance for fraud, corruption and collusion and commit to strong integrity and ethical rules. The EIB should implement the highest transparency in their operations and focus on investments in environmentally-friendly and sustainable projects. Here we have a lot of room for improvement, as only 1% of the funds were spent for the renewable energy capacity development for the 13 new Member States in 2014. If we expect them to catch up and change their old-fashioned energy policies, then we clearly need to incentivise. Last but not least we have to prevent transactions to enterprises registered in offshore financial centres or tax havens which resort to aggressive tax planning.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I believe that the report points in the right direction when it states that the EI must take into account, in its credit policy, the need to contribute to regional cohesion and the development of projects abandoned by the private sector. However, it is difficult to reconcile this position with the reality of an institution whose economic orientation is subordinate to the market (as is the case, moreover, with all European policies). That is why the reverse of their "success" (the "adaptability" to global competition) is the deepening of the dominance of the great oligopolies over the maintenance of local economies and democratic control of production. Unfortunately, this is the direction in which the EI seems to be moving forward, with the financing of its credit policy or its aggressive strategy outside Europe. Public funding needs to complement public investment and sovereign development decisions taken by peoples in the face of markets. Otherwise, the ELYS will be just one more bank.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – the European Investment Bank plays an important role in the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I also supported the establishment of the Fund because Europe needs a strong impetus so that the economy does not stagnate, that employment grows and that inflation close to zero does not suffocate the economy. Without quality investment, this cannot be achieved. The role of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is to attract private investors to projects that can only be implemented because the fund bears risks. This is also why eur 315 billion of investments are investments that would not otherwise have been made. If we look at some investments that are already ready to be implemented with the help of the fund, we will find among them those that count on the insulation of tens of thousands of apartments and houses. In my opinion, such an investment does not carry any risks and is made in other countries without the aid of the Fund. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to review the financing of such projects.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – As an EU bank, the EIB's main task is to contribute to the development of the common market, deepenIng European integration, creating jobs and thus increasing the EU's competitiveness through the support of appropriate projects. The 2014 report shows a number of positive results in terms of financing small and medium-sized enterprises, supporting action against climate change or investing in education, skills development and youth employment. These results are certainly to be welcomed. However, despite the EIB's efforts, social and economic inequality in the EU has not decreased or even become more severe. This is due to an unfair global taxation system where SMEs and people on wages and salaries bear the brunt of the tax burden, while governments introduce new austerity and large companies get richer. In these circumstances, the fight to promote cohesion and solidarity between Member States, improve quality of life or protect the environment seems to be a windmill fight. The EIB should strengthen its due diligence activities on its transactions as soon as possible in order to avoid cooperating with actors registered in offshore financial centres or tax havens and engaged in aggressive tax planning practices. Taking this step is essential for the EIB. However, in order to clearly feel the added value of the bank's projects, it is necessary to permanently eliminate harmful tax practices and offshore loopholes.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, President of the European Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen, today we are awaiting the approval of one of the most important documents aimed at managing common financial resources at European Union level. We will express our position on how the European Commission used the means at its disposal to implement its policies in 2014. The discharge process appears on the European Parliament's agenda every spring, and the rapporteurs regularly present and defend their report as I do this year. Nevertheless, I tried to bring new perspectives and new ideas into the routine process. This is because the new economic paradigm and the requirements for it represent a good opportunity right now to make some changes to the established standards of economic control of the European Commission. These changes are not self-serving. On the contrary, their sole purpose is to assess whether the EU budget' resources, when spent, not only respect the formal and legislative rules, but also contribute to the real effects and impacts of the European Union's economic, social or environmental development. Whether we are able to allocate resources to the areas where this effect is greatest. Whether we are able to identify new European priorities or are still living in the grip of stereotypes of recent decades. And whether we can adequately measure and evaluate these effects and learn lessons from the conclusions for developing new policy strategies. I have devoted almost the entire past year to the process of change towards performance culture. I believe that we simply cannot answer many of the above questions in the a positive way if we are to remain objective. Although economic developments and investment activities in Europe are now recovering modestly and the unemployment rate is decreasing, the consequences of the crisis have not yet been fully overcome. It is precisely this fact that entitles us, in the area of budgetary policy, to think differently, especially in order to be able to better cope with other crises that inevitably arise.  The European Union budget should be equipped with such control tools and mechanisms that European funds cannot be misused, but that every euro actually spent can be assessed. We are not alone in this effort to strengthen performance and simplify the budget in the European Parliament. The Same approach is declared by the European Court of Auditors in its 2014 annual report. It is also confirmed by the initiatives of the European Commission and the role of the Council, especially during the current Dutch Presidency.  Discharge must, in my view, be a logical political document, a standard process, not an instrument of unsystematic pillion of the culprits, only randomly selected and detected. Let us, please focus, in particular, on how to identify and describe the manifestations of possible undesirable loading with 1% of the EU's GDP, and, in particular, together, let us look for a solution to this situation. Simply attracting attention to some of the suspects, without the proposed measures and solutions, makes no sense. I am aware that political compromises need to be sought when promoting new elements. Nevertheless, I maintain my view that discharge should be as objective and competent as possible and should not become an instrument of political struggle or account-taking between Member States. I know that it will take many years to implement the changes in the procedures in place. However, I believe that if the European Parliament had not followed this trend, it would have become alone and outside the mainstream of the European Union's budgetary policy in its pursuit of the European Union budget. And i'm sure none of us want that. Thank you all for your professional approach, thank you for the cooperation of my team, the Secretariat of the Committee on Budgetary Control, all my shadow rapporteurs, the Court of Auditors, the entire European Commission, headed by Vice-President Georgieva, and thank you, colleagues, for having the greatest possible objectivity in considering my report.

name: Claudia Schmidt
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report As rapporteur for the European Development Fund, I am particularly keen to highlight a number of important points very clearly. This year, as last year, there are many similar points, because the principle of development aid does not change much. It is right, it is important, and we need it to enable decent living conditions, mainly in the poorest countries of Africa. What I have had to say with regret is that the problems do not change much either. Project controls are only of limited effectiveness and there is a huge need for improvement here. I would like to stress that it is not a question of creating an avalanche of bureaucracy, because there are already enough control systems in place. What is not yet sufficient is the enforcement of these very control mechanisms, the willingness to learn from mistakes and to respond to the findings of the control committee. The comments made by Commissioner Mimica were instructive. It has been made very clear that refugees who are now arriving in Europe come from Afghanistan and Syria. People from the ACP countries are currently more likely to flee to neighbouring countries, but are also likely to come to Europe. That is why I have incorporated a chapter in the report in which I am clearly in favour of a more flexible use of EDF funds. Thanks to the very good work of the Court of Auditors, we know that almost EUR 10 billion is blocked at various stages of project implementation, and these are not only the money that is sensibly committed to multiannual projects, but also those that are involved in projects that have difficulties in implementation and may be wasted. In addition, funds from the 8th EDF, which was already stocked in 1995, are still being spent. If we want to deal with the refugee crisis, we need to rethink and, above all, to realise that development aid is not a gift, it is to fight the causes. Let us use common sense by redistributing the money and setting new priorities and prevention measures! The EU Commission, represented here by DG DEVCO, as well as the European External Action Service and in particular the EU ambassadors deployed on the ground, who are the link between the EU Commission and the EEAS, need to pay even more attention to development aid projects. For example, if of 918 EDF-funded projects, 428, worth EUR 9.2 billion, have difficulties in implementation, action must be taken instead of continuing to distribute money where the added value is questionable. In order to achieve this, however, there must also be a willingness to allow criticism and to learn from mistakes. I am therefore addressing the S&D Group very clearly, because I would very much like to see the figures mentioned above and confirmed by the Commission not being voted in the report. Those who do not allow criticism will keep alive a system that could bring even more benefits in an improved form. By 2020, EUR 30 billion will be taken into account that is not included in the EU budget – that is, flowing directly from the national finance ministries to the Commission and then to Africa. I also call for a quarter of the funds to be earmarked to counteract the current refugee crisis. I am very happy to quote the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, who herself says that development aid is not a gift, but an investment, and that a new form of partnership with the African partner countries must be found. I am also very happy to quote President Martin Schulz, who said that we should, however, make development cooperation dependent on democracy and the rule of law and on what we call good governance. It is not acceptable for every dictator who oppresses his own people to be promoted in the economic sphere, and then people flee the countries. One statement – my statement is clear: development aid must be the fight against causes, and if there are no results, consequences must be drawn. I call on all colleagues from all the political groups not to prolong the outdated, but to send development aid in new, more sensible ways and adapted to the demands of the present, and to support the report.

name: Markus Pieper
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, thank you very much for the cooperation with the shadows in the discharge procedure and also thanks to the assistant advisers, to the administration for the information and support. The budget discharge for one's own house is always a sensitive issue. The people rightly expect us to lead by example. Example: Building policy. The moderate extensions are appropriate, the transfer to own property reduces costs. However, we are critical of the modernisation, which sometimes takes off too late, which then increases costs disproportionately. We are not asking for plans on the basis of additional enlargements of the European Union, but we want the qualitative improvement of the existing substance. We should always be careful if we want to set our own monuments. If Lux price, then please not as an elitist project for very few, but with broad impact. I think that the House of History should also have been better combined with existing facilities for visitors, which would also show greater proximity to the citizens and a sense of cost. Leading by example, however, also means going with the times. The new rules of the game between the Commission, the Council and Parliament give us more power in the legislative process, and here the upgrading of scientific services is just right. But our claim that we must work here away from any ideology must really apply. Going with the times also means reforming our interpreting services: firstly, in terms of technical equipment, but also in terms of working hours, they must be more efficient and fairly allocated. Unfortunately, security in the European Parliament is also very topical. Cost awareness: Yes, but this must not lead to the dangers of endangering the safety of visitors, staff and Members of Parliament. It is sometimes better if we have our own safety and driving services than to get into the hands of uncontrollable private services. Also structurally, we really should not save at the wrong end. Finally, dismantling privileges. Sins of the past are gradually being remedied, a great deal has been achieved in catering, the voluntary pension fund is closed, but the recovery of the financial legacy must now be much faster. We are now finally calling for the results and recommendations of the external audit of the Fund! Reducing privileges and role models also means that there must be no mixing of presidential function and campaign appearances. There is a very clear criticism of Martin Schulz in the report and, accordingly, a recommendation to other leading candidates. Mr Schulz sometimes cannot distinguish between personal self-promotion and a presidential task: often what he does is not in Parliament's overall interest, and I find it remarkable that the S&D shares this criticism. Finally, a word about the Members themselves: yes, pension funds, flat rates for air travel, catering, many other things – many of the legacy issues have been abolished here. Well, keep it that way, but in the end it must not go so far as to shift the well-being and woe of the EU's image only to us and to our offices. We are taking on more and more things in our offices that an administration would actually have to do. We are now saving on coffee, now we are also saving on water, and some want to force us to put everything on the net from our own ranks, our telephone bills, our movement profiles. Indeed, we even allow the success of our work to be measured by the number of one minute speeches. We should not question the dignity of our activities in such a way that we become a mockery of the people. Our job has value, and we should therefore not sell ourselves below value, which is also taken up in the report.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the main problem of the discharge procedure, which has been ongoing for years, is the discharge procedure concerning the Council and the European Council. Starting from the weakness observed during the budgetary control procedure, we have to indicate the high underspending rate that covers almost all categories, the very high number of appropriations being carried over from 2014-2015, particularly those for property, plant and equipment, as well as major transfers within budget lines. These problems could be avoided with better budgetary programming. For better budgetary programming, key performance indicators have to be developed. Moreover, the Council has still not adopted a code of conduct, which is indispensable to the transparency, accountability and integrity of the institution. There is also a worrying lack of transparency with regard to the legislative process, negotiations and Member States’ positions at meetings within the Council. The Council definitely should disclose the relevant documents and put in place a clearer reporting system that will enable the public to follow the legislative procedures in an open and transparent manner. There is also the problem of the lack of transparency of the trilogues and conciliation meetings. The Council definitely has to increase transparency and integrity with regard to their negotiations. Taking into consideration political problems, as far as cooperation between Parliament and the Council is concerned, we have to indicate that the Council ought to be transparent and fully accountable to Union citizens for the funds entrusted to it by taking part fully and in good faith in the annual discharge procedure, just as other Union institutions do. In this regard, effective supervision of the Union’s budget implementation requires cooperation between Parliament and the Council through a working arrangement. But, as a matter of fact, there is no cooperation, no dialogue. The Council does not participate in the budgetary control procedure and does not provide answers to written questions asked by our Committee on Budgetary Control or by particular members of our Committee. The Council does not participate in the hearings or debates concerning budgetary control procedure regarding the Council. We cannot forget that the procedure of granting discharge separately to the individual Union institutions’ bodies is a long-standing practice which has been developed to guarantee transparency and democratic accountability towards Union taxpayers.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! As rapporteur for two of the reports we are debating here today, I shall briefly review them before moving on to my shadow rapporteurs.  The first concerns the Court of Justice of the European Union, which, in the course of the audit procedure, did very well. Since then, however, there have been media reports and media criticism that the Belgian member of the Court of First Instance has criticised the procedure and reluctance to bring more judges to the Court of Justice. At the same time, it has been a challenge for the Committee on Budgetary Control to have access to the side activities of judges of the Court of Justice alongside their work. In view of these two things, the ECR Group is very concerned about granting discharge to the Court of Justice, as we consider that the uncertainties that have been raised are quite serious. With regard to the European Economic and Social Committee, for which I have also been rapporteur, I would like to commend the committee for following the recommendations made by the European Parliament in previous years in a wide range of areas. You've been able to cut back. It has been able to reach an agreement with Parliament and the Committee of the Regions which has meant better and more efficient procedures. I would therefore recommend that discharge be granted, although I believe that the committee should generally focus more on teleconferences and videoconferencing, and that travel costs are well high and should be cut in the future. With regard to the reports on discharge to the Commission and its agencies and to the European Parliament, I would like to thank my colleagues, as well as the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs, for constructive cooperation. Overall, we in the ECR Group believe that it is a problem that the error rate is still too high. We believe that there is too little focus on the efficiency and added value of the money spent at European level, and we believe that fundamental reforms of the two major items of expenditure, namely agricultural and regional development aid, are needed. In relation to the Accounts of the European Commission, we believe that a good and critical and constructive report has come out of our work. A report that goes a long way in the balance with the ecr's wishes. However, because it contains support for both the Joint European Public Prosecutor's Office and refers to the desire for own resources to a greater extent than we already have today, we in the ECR Group have to vote blankly on the report. In view of the high error rates, we are voting, as is tradition, against granting discharge to the European Commission and the agencies involved. In relation to the European Parliament's own accounts, we think that a line could have been drawn that was a bit more critical. We recognise that in a number of areas good and constructive action has been taken, and we particularly recognise that christian Schulz's behaviour has been approached, but we think there is a need to reject the proposal for a more expensive driver service. We think there is a need to revise our general expenditure surcharge and we think there is a need to move away from the idea of supporting the House of European History. That is why we are voting against both discharge reports. In relation to the joint ventures, we will vote against from the point of view that there is too high a failure rate in the general EU budget.

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, for the Committee of the Regions, where I am rapporteur of Parliament, I say from the outset that I have decided to grant discharge because it is a discharge of encouragement precisely to reform this Committee of the Regions, to understand that we live in a world where every penny counts and it matters how and on what we spend it. A first criticism: we do not walk on citizens' money. In 2014, the Committee of the Regions carried out 787 missions in the Member States and, of these, more than 200 missions in Greece and Italy in September. More than EUR 8 million was spent on members' travel and meeting allowances alone and more than EUR 400,000 for staff. I do not know what European citizens have gained from these missions, but I know for a fact that they have lost EUR 9 million. The documents we received from the Committee of the Regions contained hundreds of pages, they were vague, they were not clear, they were imprecise and without exact figures. A second criticism, speaking of the documents sent, I asked for answers to short questions and could be answered on an A4 page. Instead, i got hundreds of pages again in response. What does this mean? It means that there is an inability to summarise those who work at the Committee of the Regions, it is an excessive bureaucracy, and also sending hundreds of pages to the rapporteur also means a kind of disrespect. Now, a few good things: efforts have been made to adopt rules on whistle-blowers, those in institutions that basically tell us what works, what does not work legally in institutions, so what is illegal, but they only came into force on 1 January 2016. The case of whistleblower McCoy, who has been unable to complete his case since 2003, has already been famous. It's 2016, it's been on trial with the Committee of the Regions for 13 years and I think every man is going crazy to spend 13 years in trials. And OLAF said that this man is right, so it is appropriate for the Committee of the Regions to say, yes, he is right, to end this conflict and, by June 2016, to report to Parliament on how he has resolved this case. Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues at the Committee of the Regions for their cooperation, and I have also visited them. I hope that we will all eliminate excessive and costly bureaucracy because we need to adapt to the rapidly changing world. All of us. Whoever stays behind then should change their jobs. I am also rapporteur for the discharge of the European Data Protection Supervisor. Here I have a few observations: firstly, the Authority must include in its 2015 annual report the decision on whistle-blowers - those who say about illegalities in institutions - in order to comply with the Staff Regulations. I also remind the European Data Protection Supervisor that our CVs, of people are public, circulate freely, as is normal, on the Internet, on Wikipedia, everywhere and, as such, the CVs of European officials or national experts do not fall into the category of data to be protected because, at the moment, the European Data Protection Supervisor is telling the European institutions that CVs should not be published because there is personal data that needs to be protected. No, there are European officials who are at the expense of citizens and their CVs must be published to see them by everyone. I also recommend discharge to the Authority in this case, also for encouragement in the changes it has to make. A few comments ago on the discharge of justice and home affairs agencies because I was rapporteur of the LIBE Committee's opinion for these agencies. Firstly, we still have a problem with the publication of CVs - this one at several agencies. We have a problem with protecting or not protecting, specifically, those who disclose illegalities in institutions, and we have a conflict of interest problem, it seems that the conflict of interest is not yet understood, that it is not normal for people from food companies who participated in the manufacture of that product to work in an agency that says yes or no to a food product. I particularly stop at two agencies: the Agency for Fundamental Rights, where several legal actions have been brought against the Agency due to abuses committed against persons who have reported irregularities and have not complied with the judgments of the Civil Service Tribunal. Let's not make fun of people who tell the truth. And the second agency I want to talk about and conclude is the Food Safety Agency, where I had a blatant case of conflict of interest in January 2016: the agency announced a possible employment as director of a person coming from the food industry. So, even if it subsequently withdrew its candidacy, the agency's mere intention to such employment is inadmissible. How to hire someone in the food industry in a company that gives notice to the food industry and we don't know what we eat, and they get rich at the cost of our health. There are also good examples, Eurojust, for example.

name: Derek Vaughan
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, like the previous speaker I would like to use all my time now and not come back at the end of the debate. I wrote 33 reports for the decentralised agencies. This was a lot of work, and therefore I want to thank my staff – not only the S&D staff, but also the Budget Control Secretariat – for their help, plus the shadow rapporteurs worked with me very closely. At this point, I would like to make a general point about the discharge process and to thank all the rapporteurs for all the discharge reports, particularly the rapporteur for the general discharge – I think she produced a good and well balanced report, which I think will be supported by a majority of this House. For the agencies, I would also like to thank the Commission and the Court of Auditors and all the agencies for working very closely with me. Overall, the agencies received pleasing reports from the Court of Auditors. I shadowed the agencies’ discharge last year, and I am pleased to report that there has been a great deal of progress since then. There were fewer comments from the Court and, importantly, there were no qualified opinions. This means the Court found no reason to call into question the reliability of the accounts, and the transactions underlying the accounts were also legal and were regular in all material respects. I am also pleased to report that the agencies are well advanced in terms of the implementation of actions foreseen in the common approach agreed in 2012, reaching a 99% rate of completion of agency-specific actions. Also, 93% of agencies stated that they now share services with other agencies and institutions, and 75% of the agencies have cooperation agreements. I would therefore encourage all agencies to look at this further in order to make increased efficiency savings. Agencies now also put in place guidelines for inter-agency procurement procedures and for agencies’ participation in Commission-led procurement procedures, which again will, hopefully, lead to efficiencies. Most agencies have already met the 5% required staff reductions. However, I know many agencies are concerned that they are also being asked to contribute 5% extra into a redeployment pool, and I think this is something which needs to be looked at. Over 80% of all agencies have anti-fraud strategies in place. More than 90% of agencies have policies in place on the publication of the CVs and declarations of interest of the management board members and also senior staff and in-house experts. So the picture is looking pretty good, but of course – as with all reports – there are some concerns and some areas which need to be improved. For example, since January 2014 four agencies have been in the same negotiation process with a host Member State about headquarters agreements. Some good progress has been made, but I would urge all Member States to conclude negotiations with their agencies in order that those headquarters agreements can be put in place as quickly as possible. On carryovers, which is a topic that is raised most years, I am pleased to say that most of the carryovers were planned. However, a higher level of cancellations of carryovers from previous years was noted in some cases, which may indicate that the appropriations carried over were made on the basis of overestimated needs or were otherwise not justified. I am pleased, however, to note that most of the agencies concerned are putting in place measures to deal with this issue. In some agencies there is still an issue over gender balance, particularly in senior management positions, and I have asked the agencies network to provide us, as the discharge authority, with a detailed report on steps being taken to address this problem. In addition to this, I would also ask Member States to pursue gender balance when they make appointments to board members for the agencies. Lastly, I wanted to call on agencies to further strengthen their efforts to improve their communication policies, expand their visibility and raise awareness of their activities and achievements. All these agencies do a huge amount of good work for citizens right across the European Union, and they should publicise this work more than they have been doing in the past. That would raise awareness of what they do, but I also think it would be good for the individual agencies as well. The Budgetary Control Committee voted overwhelmingly to grant discharge for all the agencies. This was due to them all receiving an unqualified opinion from the Court of Auditors and because of the progress which they demonstrated in recent years. I therefore hope that tomorrow, when this House votes on the agencies’ discharge, we would once again grant discharge to all the agencies in my report.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my fellow rapporteurs and colleagues on the committee for their cooperation. There is only one amendment on all eight reports on joint ventures, so I think the work in committee has been very good. I think that joint ventures are extremely important during this period, we talk a lot about economic development, growth, jobs. The first condition is to have research, development and, in particular, innovation and implementation in practice of research results. I believe that the joint ventures that are now in operation in the Union have already shown that they are useful, especially in terms of application in practice, especially if we take as a first example, SESAR which has already started implementing the results of research in air traffic management systems, this example is a very good example. Clean Sky has reached the stage of having extremely important technological demonstrators and which can bring great benefits to the aviation industry, I hope that we will also find the financial means to apply in practice. IMI I think it is now going well, to have the results of the research applied in practice. FCH is the only of the joint ventures that used, which in fact contracted all the money allocated during fp7, during the old MFF period. F4energy is a case, let's say more special. Of course it's the domestic agency for ITER, for the international itER organization. I think 80% of what needs to be done there is ordered. There is still a problem in terms of programme and funding. There is a plan tabled by the new director, we are waiting to see this plan approved, that is why we have proposed postponing the discharge until the autumn, but the report supports this international project and, of course, it also supports the joint venture. You know that there were two other joint ventures, ARTEMIS and ENIAC, united into one in ECSEL. ARTEMIS, ENIAC and ECSEL received a qualified opinion from the Court of Auditors on the ground that it is not possible to determine exactly whether the error rates calculated on national rules, because that is the regulation of the three joint ventures, so it cannot be determined exactly whether these error rates fall within the level required by the institutions. I believe that we can take a step forward, I believe that with documents from the national institutions in this area, the national authorities in this area, we could determine whether or not what has been done so far is right. It is Parliament's request, we ask the Court of Auditors and, of course, ECSEL, the joint venture which is now responsible for the work of these former two joint ventures, to request the receipt of these two additional documents and, in this way, to resolve this situation in the future. So we ask for the postponement for ARTEMIS and ENIAC and the award of the discharge for ECSEL. Next, we ask the Court of Auditors in its resolution to provide detailed information or to go further in detail on the assessment of the contribution in kind and the overall contribution of private partners on the error rate and on how the expenditure and use of fp7 and Horizon2020 funds is carried out in parallel, as this activity will take place for a further three years in parallel with the , say, different budget lines. Moreover, I also thank the Court of Auditors for the cooperation we have had and for the repeated meetings and consultation we have had during this period, and I hope that we will continue to resolve what we have to deal with the three deferred discharges.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am happy to be here and to participate today in this important debate on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2014 in the context of the annual discharge procedures, as foreseen in Article 319 of the Treaty. On 23 February my colleague Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the Dutch Finance Minister, had the honour of presenting the Council’s recommendation to grant discharge to the Commission – to the Committee on Budgetary Control – and tomorrow this plenary will cast its vote. Clearly the citizens of Europe expect us to be particularly attentive to the quality of EU spending, and rightly so. However, sound financial management is not only important from a public opinion perspective; it is our legal obligation to execute the EU budget in compliance with the agreed rules. Keeping EU expenditure under strict control is crucial for all of us. The Council recommended that discharge be granted to the Commission and outlined the reasons leading to this recommendation. Nevertheless, the Council also reaffirmed that there is still a lot to improve in the execution of the EU budget. First of all, the Council regrets the insufficient reduction of the error rate of 4.4% and thus the fact that most spending is still affected by a material level of error, and that important policy areas such as agriculture, cohesion and research remain prone to error. The Council was particularly concerned about the fact that, according to the Court’s findings, the Commission, national authorities and independent auditors had enough information to prevent, detect and correct these errors. Clearly, all financial actors involved in the management of EU funds need to assume their responsibilities in full, including Member States. The Council urged the Commission and Member States to strengthen their mutual cooperation and stressed the importance of avoiding errors in the first place. Therefore it highlighted the need to increase the quality of controls in order to prevent or detect and correct errors before declaring costs to the Commission. So yes, I agree with the rapporteur, Claudia Schmidt, that what we need is not more controls but better implementation of the existing control mechanisms. In other words, this should – and could – be done in a cost-efficient way without adding extra layers of control. Moreover, the Council recommendation also recalled that recoveries and financial corrections are essential elements in the protection of the Union’s financial interests. Payments should be interrupted and suspended whenever significant deficiencies are identified and until corrective action has been fully implemented. Unduly-paid amounts must be recovered without delay, and full transparency regarding the implementation of corrective action must be ensured. The Council further calls upon the Commission to provide the budgetary authority in the year 2016 with a comprehensive report based on systematic data already available on the areas where the level of error identified is persistently high, as well as on the root causes. Additionally, the Council also agrees with Parliament that the simplification of rules remains paramount in achieving an unqualified audit opinion. Simplification and improved guidance not only reduces the administrative burden on the beneficiaries and respective authorities but also allows for more efficient and less costly controls. The Council welcomes the Commission’s work in the management of payment appropriations and calls for a constant monitoring of outstanding commitments. It also recalls its request to the Commission to provide transparent and timely information on the long-term cash flow forecast in order to better match payments and available funds with needs. Despite the fact that the revenue part of the budget was not affected by material error, the Council underlines the importance of mitigating the impact of revisions of national GNI data as well as measures to reduce the length of outstanding reservations. Finally, the Council welcomes the Court’s approach in evaluating the results of EU spending and measuring aspects related to performance. The Council encourages the Commission, following the Court’s recommendation, to identify the most suitable and effective performance systems for the EU budget in cooperation with the Court and Member States. So I agree with the emphasis that rapporteur Dlabajová puts on a performance—based budget. Within this context, the Council – while of course being cautious not to prejudge conclusions – welcomes the Commission’s initiative budget, for the results of which I believe the first expert meeting took place last week. It is evident that we are still far from the overall aim of an unqualified audit opinion from the Court. The Council therefore reiterates its wish to see year—on-year improvements in the financial management systems and in the estimated level of errors across all policy areas. The Council is constructively engaged in discussions on how to improve the performance framework of the EU budget and to ensure that this budget delivers better results in view of the Multiannual Financial Framework mid—term review and of the next MFF. The Council invites the Court to provide its input for this review in a timely manner. In conclusion, the Presidency has started to work on the next MFF through the Conference in January and the following discussion at the General Affairs Council on 12 April. The aim is to explore, at an early stage, possibilities for improvement and reform. From this several principles have been identified that could provide a way forward, and the joint results of these discussions will be presented in a Presidency report to the Council, Parliament and the Commission.

name: President. –
text: I just want to announce to colleagues that I know that because of an interinstitutional commitment you will be leaving the Chamber, but you will return and we thank you for that.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, dear rapporteurs, Madam Minister, President Caldeira, honourable members of the European Parliament, of the Court of Auditors, I would like to start by thanking all of you, and in particular the rapporteurs we have listened to, and the Court of Auditors, the Council, for the seriousness with which you approach the debates on the 2014 discharge procedure. We are at a time when Europe requires from us to concentrate on making absolutely best use of our people’s sacrifice. They are those who fund our budget. This year’s discharge is remarkable, with the alignment of all institutions – Parliament the Council, the Court of Auditors, the Commission – on the importance we assign to focusing on the performance of the budget, What and how well it delivers for the EU economy and for our citizens, as well as the compliance with the rules: I recognise we have work to do in both areas. We have stabilised the error rate – we have to continue to drive it down – and, very importantly, we have to work on extracting the highest possible value from our budget. As the Minister just mentioned, five or six days ago, on 22 April, we had the first meeting of the Interinstitutional Working Group on Performance. We start by defining what is performance so we see eye to eye, how we should measure it, as well as how we can move most systematically towards performance-based budgeting. I want to recognise the rapporteur Madam Dlabajová for her determination to make us expand our discussions from what used to be primarily focus on the error rate to a very strong footing in policy objectives and results achieved, and in that spirit I would draw four conclusions for us (not pretending that this exhausts all we have learned from the debate) in the following. First: alignment of budgetary priorities; second: better reporting on performance and budget focus on results; third: dealing with persistently high error rates, a topic that the minister brought up; and last but not least: how we strike the right balance between risk management and risk avoidance. So let me start with the first point. As we approach the midterm review revision, it is time to honestly identify to what degree we are capable of matching political priorities with the dedication of our budget. It is a question that will take us, hopefully, to important conclusions for the rest of this financial perspective, and also it would help us to see whether we are fully and entirely using the flexibility of the budget that has been granted in this multi-year financial perspective. Another part of the debate would be how these political objectives are translated into operational objectives on the ground and how to ensure adequate reporting back on the results achieved. We know that in the current financial perspective we have made a very big step forward in respect of priorities and measures to what extent we achieved what we have said we would achieve, but we are not perfect; there are lessons to be learnt and fed into the preparation for the next generation of programmes, and I want to stress again the importance of interinstitutional dialogue. Working together we can achieve significant improvements. Second, the debate showed a need for better reporting on performance. We have a lot of information available, but we have to organise it so it guides our allocation of resources that we streamlined reporting better, we improved the quality of our indicators. In this respect, I want to announce that we will take an important step this year when the synthesis report in the Article 318 report are combined in one, and this would provide a more complete picture on the implementation of the EU budget. In addition, we are very much aware of the necessity to insensitise earlier detection of risks of errors and errors. Avoiding them in the first place is the best way to deal with them. We also will continue our work on the multi-annual nature of errors. We know that we measure them on an annual basis, but our programmes are multi-annual. We want to provide incentives for corrections so they are actually driving down the cost on errors on our citizens. Third, we have been asked to look into the persistently high level of errors. We are going to present, later in this year, a report with analysis in this area. I want to stress that it would be drawn mostly on the prior experience from the previous multi-year financial framework 2007-2013. There are limitations how much we can translate lessons from there, but we would do our best to assess, on the basis of the latest information, what are the systemic risks and how we can best reduce them. Last but not least, we want people to be mindful of risk management opportunities. The Minister talked about simplification – very important. We have a huge opportunity with the changes in the Financial Regulation to achieve simplification, but we can never bring errors to zero, and we do not want us to shy away from what may be riskier but very high-value activity. Take for example development. If we want to prevent conflicts, to reduce the catastrophic impact of lack of development, we ought to invest in fragile situations. They are riskier, and therefore we have to help our teams to manage these risks. But we do not want them to not to do the right thing because they want to be protected by inaction. Similarly in migration: speed of action there is critical, and we are going to be working under demanding circumstances, where challenges change every day. Let me finish with a quote from Ms Dlabajová. She says: ‘the future becomes the past’. I would add that we should learn from the past to secure a better future, and discharge is fantastic in this regard.

name: Vítor Caldeira
text: President of the Court of Auditors. – Madam President, the European Court of Auditors welcomes this opportunity to participate again in the closing debate of the discharge procedure for the financial year 2014. I would first like to congratulate all the rapporteurs who have intervened and, in particular, Mrs Dlabajová for the huge amount of work she has done, and of course the whole Committee on Budgetary Control. Their reports are indeed valuable for this exercise, and the report on the European Union budget, in particular, draws important lessons that we cannot afford to ignore. Many of those are based on the work we have performed in our reports, so for those working at the Court – for our Members, for our staff – it is very gratifying to see how seriously our recommendations are being addressed in the different discharge reports. In particular, as regards the European Union budget discharge, we think indeed that the challenge now is to ensure that the lessons we have learned from the past, in particular in the 2014 financial year, will lead to short and long-term improvements in the way the European Union funds are used. It is very encouraging to have already listened today to the commitment that all the institutions are showing on the need to act. For that to happen, we need those lessons to be reflected in the mid term review of the current multiannual financial framework; we need them also to be reflected in the revision of the Financial Regulation, and we need to work together – all the institutions in their different roles and capacities – to develop a budget more focused on results. As I said in November last year, we believe it is time to start developing a wholly new approach for European Union spending and investment. That implies the European Union budget being better targeted to the European Union’s strategic objectives; it needs to be more flexible in a crisis – refugees and migration were mentioned – and it also needs to be used more efficiently, and then there is also huge room for improvement. Our 2000 Annual Report highlighted the scope for tackling financial backlogs, reducing payment errors, and improving reports on results. The Commission has welcomed the message, has accepted our recommendations and, as we listen now, is acting upon them. That is very encouraging. In turn, the Court will follow up all these developments in our 2015 annual report, which we are currently preparing. This year we hope to be able to publish it in October, earlier than in previous years. I want to thank the Commission, and in particular Vice-President Georgieva, for their support in achieving this target, and we also very much count on Parliament’s acceptance of this. We are also actively engaged in strengthening dialogue with this Parliament and its committees to ensure that we produce reports that provide you in this House with the maximum assistance for you to exercise effective public oversight over the implementation of the European budget and European Union legislation. I will conclude by saying that the European Union must make the most of the opportunity it has now to fundamentally review how public funds are raised, spent and managed to achieve the European Union objectives.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: Rapporteur for opinion Committee on Foreign Affairs. – As the author of AFET's views on the budgetary discharge of the European Commission and the European External Action Service, I would like to express my support for the recommendations made to these two institutions, in the various reports we are debating today, on how the budget for the Union's external activities is managed. I think that when we discuss how the money related to foreign policy activity has been and is being spent in third countries, it is essential not to forget that the impact we will have depends on a lot of factors: local, regional, factors that we cannot control. I therefore believe that the management of the budget attributed to the Union's external activities must be flexible enough that it can respond quickly and efficiently to developments in third countries. I also believe that the management of these funds must be done in full transparency. I also find it important that both the Commission and the European External Action Service make efforts to drastically reduce delays in payments, errors and improve the number of projects financed by the Union in third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, as rapporteur for the Committee on Development opinion on discharge implementation of the EU general budget for 2014 and on the 8th, 9th, 10th and 11th European Development Funds (EDF), I would like to raise some concerns about certain points that were included in the political resolution accompanying the discharge. First, in both the Committee on Development and the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), we expressed concerns at the inclusion by the rapporteur of some critical and unjustified phrasing and figures drawn from an unofficial working document by a colleague on the CONT Committee and which had never been approved by the CONT Committee. I strongly oppose the inclusion of any references to this document in the EDF discharge. Moreover, the rapporteur calls for one quarter of the 11th EDF to be used in combating the migration crisis. However, the scope of the EDF is to tackle the root causes of migration by supporting sustainable development, and focusing it on addressing existing migration flows would send out a false signal and may lead to a misappropriation of funds. I therefore ask you to vote in favour of Amendments 5, 6 and 7 in order to ensure that the resolution we will adopt tomorrow not only paints an accurate picture of the reality of projects in our missions in this region but also that it does not call into question the fundamental principles of this important fund.

name: David Casa
text: Rapporteur għal opinjoni tal-Kumitat għall-Impjiegi in l-Affarijiet Soèjali. – Irrid niffoka partikolarment fuq ix-xogħol tal-aġenziji tal-Unjoni Ewropea, jiġifieri s-Cedefop, l-ETF, il-Eurofound in l-aġenzija li tittratta s-saħħa in s-sigurtà fuq il-post tax-xogħol. Naturalment, dawn huma aġenziji whether jiffokaw fuq taħriġ vokazzjonali, li jiffokaw fuq systems ta' taħriġ għall-pajjiżi li huma sottożviluppati; huma aġenziji jitkellmu dwar ir-rièerka in x-xogħol importanti tal-analiżi li jagħmlu u anke wkoll kif jiġi pprevenut ir-risk, in jiġi promoss post tax-xogħol sostenibbli in sleep.  Irridu niffokaw ukoll dwar rapport dwar l-implimentazzjoni tal-baġit tal-aġenziji, li kien wieħed pożittiv u xhieda tas-sanità finanzjarja. Irridu però wkoll naraw li dawn l-aġenziji jibqgħu separati, dawn ma jagħmlux xogħol duplicate, qed jagħmlu xogħol importanti, in għandna nħalluhom jagħmlu day ix-xogħol b'mod separat. In fl-aħħar nett, inħeġġeġ lil dawn l-aġenziji jieħdu abbord ir-rakkomandazzjonijiet imressqa f'dawn ir-rapporti għaliex naħseb huwa importanti għall-ġid taä-äittadini tal-Unjoni Ewropea.

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the occasion of this discharge gives us the opportunity, in the field of transport, to make a more important consideration than all the others. There are many comments, but I am focusing on the specific issue of investment, which is crucial if transport policy is to get out of the logic of the proposal and into the logic of implementation.  We have an issue that strongly concerns the performance of this committee: the so-called Juncker Plan. This plan is a plan on which we invest a great deal politically because it aims to pool the investment potential of all the countries of the Union, but it is also a plan that places a great doubt on us, as the Committee on Transport: the misappropriation of resources from the CEF, that is, an instrument that has historically strongly encouraged investment where the relationship between public and private struggles to generate the necessary investments and the necessary resources.  We cannot continue to take resources away from the CEF in order to take them where we are not sure that investment will go in the same direction. The case of rail transport documents this plastically. Therefore, we strongly urge that these resources should not be further reduced, even though we know the invaluable value of the proposal contained in the Junker plan and the EFSI.

name: Ivana Maletić
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the REGI Committee. - Madam President, (incomprehensible) and I welcome Commissioner Georgieva. The level of error in cohesion policy in 2014 has increased compared to 2013, which should not really surprise us. We have so complicated the system with various additional instructions and interpretations that often even the auditors themselves are not sure what is right and what is irregular and have different interpretations.  A complicated system subject to interpretations and changes leads either to irregularities or to non-implementation of activities and standing, because in fear of error, many prefer not to use the means and opportunities provided to them. We have this case with financial instruments for which the instructions are so complicated that it is easier not to use them despite the benefits and benefits they bring.  A clear and simple system is the way to reduce irregularities, as well as to invest in education and the establishment of quality financial management and control systems. This is the investment in prevention that we must work on most with the aim of swift and successful implementation of cohesion and other EU policies and of course with a view to quality implementation of the EU budget.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Tibor Szanyi, who cannot be here today, for the excellent work he has done in drafting the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, which is the result of intensive discussions and excellent cooperation between the political groups.  2014 was a year of transition for the common agricultural policy between the old programming and the implementation of the new reform. And 2015 and 2016 can also be considered years in which the reforms introduced will be fully implemented and there will be new, very complex rules, starting with greening, which is certainly one of the most important innovations introduced by farmers. Although we have seen a reduction in the error rate compared to 2013, we believe that there are still many steps to be taken to reduce the bureaucratic burden on European farmers.  The Commission is already working on simplifying the CAP, through delegated acts and implementation, especially in terms of controls and sanctions, but we believe that the mid-term review of the common agricultural policy can be a valuable opportunity to make spending public money on agriculture more effective and efficient and to increase environmental benefits.

name: Yana Toom
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, I have a few remarks from the point of view of the Committee on Culture. First, I would like to stress that there are certain problems in the youth section of Erasmus+ that relate to access to funding compared to the previous youth and action programme. We regret the current suspension of Erasmus+ youth funding in Greece. Second, there are considerable delays in the final payments by the Education, Culture and Audiovisual Executive Agency. This is unacceptable. It directly affects the beneficiaries’ rights. Third, we believe that the European Schools have still not addressed the issues raised by the Court of Auditors and the need to implement a rotation system for sensitive posts and to address other weaknesses in their work. Fourth, there is a mismatch between the 7—year programming of the MFF and the 10-year programming of the political and strategic priorities of the Union. Fifth, the Europe for Citizens programme: it is a unique tool to promote European values and solidarity, especially considering the increasing popularity of radical right and Eurosceptical parties, but the present funding level is rather low and budget cuts for this programme are not welcomed.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE)
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Madam President, one minute to talk to you about a subject that may seem minor. Three billion euros: this is what the European Parliament cannot control since 2009, simply because the Commission and the Council are turning the ball over to each other in a game of ping-pong. The Council refuses to give its accounts to the European Parliament and the Commission refuses to include the Council's budget in its own accounts. We parliamentarians are therefore unable to control accounts at a time when transparency and the need for information appear more than necessary. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs is taking advantage of the presence of the Commission and the Council to ask them to try to agree and discuss with the European Parliament to put an end to this absolutely ridiculous situation - on a legal - and scandalous - economic point of view, namely that the Council's accounts are beyond budgetary control.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, I would first like to thank Mr Caldeira for the increasingly useful annual discharge report, accompanied by the corresponding special reports, this time underlining the surprise, alarm and concern that the error rate of direct management reached that of shared management in 2014, which was so far our workhorse in the funds earmarked for cohesion and agriculture , and which, this time, has fallen exclusively into the research budget, revealing the high risk of dispensing with ex ante audits as a simplification method. I look forward to a quick and decisive reaction from Commissioner Moedas in such a crucial sector for the future development of the EU.  I would like to thank Mrs Dlabajová and congratulate her on the very constructive and innovative approach, which has made her report a comprehensive and promising review of open control procedures and systems, and aimed at the future results budget, which will require an in-depth debate, but which her recommendations, Mrs Dlabajová, help us a lot to prefigure.  Finally, I would like to thank Mr Pieper for his pragmatic cooperation in further improving the capacities of our house at a time when this Parliament is fighting with verve to fully regain its central role as a co-legislator and control. Hence he respects his views, but does not share them, by attacking, for part-parting reasons, the President of our institution for his role as a listhead in the elections, a role that other candidates also assumed. I believe that it is easier and more important to continue to support you in your struggle to achieve a political platform to which heads of state and prime ministers come and ask to turn.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we dealt in particular with the three supervisory authorities, banking supervision, securities supervision and insurance supervision. First of all, of course, we welcome the fact that the European Court of Auditors has made a positive finding, that the money has been used properly here. Of course, we very much welcome that. On the other hand, we have a number of criticisms regarding the way in which these authorities operate, the methodology of these authorities. I find it very shameful that an authority has not managed to advertise its IT infrastructure in such a way that it can also fully implement the legislation that we have adopted, and that we must therefore now postpone important legislation on financial market regulation by one year. In another supervisory authority, we find that it is likely to interfere with the financial markets far from the legislation in order to work with a variety of guidelines, that is to say, general rules that it enissues. And so there are a number of things that we have formulated very critically in our report. I hope that the discharge procedure is not a formal act, but also contributes to improving the way in which it operates, especially in the case of these three agencies – EBA, ESMA and EIOPA. Then the ECON would be very, very happy.

name: José Blanco López
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Madam President, the European Fisheries Control Agency has exemplary budgetary compliance. Commitment and payment levels improve year after year to 99% and 88% in 2014 respectively. The results it has achieved since its inception are exemplary, as are its contribution to the implementation of the reformed common fisheries policy. The room for improvement is very limited, in particular because of staff reductions and the freezing of its budget. In my view, it is necessary to increase the resources available to it — financial and human — so that this Agency can continue to fulfill the responsibilities assigned to it in the reform of the common fisheries policy.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Parliament has a say in the budgetary procedure, but that also means that we must ensure that the funds of the EU budget are used in a targeted manner, but also in accordance with the rules. This is all the more so because the bulk of the budget is implemented by the Member States in shared management, in shared management. We should therefore not be afraid to identify the errors and irregularities in those Member States where they occur, so that the control and supervisory functions in those states are improved. If we have a target of two per cent error rate in the use of funds, then we cannot accept the error rates recorded by the Court of Auditors repeatedly being far above that, and most of the same Member States are affected. If, in some cases, some countries are three times higher than the average for financial corrections involving recovery of funds, I think that is a figure that also indicates that the budget has not been implemented in a targeted manner. The recoveries that have occurred in the context of the financial corrections are then funds that are not being implemented for growth, for employment and for the objectives for which they were intended. We therefore welcome corrections and also recovery as effective instruments for protecting the budget, because the protection of the budget is also the protection of taxpayers in the European Union.

name: Георги Пирински
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, Mrs. Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to mark three points. The first is that how the Commission spends taxpayers' money is undoubtedly evidenced by the error rate that is allowed, and this should remain a very important measure precisely of how much taxpayers can be satisfied with the way the Commission acts on the budget. At the same time, however, it is clear that people ultimately care about how much and how their lives are changing, how much job opportunities, income, security are improved thanks to the contribution of budgetary events under the European Commission.  And I would like to point out here, and this is the second point, that Ms Dlabayova's report in this regard represents, in my view, an appropriate combination of attention and analysis on both sides of the commission's assessment of actions. I would also like to thank her in this regard as one of the shadow rapporteurs who sought to contribute to this report. The third point relates to an important aspect of the report, it is contained in paragraph 73, where there is an explicit call that citizens do not understand this error rate very well and that the European Court of Auditors, together with the Commission, needs to try to achieve unity in the methodology for error assessments and omissions on the basis of single standards and reporting procedures. This is very important in order to have an objective assessment of who is spending the funds properly.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Mr President of the Court, I would like to begin by thanking Speaking in this debate on the 2014 discharge, I would like to focus on section 3 expenditure – the Commission and the executive agencies, because that is an essential part of the EU budget.  With regard to the expenditure of this section, I would like to draw attention to two serious problems in my opinion. The first is a worryingly high level of error, which averaged 4.4% in payments and was similar to 2012-13. Moreover, in budget measures such as cohesion and agriculture, which account for nearly 70% of expenditure, it was even higher at 5.7% and 6.2% respectively.
