Although the error rate is not synonymous with fraud or waste, it may also mean spending in violation of the current rules, but nevertheless reservations are about spending around EUR 5 billion in this way, and unfortunately this amount is increasing from year to year. The second problem is the zero absorption in 2014 for many programmes under the 2014-20 financial perspective resulting from the late adoption of regulations by the Commission, which may negatively affect the use of budgetary resources in subsequent years.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: on the alde group. – Madam President, I am now speaking as shadow rapporteur for the report on the discharge of the European Development Fund. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur, Claudia Schmidt, for their good work and cooperation. Let me express my delight at the fact that many of the new elements that I introduced in the 2013 Report on the European Development Fund are becoming an integral part of the discharge text. Whether it is a result-oriented and performance-oriented view or the conclusions and formulation of recommendations for the next period. In the area of development aid, too, economic criteria must be respected and reality perceived. However, I admit that the reality is still changing, quite significantly, even in the portfolio of activities of the European Development Fund. As I propose in the case of discharge for the european commission's management, the European Development Fund should evaluate whether its funds are focused on real priorities. In my opinion, these are currently two main areas: migration issues and protection against terrorist risks. Their non-implementation may jeopardise any other development activities supported by the European Union. Limited resources need to be allocated in a targeted way where the greatest benefits for the countries to which they are addressed are identified, while at the same time benefiting Europe, its integrity, development and future existence based on the values on which European integration was founded almost seventy years ago. Let us keep these values for future generations, for their importance does not fabeg over time, but rather grows.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President! First of all, thank you to colleagues for some very good reports. I must admit, however, that it also feels somewhat hopeless. Exactly one year ago, we were also here discussing the EU's accounts, just as we have done the years before. Every year we point to the absurdity of the Council choosing not to answer our questions. This is absurd at a level where it can hardly be described. It is a mockery, not just against us in this House, but especially against the people, that you close the doors and refuse to let us look after things. We in the European Parliament should be happy to act as the citizens' watchdog. Today we have even heard the Council call on the Commission for openness and transparency, but without a single word in response to the criticism against themselves. This year will be the eighth year in a row that we are refusing to approve the Council's accounts. Yet nothing happens. This shows a total lack of respect for the citizens!  It must be said to the Commission's credit that there is indeed a willingness to engage in dialogue here. Thank you for that, even if there are problems here too. It has to be said that the error rate - that is, how many errors are made in the payment of money - is still too high. I know that the Commission says that you would like to do something, but I have to say that it is often as if you are trying to shift responsibility away from you and onto others. It is frustrating to see that taxpayers' money is still being spent at such a high error rate. We owe it to the citizens to get a grip on this. After all, it's their money.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Therefore, the error rate in the use of The European Development Fund's resources is also much higher than allowed in 2014. What is more, this is the third consecutive increase in recent years, and the Court of Auditors also states that the Commission should have sufficient data at its disposal to prevent and correct most of the errors, and thus this error rate could be reduced by as much as two percentage points and, for the first time in the history of the budgetary discharge, we would no longer talk about the level of error, but could focus all attention on the area of assessing the effectiveness of development projects. The level of error must not therefore be our only focus, correctness and legality should have been taken for granted long ago. The increasingly harsher situation, especially in developing countries, reminds us that we need to go a step further and demand that projects help to make the progress of the region and the country. The main principle in assessing the long-term results of these projects must become results not only in the economic but also social, environmental and human rights areas.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are 150 billion properties of 500 million citizens in the European Union budget, which must be met absolutely in terms of results, but above all total traceability and transparency.  Transparency in this report calls for the publication of all financial documentation relating to European funds, both structural and direct, on infrastructure projects, which are very often useless and very expensive, such as Turin-Lyons and other major projects. With regard to transparency in public procurement, the rules are already very permissive, but often contracts managed in the regions are not transparent and regular, as the European Court of Auditors reports.  With regard to transparency on refugee funds, it is absolutely essential to avoid a lack of transparency on the pretext of the emergency and to avoid funding organised crime, fraud and speculation on this sensitive issue. Transparency on pre-accession funds: are they political bribes or real funding? We want total and public information, for example the billions given to Turkey, a country that continues to violate the rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. There is one point in this report which calls for this reflection.  Finally, tomorrow we will vote on a very important amendment on the transparency and publicity of scientific data that are analysed by EFSA, the European Food Safety Authority: it is not clear to us whether we are eating poison or not – and I am referring to the glyphosate case.  Does this Europe defend the health of its citizens or monsanto's interests? EFSA should only use data subjected to a scientific and peer review process,

name: Louis Aliot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the complicated architecture of the European Union leads to mis-assignments, exorbitant costs, unacceptable waste and an opacity that is both technical and control that drives the European problem away from peoples and nations. Too often, the same errors are repeated from year to year and errors found in the past are almost never corrected. The only satisfaction is the quality of the work of the Court of Auditors, which allows Members to better understand the problem and try to deal with it. Questions remain, in particular, about the President of the European Parliament's use of the institution's means for electoral purposes, as was said earlier. The answers provided by the latter have not been clear, and I find it surprising that the EPP and The Socialists are co-authoring amendments on this delicate issue. Perhaps OLAF should address this embarrassing issue, because it is tainting the entire institution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the role of the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and its mission are important and commendable and its activities must be financed. But I have the following questions: has anyone informed the Centre of the unacceptable and tragic health situation in Greece, because of the inhumane measures of the Memorandum imposed, including by the European Union, on the Greek people for six years?  Does anyone know that health care in Greece is almost non-existent because, because of austerity measures, money is not available in the health sector? Are you aware that every week hospital managers, in cooperation with doctors, decide which cares will be cut? Are you aware that no money is available for the purchase of medicines that treat dangerous diseases, resulting in the dying of helpless patients? Are you aware that suppliers of sanitary materials have restricted deliveries, resulting in clinics facing shortages of basic materials and suffering patients? Are you aware that the food given to hospitals has been restricted? Are you aware that those who have no money are sentenced to death? Are you aware that mortality in Greece has increased to a very large extent?  Does Greece have the most flu deaths of any other country in the European Union? Most children are unvaccinationally; infant mortality and premature births of children, who are also dying, have risen sharply because there is no proper care. What is the European Union doing about all this in order to prevent this genocide of the Greeks? Nothing more than tolerating Turkey sending hundreds of illegal immigrants carrying dangerous diseases that have, for many years, been forgotten.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, let me thank Mrs Ingeborg Grässle and other colleagues from the Committee on Budgetary Control for their excellent work on the reports. I think that we have really done a huge amount of work and that the Committee on Budgetary Control is becoming one of the most respected committees in this Parliament. I would like to mention two things here. First of all, I would mention the European External Action Service, which we are addressing a number of recommendations. It's right for Mrs. Frederica Mogherini. First of all, it is the structure of this service. In my view, this structure is too complex, cluttered and therefore counterproductive. We criticise that areas where quick, clear decisions should be made are cumbersome, lack analysis and too slow. We also criticise recruitment procedures, which are lengthy, stale. It also criticises the selection of diplomats who are only from the old Member States and are not from the new Member States. We also consider the functioning of embassies to be problematic. The second part of my speech is devoted to criticism of the European Council, which has long refused to be complicit in the discharge. I would therefore like the European Commission to contribute to finding a solution to this long-standing problem, where discharge is not granted to the European Council and the Council because of non-work.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Mr Caldeira, i would like to thank you for your comments. Let me start with a wonderful sentence, one of the first Mrs Dlabayova, who said: discharge cannot be used for political games.  Two. I would like to refer mainly to the Pieper report (nota bene thank you very much to Mr Pieper for his good cooperation) and to what he said: the value and importance of the work of the European Parliament and its Members are of great importance. And the Commissioner was kind to say about two important indicators or measures, namely the error rate and the achievement of policy objectives. It should be combined. Discharge to the European Parliament – the error rate is 0.5%, a year ago it was 1% – this is an improvement. Parliament's reputation is clearly growing, and here we should, rarely, pay tribute to President Schulz and Secretary Klaus Welle. As an institution that gives discharge, we serve as an example ourselves.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: First of all, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs for their excellent work. In addition, the Court of Auditors, the Commission and the Presidency would like to thank them for their presence. My contribution is about the discharge of the parliamentary budget. Unfortunately, I have to say that our own President is once again not present, despite the fact that we, as a Parliament, are granting discharge to our own President. I would therefore like to reiterate my wish to insist that the President be present. (The President interrupts the speaker) I hope that message can be conveyed again. And I say that especially as a Dutchman. In the last election campaign, I once again noticed how vulnerable we are as an institution. In the European elections in the Netherlands, the debate was about one thing, namely expenses and nothing else. All the other work we do here is being swept away by the public debate in the Netherlands about expenses. That is why I would like to stress once again how important it is that we in Parliament are transparent about these expenses. Two years ago, on 16 April 2014, we adopted a resolution in plenary asking the Secretary-General to check our own general expenses through 'light arrangements'. Unfortunately, none of that has come in. Today there is another amendment calling for this. I would not only ask my colleagues to vote for it, but I would also like to urge the President that he will make this work work this year.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr Gerbrandy, I have a question when you are turning to President Schulz. "Unclear matters" – we know that it was the so-called Spitzenkandidat, did you also ask your President Guy Verhofstadt, the president of your political group? Also there was Spitzenkandidat. Has he made a similar report or been treated like President Schulz?

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Well Mr Liberadzki, maybe it was because I was talking Dutch, but I was not criticising the President per se. I was not saying ‘Mr Schulz’ and I was not criticising the President because he was one of the Spitzenkandidaten. I was criticising him because we grant discharge to the President of this House – and in national parliaments that is also the rule – and I believe that the President of this House should be present at the debate on the discharge of this organisation. That has nothing to do with political colour or the person in office; it is a general principle, from my side, that I believe that the President of this House should be responsible and should be present. (The speaker agreed to take a second blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr Gerbrandy, I would just like to tell you that, according to that principle, Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk should also be here, right? I haven't seen that amendment you've talked about. I hope you'll introduce her again next time.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I do believe that is important, but I have been repeating this message for years and years, and I believe – since this is our own House, and since we are always criticising the rest of the world, especially the other institutions – that we can also criticise ourselves, and that we should do that more often and look more internally to our own functioning. But I agree with your point.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about two discharges as shadow rapporteur, first about the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). The glyphosate scandal raises many procedural anomalies in the field of transparency and conflicts of interest in EFSA. I believe that we should stand firm and should not grant discharge to EFSA until conflicts of interest of experts are resolved properly.  Second, regarding the discharge of the Parliament, the EP is pointing the finger in different scandals – LuxLeaks, Dieselgate and now the Panama papers – trying to explain what happened and who is responsible on one side. On the other hand, MEPs are not truly transparent when it comes to their own expenditure, including the general expenditure allowances, which are not transparent and not accountable. We have to be completely transparent and thus earn the credibility of voters, and not only point at other institutions but also do the same ourselves.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – There are few times when the European Union reflects on its very existence and its actions in front of its citizens. I therefore take the discharge for the general budget to give this Parliament of this European Union a sense of reflection on this. The almost religious dogmatics, in which those in power always see more Union as a better solution to any problem, must stop. Firstly, this has not proved to be true: both the euro chaos and the immigration chaos perfectly illustrate this. Secondly, the population does not agree. I therefore strongly protest against the arrogant way in which the result of the recent Dutch referendum on EU policy has been ignored in this Parliament.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say a few words about the agency's discharge procedure. Firstly, I would like to thank the reporter and the other shadow notions for their excellent cooperation. The current discharge procedure for agencies is also special because, for the first time in a long time, the Committee on Budgetary Control proposes to grant discharge to all agencies. This year, all agencies received a statement of assurance from the European Court of Auditors, and during the closure procedure, the still open issues were clarified with the agencies. The financial situation of the agencies and the regularity of their operation have steadily improved in recent years. The Opinion of the European Court of Auditors on the financial year 2014 was positive compared to previous years and did not raise any objections.  I believe that the 'common approach' approach, the unification of the functioning of the agencies, has been effective and that a much more orderly and transparent agency structure has already been developed. Nevertheless, we cannot ignore the fact that in some agencies the Court of Auditors has made remarks called 'emphasis of matter'. These minor objections were processed by the reporter in the discharge reports, and the agencies promised to remedy these problems. In the coming years, we will have to focus on further strengthening the transparency and efficiency of the agencies and, where action is still needed, helping the agencies concerned. On the part of the People's Party, I support the granting of discharge for all agencies.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to mention several aspects of the budgetary discharge for joint ventures of the European Union. This year we decide on seven discharges to companies. Despite some minor disagreements with the rapporteur, our position has become closer to five of them. These are Clean Sky, ECSEL, IMI, SESAR and ITER. ITER is undoubtedly the most ambitious energy project in the world, with other very important countries in addition to the European Union. The European Union, through Fusion for Energy, is one of the most important partners. Together, these countries are building the so-called tokamak, a pre-escalation to the commercial use of thermonuclear fusion in the energy sector. WITH its budget, unique concept and technological complexity, ITER logically stands out among other businesses, but it also stands out. I am aware of the problems to date and the unrealistic plans relating to the budget. On the other hand, I believe that at the moment the new management can bring about a new solution, a new action plan and also a new approach. I hope that this will be evaluated in September when the discharge is granted.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors and the Court of Auditors for the excellent report. This is very important for our Parliament. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Martina Dlabajové from our group. With its report, it has provided groundbreaking information and guidance. The political groups share the common concern for better use of public funds. Innovation, growth, research and development, infrastructure are in urgent need of money. It is therefore unacceptable for money to be wasted when it is not used properly. Here, as in previous years, the Court of Auditors has pointed out maladministration which urgently needs to be rectified. Above all, however, we want to move towards a results-oriented budget, to performance-based budgeting. Here we would like to thank Commissioner Georgieva warmly for her commitment and encourage her to fight even more consistently in the Commission for this cause. We expect you to propose pilot projects on how this can be implemented so that we can discuss together how better financial management can be implemented in a modern budget. As a Parliament, we should also begin to take the Court of Auditors more seriously by giving the special reports a higher priority in the specialist committees. Here are important references – for example, to the task force for Greece, but also in other areas. If Parliament makes better use of this much data, then we can also achieve better spending.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as the tasks of the European Union have expanded, Parliament’s annual scrutiny of the Commission and other institutions and bodies in their task of implementing EU budget appropriations has taken on growing importance for the Union’s taxpayers. But having said this general remark, why actually is the discharge so important? It is so important because the European Parliament is the only European institution that is directly elected by citizens, and therefore we have a crucial role in supervising the use of the taxpayers’ money. Our role is to enhance the transparency of financial management and improve democratic accountability to EU taxpayers. Our role is to make sure that our common rules are obeyed. We need to further improve accountability by putting more focus on performance and results, but at the same time by being able to admit and correct things if something went wrong. But most importantly, Parliament’s role in the procedure must be strengthened. Discharge is often overlooked, and the only reason for that is, in my mind, that it is not given the institutional role and importance that it deserves. As long as the discharge is not binding, we are undermining not only this House but, more importantly, the Union itself.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, this House, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors for the good cooperation – the cooperation we would also like to see with the Council. As in previous years, the Committee on Budgetary Control recommends once again that the discharge of the Council and the European Council should not be granted at the moment, but that it should be postponed for the time being. As in previous years, this decision by the European Parliament is based on the Council's unwillingness to cooperate, which in turn is based on a different legal view as far as the granting authority is concerned. For years, the Council has refused to provide the relevant documents and information that would be necessary for any discharge. In the interests of transparency and out of the EU's responsibility towards its citizens and the financial resources they raise, it would be desirable for the Council to recognise the fact that the entire European budget must be subject to controls by a democratically legitimate political institution, the European Parliament.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Vaughan, for the work done on the 2014 discharge to the agencies. The budget of the agencies in 2014 is about EUR 1.9 billion and they employ in different capacities almost 10 000 persons. On the positive side, there is an approach towards the introduction of performance-based budgeting in most of the agencies, increasing the level of implementation of the budget and promotion of their work to the citizens. Nevertheless, there is still a need to improve the principles which would increase the value-added aspect and to identify possible improvements to the performance models currently applied in the agencies. Conflicts of interest and transparency within the structures that spend the money of the European taxpayer is an important issue. While most of the agencies have taken the appropriate steps, there is still a need for overall improvement in the public sector and for a holistic approach. Concerning communication and visibility, there is a need for the agencies to further strengthen their efforts to improve their communication policies. In order to raise awareness of their activities and achievements and to ensure that citizens are well informed about their work, they should expand their visibility through different social media tools. Despite some discrepancies and the need for further improvements in certain fields, there is positive change in the functioning of the agencies. We expect a better performance of these structures, which are important for implementation of the European Union policies.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Madam President, President of the Court of Auditors, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has We are pleased, Mr Caldeira, that you are back with us. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the Dutch Presidency for being here. We do not often have to deal with defence ministers. I am not sure that we have left a lasting impression, but in any case, you pass on our thanks to Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert for being there. The Dutch Presidency is an active one, particularly in the field. Thanks for that! I would like to take up a word from President Caldeira: more efficiency. This year, in the discharge procedure, when you sit up there, you think about one thing or another, I have awarded a lobbying prize. In my view, this year's lobbying prize is deserving of the interpreters of this House, who have been particularly opposed to efforts to bring more efficiency into their area. That is why I would like to pay tribute to the Secretary-General of this House. That was exactly what we needed, which is to try to be more efficient. Personally, I would like to tell my own colleagues that it is not expedient to become the top lobbyist of detailed interests. I can well understand that not everyone likes such efforts. The same applies to development aid. Apparently everyone in the world has noticed that development aid is dead, but we have not yet. I believe that we need much more courage, including courage to change, in order to really proactively approach things. We have been under considerable pressure from DG DEVCO and, of course, from the Development Assistance Committee. I believe that we need to exploit the information we have, otherwise we will be completely implausible. I really want to encourage the Commission to include in EU laws that officials cannot apply for EU funding either in the EU or in third countries. This would really be an elimination of a significant reputational risk for the EU.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have heard colleagues that they are confused and angry by the numbers they see. There's no reason for that kind of emotion, colleagues. It is normal that at the end of the programming period, when there are more payments, there will be more errors. That, of course, doesn't mean we shouldn't be fake and that we shouldn't be critical. We must, but we must not see an enemy behind every tree. It is true that at this time, when we relieve ourselves of budgetary responsibility, we hear relatively uniform answers to relatively identical questions. The difference this year is that there is a team from the European Commission that works well, it is dialogueal and Parliament's opinion is taken into account. In addition, however, I also have something to ask for more and I would like to see a clearer focus on approved payments next year. This is the only way to achieve the goals we have in Europe 2020 faster. This is the only way to achieve faster the objectives we have in the multiannual financial framework. Since the beginning of my term, I have been working to reduce red tape. I wish we could show more results to people out there. This is what we are waiting for, and this will happen when we base the control of European funds on the risk of losing them, and this will happen when beneficiaries who work badly and mess with European funds get more control than those who do well. Only then will we relieve them. I am pleased that Bulgaria was one of the countries that first implemented the European Commission's public procurement guide and caught up with the backlog it had from 2013 and 2014 due to internal problems, and in 2015 was one of the countries that was first with the absorption and payment of European funds.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have signed up to discharge the European Parliament's 2014 budget in order to support the Lux Film Price and its further funding. I would like to point out that expenditure on the organisation of the film prize decreased to EUR 391 500 in 2014. These are the means for evaluating films, subtitling them, making copies and also for the closing ceremony. In 2014, the funds were increased by EUR 193 000 to promote this prize. The promotion is associated with screenings in all twenty-eight countries, and this screening was attended by more than thirty-five thousand viewers in 2014, free of charge. Overall, expenditure in 2014 was around EUR 500 000. It must be said that these funds are spent here to support the production of European filmmaking with themes that promote European values.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, ENISA is the only decentralised agency in the European Union located in Greece, which has spent millions of euros to support its operation. Mrs Georgieva, ENISA has state-of-the-art offices of 4,500sq.m. Heraklion, Crete. Unfortunately, however, only ten people are employed in these offices, since the Agency's operational centre has been moved to Athens, despite the fact that the Greek authorities have implemented all the commitments they had made for the operation of ENISA in Heraklion.  Unfortunately, on 16 March, Parliament's Committee on Budgets supported the enisa administration's methodologies and effectively paved the way for the Agency's obsolescence in Heraklion. The ultimate aim of enisa leadership is to move the headquarters to Brussels. Since 2012, as a Member of Parliament for Heraklion, I have been fighting with the local authorities to stop the methodologies of the ENISA leadership, which came here last week, here in the European Parliament, in an arrogant tone and mocked meps.  Mrs Georgieva, please take the ISSUE of ENISA seriously.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has done. In the course of today's debate, we are discussing the budget discharge of 53 actors from the general budget. Since this is very complex, I would like to focus on the agencies. The European Court of Auditors is truly extremely grateful for this excellent work. The audit reports show that there are still many weaknesses in the financial assistance granted, and this is due to the lack of control systems. As a result, there are incorrect grant procedures and also intransparency and inefficiency. Five agencies have been found to have significant shortcomings in performance monitoring and evaluation. These are the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, the Frontex Border Agency, the European Environment Agency, the European Food Safety Authority and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. These five agencies alone account for 92% of the EUR 740 million budget. Similarly, in the area of the use of funds, these agencies have not taken sufficient care of alternative funding options, such as private financing, which has limited the effectiveness of funding. That is why I am calling for a reform of financial aid.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, First of all, I am glad that the work of the shadow rapporteurs has led to the 'delivery of pepper to the report', a quote from our shadow rapporteur, whom I greatly appreciate. I would particularly like to address the issue of payment delays. It appears in several places of this report. In my opinion, it is precisely the delay in the absorption not only of multiannual funds under cohesion policy that is rightly criticised in the discharge, but also important to say that the delay in direct payments or simply the payments to which the beneficiaries are entitled is very much jeopardising the credibility and credibility of the European Union as a whole. I don't think that should happen. We have repeatedly criticised this within the Committee on Regional Development, and I am very glad that this report has also been taken into account in several other places, not only in cohesion policies, but also, for example, in humanitarian organisations or in the payment of various cultural projects.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, of course it is very important that the European Parliament has oversight of our budgets and see that public money is properly spent. Transparency and performance-based budgets are essential. One area that was mentioned was in relation to pilot projects, and I think this is an area we should really focus on, especially as regards our commitments in COP21 and Mr Juncker’s desire that Europe be world-leading in terms of renewables. So innovation and pilot projects in that area are vital. I would also like to mention briefly another point which seems to have gone off the agenda, and that is own resources. It was very much part of our discussions in the last mandate, but it seems to have gone off the agenda in this mandate. As we all know, it is most unlikely that Member States are going to increase their contributions to the European Union, and the demands are going up all the time. We should look at own resources as a means of funding.

name: Vítor Caldeira
text: President of the Court of Auditors. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for the kind words about the work done by the Court of Auditors. That is encouraging for us. We welcome all the suggestions for future audit work in the different discharge reports. I would like to note in particular the requests for the Court to continue to develop its approach to auditing the Commission’s reporting on the implementation of the Europe 2020 Strategy. We take note of the remarks on joint undertakings, on the need for more information, but I would like to say that the recommendation on the discharge report, which suggests that the issue of the error rates is a methodological problem to be solved between the Court and the Commission, probably does not move us forward. What we need to do is address the root causes of the problems. I welcome the reference from Vice President Georgieva to matters of risk. Those who draft laws, those who agree on the projects and programmes to be funded, have to acknowledge, from the beginning, how much risk they want to take. Do not ask the auditors to do that. The auditors have to identify whether or not there is a material level of error. So we take good note, but if you look on this as a methodological issue to be solved between the manager and the auditor, we will not make progress. I think the point is that we do indeed need to develop a new approach on European Union spending and investment for the future. This is a challenge we, as a new institution, share with all the European institutions. We need to work together on that, and now. I have already underlined three major lines of action where the Court is very willing to contribute. We very much welcome the Council invitation to contribute to the mid term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). We very much welcome the opportunity to provide our views and opinions on the review of the Financial Regulation. We think that this is a good moment to streamline this for the future, but also to develop a budget more focused on results. We are contributing in that capacity as an auditor already. So be sure that for our part we look forward to contributing to this interinstitutional dialogue, which needs to produce concrete action that will make it possible in the future to have better financial management and accountability for all European citizens.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I took two minutes more in my opening speech, and I will pay that back now in my closing remarks by being short and focused. I have just three points to make. One: an expression of gratitude for the debate we had today, for the issues that have been raised on the policy side, as well as a very specific request to pay attention – and we will indeed reflect very carefully upon, and respond to, the comments that have been made today. More importantly, two: we are already working on the follow up to the 2014 budget discharge resolutions and we will report back after the summer break this year. Three: listening to the comments that have been made, of course we have to continue looking at preventive action and corrective action on the side of errors. That is very important. This work has to continue. We will continue to work with the Court of Auditors on how we can best integrate what we have learned from its reports and from our own work. President Caldeira would not understand it if I did not bring it up, but we will continue to look at the issue of the multi annuality of our programmes. We want to be prudent in making sure that we can, over a longer period of time, achieve the best possible results on the side of errors. But at the same time we are very grateful to those who have spoken and recognised there are things that Member States and we in the Commission do well. And, of course, the Court of Auditors recognises in its reports that we can also draw on what we do well, especially on the policy side, and use it to generate more replication of good practice, making sure that good practice is the normal practice – I would even say best practice should be the normal practice. Our commitment to engage is very strong – to engage with Parliament, with the Court of Auditors, with the Council – and you can count on me and my staff, on all of us, to be available for this discussion to be a continuous process and not a one off in this House.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for all your constructive comments, opinions and your support. I believe that tomorrow, in the vote, I will be able to meet this professional challenge and successfully complete the discharge process for the European Commission. I also thank my entire team, thank you to the Secretariat of the Committee on Budgetary Control, who have been actively involved in the joint work and have been a great support to me all along. I very much congratulate the rapporteurs from the Committee on Budgetary Control for the other discharges, and I also thank the draftsman of the opinions from the other committees. The cooperation with the other expert committees was really excellent. Of course, I thank Commissioner Georgieva and I thank the President of the European Court of Auditors. My efforts in working to discharge the European Commission have been to achieve maximum transparency, objectivity and a project approach in its preparation, respecting the financial interest of the entire European Union and its citizens. I am pleased that this approach has manifested itself in the final text on which you will vote tomorrow. I would appreciate it if it were followed up by the creation of a new discharge report for 2015, which will start in just a few months. I will be happy if the proposed recommendations in the area of The European Union's budgetary policy are reflected in the work of the Committee on Budgetary Control and also affect the work of the other parliamentary committees and institutions of the European Union.  Finally, I would like to propose that we really strengthen the dialogue between our institutions, that we insist on follow-up, that we create and actively work in the results-oriented budget working groups. And, where appropriate, they have also found the possibility of continuous control of the European budget, in particular the european commission's management, as is the case, for example, in the European Semester process, which is based on year-round synergies between the main institutions of the European Union and has fixed deadlines for the fulfilment of the obligations. This is the only way to prevent repeated problems with the error rate in the use of European funds and cases that do not contribute to the credibility of European economy in the future.

name: Claudia Schmidt
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. A great deal has been said this afternoon. As a brief response, I would like to stress once again, as rapporteur for the EDF, that we not only want to combat the causes of the refugee crisis and promote sustainable development, but we also want to be able to react quickly and flexibly to existing and imminent requirements. It is not a question of protecting ourselves from existing things that have not proved their worth, or even of people, but of using development aid money – that is taxpayers' money – in a sensible way and in the interests of the cause. I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those involved in my report. I hope that the vote will be based on common sense.

name: Markus Pieper
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am grateful for the suggestion and criticism of my report. First of all, I was astonished at the administration when it came to safety aspects, driving services and more re-switching to internal services. There are now a number of amendments to my report which go in exactly the opposite direction. That is why I raised this again today. Basically, the direction of the administration is quite okay. Then there is the issue of independence and the value of the mandate: I would like to express my thanks for the support that has come from many here. However, I really have to say to the Liberals, now to Mr Gerbrandy, that if the European Parliament's discharge report and the election campaign at home are confined to the issue of flat-rate costs and have nothing else on it, then this is a sign of poverty as far as liberal policy in the European Parliament is concerned. There should be a bit more to come than just stiffening up on this one topic, I'm a bit sorry. And then to criticise Mr Schulz for not being here today, and then to ask me a question and not to be there now. So, please, Mr Gerbrandy, next time I would assume that you will have a bit of mummy and listen to the answer. One final remark: we have, as Ingeborg Gräßle has indicated, dealt with pensions, interpreting costs, building policy, privileges, everything possible. Every force here in the European Parliament has an incredibly strong lobby: yes, save, but please not with me! So if we give in every time, we, as the Committee on Budgetary Control, will achieve nothing at all. That is why I would like to thank once again those who hold certain positions together with us, who go through and then really improve something in one place or another. I am, in fact, slowly tired of the fact that the national interest, institutional interest, the interests of employees and the employer's interest are the discharge of our Parliament. We should already have our own opinion and persevere with it.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam President of the European Commission, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr S Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Representatives of the Dutch Presidency, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab, This time I will speak Polish, I have spoken English before, also 3 minutes, and I will say that, above all, our cooperation with the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg – the cooperation of the European Parliament and, in particular, of the Committee on Budgetary Control – is much better at the moment than it was 7 years ago, as I remember, or six years ago. This is progress and at the moment we are playing together in one team, a team of auditors, and I think that is a good signal for the European taxpayer and for all those who want European money to be spent as prudently as possible.  The second point is that it seems necessary to make it very clear, in the context of the European External Action Service, in the context of EU diplomacy, that certain geographical quotas are still needed. This is absolutely obvious and absolutely basic. If we hear that out of the 128 heads of delegation, the Delegations of the European Union, 60 are almost from the Member States and from these 60 only 20 from the countries of the new Union, then of course we can talk about some important disparities. If my country should have 11 EU ambassadors by population (Poland by population) and it has 4, then indeed these disparities are a fact, and this also applies to other countries of the new Union, and that is to be said. Similarly, since it is not just the European External Action Service, it is the same in the European institutions. Not yet the best, but it is relatively good in the European Parliament, worse in the European Commission, the worst in the European Council. And here we come to the European Council. I wanted to say that I have the feeling that every year there is the same spectacle played: we are right all the time complaining and complaining about the Council, we stress the lack of willingness to cooperate, the lack of this political will – political will – on the part of the Council, and we are right all the time, we are constantly declaring the same thing and, of course, no response. There is an old Polish saying: he talked grandfather to the picture, the image to him not once. We bounce these balls to the Council and it has no effect. It is really time for a very hard position by the European Parliament on this issue, because it cannot be that these two institutions do not cooperate because of the council's lack of willingness to cooperate.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! It has been a long debate, but I think it has taken us forward. I would like to thank both the shadow rapporteurs who have helped me get through my reports, but also the rapporteurs where I have been allowed to be shadow rapporteur. I think that most of the discharge reports are reasonably objective and they go to the steel, where we as a Parliament are required to exercise very hard control over how taxpayers' money is spent. I think it is commendable that there have been no taboo issues, that we have been struck down in most places where it was necessary. The only place where I really think that we could have done a little harder was in relation to ourselves - in relation to Parliament. I always think it is commendable to set the same high standard for oneself as others are demanded, and I still think we have some way to go. In addition to this, I would like to thank you for the debate, thank you to the Commission and thank the Court of Auditors for the hard work that underlies our reports. I look forward to tomorrow's vote and hope that we can keep the line from the committee.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – We all agree on the need to increase the transparency and efficiency of the use of EU funds. It would be possible to save a lot of money and to ensure more efficient functioning of the European Parliament if the transition to a single workplace is achieved. I support the provision that a solution must be found on one place of work for the European Parliament. The Court's report, adopted on 11 July 2014, indicated that, if Parliament were to operate in one place, some EUR 114 million could be saved per year. the Union budget. I believe that we need to respond appropriately to such conclusions and to draw up an action plan for the transition to a single seat, as already stated in several previous parliamentary resolutions.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Hearings before the European Parliament for nominees to the EU’s Court of Auditors are consultative. Nominees who receive a negative vote in committee or plenary, can still be appointed if the Council of Ministers so decides. Dr Toni Abela was nominated this year by the Maltese government. He promised that if turned down by the relevant Committee of the Parliament, he’d withdraw. So he did. I applaud Abela for his political integrity. I cannot applaud how his nomination was reviewed. It frequently happens, as with Abela, that occult elements organize campaigns to discredit nominees, alleging dishonourable or criminal behaviour. Nominees can defend themselves during face to face meetings with members of the committee and during the hearing. In Abela’s case, the hearing was short. Allegations against him could not be fully clarified. Other issues too needed discussion. Abela was treated unfairly. If this Parliament wishes hearings on nominations to be meaningful, it should reconsider how to conduct them. When allegations of criminal or dishonourable behaviour arise, they should be considered separately by a jury d’honneur, aided by legal counsel, on the basis of facts. The hearing would then concentrate on the personal, professional and political abilities of the nominee.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Without underestimating the results achieved in the economic and social development of some countries and regions, using the European Development Fund, I draw attention to the fact that some of these countries, beneficiaries of European funding, have not acceded to the tax transparency, anti-money laundering and tax evasion agreements. Therefore, I believe that such countries should be excluded from European funding until they adhere to tax transparency agreements. Otherwise, European money, instead of reaching the people who need it, will end up in tax havens, in the accounts of the cleptocrats and other corrupts.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2014 gives valid reasons and recommendations in favour of granting discharge. It states, inter alia, that, according to the Court of Auditors, the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for 2014 adequately show, in all material respects, its financial position as at 31 December 2014 and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ending at that time, in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The following is the oral question to the Council by Elena Valenciano and Linda McAvan on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Development: Attacks on hospitals and schools — violations of international humanitarian law (O-000063/2016 - B8-0361/2016) (2016/2662(RSP)).

name: Elena Valenciano
text: Author. – Madam President, I would like my first words to serve to pay, on behalf of this House, the sincere tribute to the unpayable courage and dedication of local or international humanitarian personnel working in conflict zones: doctors and doctors, teachers, teachers, workers from international and non-governmental organisations who put at risk everything they have, including their lives, to try to bring some humanity where there is no trace of it.  The Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Committee on Development wanted to bring this debate to this plenary session of the European Parliament because we believe that the international community is not doing enough: it is failing all of them and also the populations they protect.  We are witnessing an increase in attacks on civilian facilities, particularly schools and hospitals, in multiple conflicts, and we are not doing enough to prevent this. I'm not talking about isolated cases; it is a pattern of behavior already being seen in conflicts such as those in Syria or Yemen, where attacks on schools and hospitals are counted by dozens and those killed by hundreds.  The impact of all this affects thousands of innocents who are deprived of all assistance. It's war crimes, because there are rules in war too, and those rules, today, are neither being enforced nor enforced. The problem is getting worse and we have to end this impunity.  Unlike the past, today the victims of armed conflict are mostly civilians. The growing role of non-state actors, for example in Syria or Iraq, further complicates respect for human rights. We need to adapt the system to the new contexts, but above all we have to implement the mechanisms that already exist.  Much of what we have to do is written. What this Parliament wants to know and asks the Council today is what it has done and what the European Union intends to do in the face of this systematic violation of international humanitarian law.  The world needs more than ever a European Union that remains true to its values, and no one will do it on our behalf.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: Author. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the Council for its presence and its commitment to this debate. I would like to add, of course, to the words of my colleague Elena Valenciano, paying tribute to the humanitarian aid workers who around the world expose their lives to save those of others and who, in many cases, are precisely punished for it. Violations of international humanitarian law in multiple conflicts—whether in Syria, or Yemen, or in Area C of Palestine—are becoming a routine succession of criminal acts. These are no longer unexpected and unavoidable side effects, this is a consciously sought-after action. And this is a serious setback in civilization, because the first rules for humanitarian protection in cases of conflict have been put in place 150 years ago. Today we do not lack standards, nor do we have enough, but what is left over are violations and disrespect for these international standards. We are at the highest peak of humanitarian need and armed conflict in the world: 120 million people are displaced, refugees, in need of humanitarian aid. If we grouped them together, they'd be like France and Spain together. Many conflicts in Africa last more than a decade. Syria's war lasts five years. The situation in Palestine lasts four generations in a row. We cannot accept with impunity that this situation continues as such. We have a moral obligation, a legal obligation and a political obligation to call for the cessation of such attacks on hospitals, schools, places of worship, killing civilians, killing children, killing women. The question, as Elena Valenciano has asked, is what has been done so far, what actions are being taken. But, looking ahead, in the face of the World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul, I call on the Member States, as the representative of Parliament to chair the delegation, for a clear commitment to the humanitarian dimension, to respect for international humanitarian law and also to facilitate access to the people in need of this humanitarian aid.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am very pleased to be here tonight. Let me be clear: attacks on hospitals and schools in conflict areas are simply intolerable. The Council – as you do – explicitly condemns such atrocious acts. As you know, promoting compliance with international humanitarian law is a clear commitment by the European Union, including the Council. In this respect the EU guidelines on promoting compliance with international humanitarian law were adopted by the Council in 2005 and reviewed in 2009.  The Union’s support for compliance with international humanitarian law is also reflected in the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for 2015—2019. At the 32nd International Conference of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent Movement, the Union quite rightly reiterated its commitment to advocate strongly and consistently respect for international humanitarian law. In the context of the World Humanitarian Summit’s global consultation, common messages were also agreed. The Council noted in December in the Council conclusions that the World Humanitarian Summit should produce practical outcomes and specific commitments made by all relevant actors, in particular as regards safeguarding humanitarian access and respect for international humanitarian law. We definitely look forward to discussing summit preparations at your next plenary in May. When it comes to specific situations, the Council, for example, in October last year addressed the situation in Syria and called upon all parties – and will continue to call upon all parties – to stop all forms of indiscriminate shelling and bombardment against civilian areas and structures, such as hospitals and schools. Concerning Syria and Iraq, in view of the Third Kuwait Pledging Conference, the EU and its Member States have expressed their concern regarding grave violations of international humanitarian law, including attacks against schools, medical facilities, markets and other civilian areas. Regarding Yemen, the Council, in November 2015, stated that ensuring accountability for humanitarian law violations is an important part of the process to achieve a lasting settlement of the current conflict. It also reiterated its call for the independent investigation of all alleged violations. The monitoring, control and promotion of international humanitarian law is also an essential part of the conclusions on the EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the ISIL/Da’esh threat, adopted by the Council in March 2015. Also on this occasion, the Council called for the protection of medical facilities to be ensured at all times and, on many other occasions, the Council has discussed the situation in Libya, South Sudan, Sudan, Iraq, Nigeria and Ukraine and addressed the specific situation of – yet again – educational and medical facilities. As regards the promotion by the Union of the prevention and repression of such international humanitarian law violations, the Council adopted its CFSP decision in 2011, under which the Union and its Member States must raise the issue of the widest possible participation in the International Criminal Court in negotiations or political dialogues with third states, groups of states or regional organisations as an essential means of promoting respect for international humanitarian law. Finally, violations of international humanitarian law are targeted by many of the restrictive measures imposed by the Union against third states in the context of its external action, for example, Syria, Yemen, Libya, Burundi and other third countries. Without a doubt, the Council shares your deep concern regarding violations of international humanitarian law, including those relating to medical and educational facilities. The Council continuously monitors situations, undertakes action, and will continue to act accordingly. In closing, why is this important? Let me stress that once more that we should never forget what international law is all about. It is about human beings – men, women, children, families – and we cannot, and should not, lose sight of humanity in our foreign policy. Indeed, we have to stay true to our founding values.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Madam Secretary, for your statement on this oral question. Now it is up to the political groups to make their key words.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the resolution that we have negotiated and which we will vote on tomorrow strongly condemns the frequent attacks on schools, hospitals, other civilian structures in conflict situations. They are obviously inadmissible attacks on international humanitarian law and respect for human rights, the principle underlying humanitarian law being precisely that of protection for those who do not take part in a conflict but are caught up in it. The text that various political groups have agreed to is a very balanced text. Unfortunately, the far left is again doing what we are used to doing on other occasions: introducing amendments that have nothing to do with the subject: about Western Sahara, about abortion, about Israel. It is inadmissible to miss the main subject by introducing the same obsessions of the extreme left. I hope that other left-wing groups will not support this destruction of the main subject we have.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as we know, international humanitarian law applies during armed conflicts, where the degree of control over respect for the rule of law and individual rights is inevitably relaxed and attacks on the civilian population have increased significantly in recent years, not sparing the operators of humanitarian aid organisations themselves. As a result, the distinction between military and civilian objectives is eroded, as well as the protection of the special status assigned to structures and personnel given the role of impartial and neutral aid playing between the parties to the conflict. On the contrary, I would say that it is precisely with a view to seeing the enemy in anyone who helps my enemy, the staff of international humanitarian organisations are often seen as targets to be hit.  In recent months there have even been cases of violations by state entities and partners of the European Union: just think of the attacks on doctors without borders hospitals in October in Afghanistan, the greatest suspicions of which fall on the US air force, and in January in Yemen, by the Saudi coalition. It is precisely for this reason that, at the forthcoming summit on international humanitarian law convened in Istanbul, it is necessary and urgent to find concrete action that will activate the international community in the protection of civilians and humanitarian aid workers at risk and those responsible for indiscriminate attacks on the civilian population and aid areas must be identified and answerable before appropriate war crimes tribunals.  That is why we need a coercive mechanism that can investigate the violation of international humanitarian law. We therefore call for action at European level too, for this emergency to be recognised, using all the instruments at its disposal, and we call on the Council and the High Representative for Foreign Policy to commit themselves to the creation, in the wake of the Istanbul Summit, of a permanent place for discussion on these issues.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – My country, Flanders, like many other European nations, has too often experienced the horror of war. One hundred years ago, the Great War raged in the trenches on the Iron and after the war the Iron Tower, a Flemish peace monument with the message "never again war", was erected there. That cry remains an unfulfilled sigh in 2016. War is still there and war is always abomination, for soldiers and for innocent civilians. My parents and grandparents told the stories a hundred. Today, the fast means of communication leave nothing to the imagination. We see the horror immediately on the screen of our television or the PC and we are shocked because civilians are affected because hospitals and schools are not spared. These should be just safe havens, neutral and protected places. Moreover, this is not only happening in Syria, Afghanistan or Yemen, outside Europe. I myself witnessed how in eastern Ukraine, in Europe, schools are militarised and hospitals are deliberately targeted. All too often, international humanitarian law has to give way to raw power politics. All too easily, the loss of life is simply dismissed as collateral damage, which of course it is not. The unique and ambitious EU tools to promote compliance with the basic principles of humanitarian law are well known. It is now up to the European Union and its Member States to show that they are in their right hands. The World Summit on Humanitarian Aid in Istanbul at the end of next month is therefore not a day too soon. This international toolbox and this momentum must be seized on with both hands. Madam Minister, I have another question: can you tell me why the countries that participated in the 32nd International Conference of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent in December 2015 have failed to agree on a new mechanism to strengthen the governance system of international humanitarian law, and how do we avoid the same scenario at the forthcoming world summit?

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the bombing of the hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, a few months ago, has claimed the lives of many people, including doctors without borders staff. The President of the United States strongly deplored this disaster, underscoring the seriousness of the facts. We are all the more shocked that the GPS coordinates of the Hospital in Kunduz were well known to the Us authorities.  Unfortunately, this is not an isolated case, resulting in many victims among patients and health professionals. All the more reason to appeal to the conscience of our leaders at the upcoming World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul, and to be more respectful of international humanitarian law. Every effort must be made to ensure full respect for the impartiality of humanitarian actors who, very often, at the risk of their lives, are willing to devote their time, energy, know-how and generosity to finding solutions to the humanitarian challenge. Our resolution aims to promote preventive and/or deterrent measures in light of the many violations of international humanitarian law. These include a ban on supplying arms to actors involved or who may be involved in operations that flout international humanitarian law. We also add the need to launch independent investigations and bring recognized crimes before the competent courts, including the International Criminal Court. If, in fact, we were able to end impunity in this area, we would be able to strengthen the authority of the United Nations as an institution responsible for managing such conflict situations. Before concluding, I would also like to stress the urgent need for our Member States to finally honour their promises to finance official development aid and humanitarian aid.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, in October last year, my GUE/NGL faction initiated a point in plenary on an attack led by the United States of America on the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan. We all expressed our condolences and concern at this tragic and cowardly event. But what has happened since then? The Americans investigated the whole event internally, and the affair fell silent, as did the destroyed hospital and the voices of the patients and doctors in it. Doctors Without Borders has since been calling for the International Humanitarian Commission of Inquiry to be involved. This mechanism, which is only intended to as much information as possible about the incident, was introduced as early as 1991 by the additional protocols of the Geneva Convention and has never, I repeat, been used in real life. Thus, while there is a tool for concentrating information, the signatories are still afraid to apply it in order not to set a precedent. So can it also mean that we all accept every once in a while that hospitals will be being destroyed? I hope not. If we do not investigate the attacks and clearly point to the culprits, hospitals will continue to be destroyed. As we see it today in Yemen or Syria. For me, the Council's response that it monitors the situation and takes action is not satisfactory. I would like to see a solution, because only deterrence of those who cause it can mean that they will never do it again.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is deplorable that EU Member States are complicit in grave violations of international humanitarian law. Countries receiving weapons from EU Member States are responsible for targeted attacks on civilians, including bombings of hospitals and schools. With the forthcoming resolution we call for effective measures to end this complicity and we ask for support for the Green proposal to impose an EU arms embargo against countries that are responsible for such serious breaches of international humanitarian law. This resolution draws on our previous call for a weapons embargo against Saudi Arabia in reaction to its bombing campaign in Yemen. The EU guidelines on international humanitarian law also provide for other measures, but we – the European Union – do not do enough to implement them. They include the support for information-gathering missions that can be useful for investigations of war crimes and for the International Criminal Court as well. Investigations into violations with a view to prosecute are crucial in order to send a clear message to those responsible and to prevent further killings of civilians. The rising number of attacks on schools and hospitals is a horrific example of growing indifference towards international humanitarian law. It is vital that schools and hospitals remain – and are protected – as a neutral secure space during situations of armed conflict. The upcoming World Humanitarian Summit provides an opportunity to reaffirm the centrality of international humanitarian law and discuss the ways of strengthening compliance with it. Among other topics, challenging improving the situation of women, girls and other vulnerable groups during conflicts should be at the core of these tasks.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, targeting schools and hospitals is strictly forbidden under the rules of international humanitarian law, and bombing such objectives on purpose is universally considered a war crime. Yet the international community has witnessed over the past few years a harrowing trend of attacks such as those on Doctors Without Borders and hospitals in Afghanistan, Yemen and Syria. I want to pay tribute to the admirable courage and dedication of humanitarian aid workers in those countries. We need immediate and effective concrete action in order to tackle these war crimes, so we need first of all to block the flow of weapons towards the belligerents. For this reason, I approve the call to High Representative Mogherini to launch an initiative aimed at imposing an EU arms embargo against countries that are responsible for serious breaches of international humanitarian law. The licensing of weapons sales to such countries represents a breach of the Council Common Position of 8 December 2008. We cannot accept complicit silence.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – I consider the growing attacks on hospitals and schools, but also the growing trend of abuses of hospitals and schools as cover for military activities, to be a key issue in this resolution. In order to reverse this trend, it is important to insist that hospital and school buildings must always have only one mission – to heal and educate. And whoever violates this principle commits a crime against humanity. A balanced text has been reached, under which all political factions are signed. I am therefore disappointed that my GUE colleagues have once again decided to table amendments questioning their political correctness. Their actions are irresponsible and raise the question of whether negotiating with them is not just a waste of time.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her War crimes by state actors, as well as terrorist attacks by non-state actors, are at the heart of the conflicts that have plagued us most in recent years – in Syria, Yemen, Afghanistan, Iraq, and so on. Attacks on hospitals, schools and kindergartens are of particular concern. This is an extremely cynical form of violence, as is attacks on NGOs and all those who provide humanitarian aid. These are war crimes, and they belong before the ICC, that is undisputed. But this finding does relatively little help to those affected in the current situation. That is why our resolution is so important, because we recall that we actually have an important instrument: the 2009 guidelines to promote compliance with the norms of international humanitarian law. We call on the relevant units of the Council to present, to clarify to us what measures have been taken during this period, to make the guidelines relevant and binding. We are aware of the importance of the European institutions and of the role of the Member States. We also draw attention to the important role of the United Nations Security Council in this resolution. Cooperation between the European Union and the UN is of the utmost importance in these conflicts. An essential aspect should not go unmentioned, the European Parliament confirmed it a few weeks ago in its resolution on Yemen, and I believe that we are now rightly taking up this again: we should exclude those states from arms supplies that violate international humanitarian law.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab One of the islamic state's most brutal, shocking terrorist attacks in recent times was the attack in Ana on a nursing home, Mother Teresa's house, where nuns and their wards were deliberately killed, not as accidental but intentionally. We, as a rule, have a very rich agenda for debates on human rights. Unfortunately, this event has completely come out of our sight. We must record every time not only do innocent people fall victim to hostilities, but when innocent people are the target of these hostilities, and in this case we have had to deal with such an event.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, at a time when the Secretary-General of the United Nations has raised alarms about the continued erosion of international humanitarian law, we are at least facing a timely resolution. However, it is very disappointing to see how most of the groups in this house have consciously decided to bypass the military occupations of Palestine and Western Sahara, where, I recall, international humanitarian law also applies. This mission is to pour salt into the wounds and pain of the thousands of civilians living under occupation and is to leave them totally helpless. We must not ignore the recommendations of the 2014 Commissions of Inquiry on the Gaza Strip, which spoke of war crimes over the bombing of hospitals and the indiscriminate and disproportionate use of force. I would like to remind you that the interpretation of the rules of international humanitarian law for political purposes is one of the main factors in its failure to comply and impunity for this partner. That is why I hope that tomorrow you will vote in favour of the amendments that my group has tabled to remedy this situation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, according to a report on doctors for human rights in February 2016 alone, there were 358 attacks on medical facilities in Syria, although over 90% of these attacks were carried out by the Assad regime and their allies.  Doctors, nurses, humanitarian workers working in war zones work around the world and are often forced to act in areas outside their profession due to a lack of qualified personnel. That is why we must honor them for their dedication to help civilians, for the true courage worthy of our admiration.  Attacks on hospitals are a serious violation of international humanitarian law, but it is not enough to try violations of international law, but it is necessary to act and condemn those responsible, but this is not easy. We know this well, those of us who come from countries that were victims of Milošević's aggression and who witnessed that many criminals unfortunately went unpunished.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for What we are seeing today is a different warfare that has put in systems to carry out deadly attacks on civilians, women and children where women and children are located. These are serious war crimes and require absolutely immediate action on the part of the EUROPEAN Union. To condemn alone is in itself a violation of international law.  The EU has adopted guidelines that need to be implemented, and each case must be investigated and those responsible must be brought to justice. If we allow the situation to continue like this, it will only lead and contribute to more attacks.  The Council must consider an arms embargo on countries that violate international law. Those countries that continue to sell arms to such countries are in breach of previously adopted Council conclusions. The use of armed drones in these conflicts is alarming and the EU must develop a common position on this as a step towards global disarmament.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, violations of international humanitarian law such as attacks on hospitals and schools must be condemned without exception and the perpetrators of these crimes brought to justice. Such mindless behaviour shall not be tolerated or relativised for any strategic interest.  Let me remind you of the terrible fate that vukovar hospital went through in the Croatian war of independence. It is estimated that up to 700 missiles a day fell on it during the siege of Vukovar, after the fall of the city, Serbian terrorists in contact with the Yugoslav People's Army took, tortured and shot several hundred wounded and hospital workers from the hospital.  To date, Serbia has not returned the estranged hospital records, nor has it made efforts to find out the fate of the people who lost all trace after being taken from the hospital. Such a Serbia is uncompromisingly supported by many European leaders, but also by members of this house, and croatia is condemned for not allowing itself to be humiliated.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this is not about one attack– Physicians for Human Rights has documented 358 separate attacks on medical facilities in Syria since 2011 alone.
