We have heard from colleagues about the recent attacks which have hit Médecins Sans Frontières’ health centres in Afghanistan and Yemen. The aid worker database says that 610 aid workers internationally lost their lives working for major international organisations in the last year, for those statistics are available. We have to do better. We have to do better as a European Union to strengthen the international legal protection. We have to do better with our Member States in order to avoid any complicity whatsoever in such attacks. And we have to condemn the terrorists and their armed groups that use human shields and deliberately ensure civilians are vulnerable to those attacks. There is something truly tragic that victims of violence go to hospitals as a refuge from war, to heal their bodies, and then find themselves subject to further violence and death. We condemned Isis when they attacked humanitarian workers. If we are better than them, then we have to ensure that we never do so.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am particularly happy for what I have heard from my fellow speaker, Mr Howitt. Indeed, there are many attacks, and I would hate for only the Kabul one to be highlighted. For example, we have not even talked about the Russian ones that have happened in the past year. On February 15, 2016, about 50 people were killed in a Russian airstrike in the Maarat al-Numan area. Thirteen victims at Sarmin on October 21, 2015. I pity every victim, I regret any unauthorized airstrike that truly violates the norms of international law. However, I think, given the resolution tabled by my colleagues in the left faction, that it would be appropriate to have some objective balance, because if this resolution is proposed in a one-sided direction, then of course we are against it, and it would be good for this report to be balanced as it is in the original proposal, not as the proposals made by our GUE/NGL colleagues are amended.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, in recent months, unfortunately, we have repeatedly discussed violations of fundamental human rights in the fields of war, particularly in the Middle East, mainly because of the action of the Daesh jihadists. But last November, the United States confessed to the murderous bombing of a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan.  In Yemen, the Saudi-led Arab coalition has carried out an of violence against civilians, with numerous attacks on hospitals and schools. With the 'double standards' attitude adopted today by the European Union and the West more broadly, their reputation and credibility are at stake. International organisations have a duty to recognise war crimes in Yemen, Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, but also elsewhere, whoever they are. This should be the first step so that the decision-makers take responsibility for their actions, the economic rehabilitation of the affected countries, but also of the people, as well as the safe and unconditional care of the thousands of refugees they have created.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it is as if we have learned too little from what was the consequence and what happened in the wars in the former Yugoslavia. What was happening in Bosnia and Herzegovina, what was happening in Croatia, and of course, I want to underline the fact that it was schools, hospitals, religious buildings more than 20 years ago that were the targets of the attack. The most disgusting thing is what happened to the Vukovar hospital.  However, it's as if we really haven't learned anything. How can we even be surprised that civilians are the ones who are most vulnerable and die in every war, in every war it is always the same story, in every war there are attacks on schools, attacks especially on hospitals. We really can't have this discussion here without making firm decisions and leading such crimes, because these are the most heinous crimes against helpless people, to the fullest.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we agree with the general principles that guide the discussion. However, we cannot fail to note that the real causes of the conflicts in which these criminal actions take land are absolutely ignored.  A discussion that whiteses the direct and indirect role and responsibilities that the European Union, NATO and the United States of America have, in particular, in military aggression stouts in the Middle East and North Africa, as well as the role and responsibilities of Western allies who have themselves been responsible for attacks on hospitals and schools.  What about israel's criminal action, with a record of attacks on UN schools, which arrests and kills children? What about Saudi Arabia's role in the Yemen conflict or the innocent victims of Us drones? A tremendous hypocrisy at a time when the European Union is now an example, throughout the world, of the violation of the most basic human rights with the response to the humanitarian refugee crisis.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is in my view evident that all EU institutions coincide in considering that respect for international humanitarian law, rules and principles is, and must remain, at the core of the Union’s external action. That is why I said earlier this evening that it is crucial to stay true to our founding values. We should never forget what international law is all about: men, women children – families. In reply to Mr Demesmaeker, I would like to say that, like you, I deeply regret that the conference failed in adopting a new mechanism. However, we should not forget that the 28 EU Member States make up only a small portion of states participating in the conference. At the 32nd International Conference of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement you referred to – as I said earlier this evening – the Union reiterated its commitment to advocate strongly and consistently respect for international humanitarian law. One of the pledges made in that conference by the Union and its Member States regarded attacks against medical personnel or patients. The 28 EU Member States have a strong voice if they join forces, but we make up only a small portion of the states participating in the conference.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. I have received 6 motions for resolutions to conclude the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday, April 28, 2016. Declarations in Iras (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. The vast majority of the victims of the latest armed conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Afghanistan are innocent civilians. Attacks on civilian facilities such as hospitals and schools are acts of gross negligence and violations of the basic principles of humanitarian law. It is essential to tackle effectively the problem now known to all of the serious violations of international humanitarian law and international human rights law, by promoting appropriate mechanisms for taking responsibility. I would stress the important role that the International Criminal Court can play in cases where the State or states in question cannot or do not wish to exercise their jurisdiction. Since the beginning of the year alone, there have been 15 attacks on hospitals and medical facilities in Syria alone, while, since the start of the conflict in 2011, Amnesty estimates that 336 medical centers have been attacked. Europe must make its voice and political weight heard loud. It is necessary to draw up a concrete action plan with precise deadlines, impartial and independent investigations to put an end to this barbarity. Hospitals and medical personnel are explicitly protected by international humanitarian law and attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure are a war crime.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the resolution because I strongly condemn attacks on hospitals and schools. Unfortunately, we cannot put an end to war, but we must work to ensure that attacks on patients, their relatives, medical staff, teaching staff and children are not accepted by the world community and should have consequences.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "As a result of the various military operations currently under way, we have seen an increasing number of attacks on hospitals and schools around the world. International humanitarian law mitigates the effects of these actions by protecting those who do not participate.  The 1946 Convention on UN Privileges and Immunities protects schools and healthcare facilities. On the eve of the World Humanitarian Summit, we should strongly condemn the use of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and schools, by parties to armed conflicts. This summit offers an opportunity for all UN Member States to re-enter into commitments to protect and respect human rights in this area, i.e. the principles they have already agreed to.  EU policy in this area should be promoted and implemented in a coherent and effective manner. Eu Member States, using all available tools to effectively comply with international humanitarian law, should set an example in the implementation of the ratified basic instruments of that law. It is necessary to impose an EU embargo on arms deliveries to countries that are responsible for violations of international humanitarian law, in particular deliberate attacks on civilian infrastructure. International investigative and judicial systems should be strengthened in order to end impunity for perpetrators of violations of international humanitarian law.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Attacks on hospitals and schools are a gross violation of the fundamental principles of humanitarian law and extremely despicable. Every change must be made to ensure that such attacks do not take place and that the perpetrators of such acts must be held accountable, if necessary using the International Criminal Court.  The EU can contribute in its relations with third countries to protect and assist innocently suffering people through political dialogue, restrictive measures and cooperation with international institutions. It is important to increase eu humanitarian aid, which currently accounts for only 1% of the total EU budget. In addition, Member States have to comply with the financial commitments already made.  It is also important to reach a conclusion that the UN Security Council will not be able to veto war crimes and humanitarian issues. The Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul, on 23-24 May, must also reach agreements to help resolve the upcoming humanitarian crises more effectively.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The current situation, involving several attacks on schools and hospitals in conflict areas, is unacceptable. The safety of peace zones in time of conflict is jeopardised. The situation of civilians needs to be improved, and the EU cannot stand aside from the reality. International humanitarian law provides for the protection of civilians in countries experiencing armed conflict. The EU has a role to play in ensuring that events of this kind do not happen in the future, and in clarifying the approach to investigating such attacks. The parties responsible must pay for the crimes that have been committed.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – In armed conflict conditions around the world, soft targets, hospitals and schools are the most affected. These cases are gross violations of international humanitarian law. We should ask all parties to respect people's right to health. To ensure the accessibility and quality of health services during conflicts. I think we should also be more aware of the fact that they need to ensure a good schooling. Children, students, students have a right to do so. They're our hope. I, too, wonder what we, as an EU, have done as part of a global village to stop such discarded actions happening.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on laura ferrara's report on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs: Public access to documents for the period 2014-2015 (2015/2287(INI)) - (A8-0141/2016).

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs with whom fruitful meetings and constructive debates have taken place. And then I would also like to thank all the citizens who have contributed with suggestions and proposals, to the drafting of the resolution, the draft of which was published on the online platform of the 5 Star Movement. The result of the work carried out in close synergy in recent months is a good text and I am satisfied because it goes in the direction of ensuring greater transparency and greater and better involvement of citizens in the work carried out in the institutions.  This step forward is all the more important because it comes at a time when public confidence in the European Union is faltering: the buildings of the European institutions are seen as opaque places, where decisions are taken that directly affect them but of which they often know nothing or almost nothing. We must take note of the fact that there is a lot of talk about transparency, but unfortunately words are not always followed by deeds. Suffice it to say that many of the recommendations made in parliament's similar resolutions in previous years have not been followed up. Yet transparency, as well as participatory democracy, are fundamental democratic principles, recognised by the Treaty on European Union.  It is therefore precisely in the wake, traced by the principle of participatory democracy on which the European Union is founded, that the text was drawn up, calling for the establishment of a public telematic register on the work of citizens' representatives, on the decision-making process and on the way in which public money and the results obtained are allocated and spent. It calls for the accessibility of information to be improved, increased and simplified, through the development of a common access point to the portals of the EU institutions, while also providing for access arrangements that take into account the needs of people with disabilities. On the other hand, the transparency of the institutions cannot be separated from adequate protection for whistle-blowers, who must be protected both morally and financially. We therefore call on the Commission to present a proposal to keep whistleblowers as part of the democratic system.  The transparency of the entire legislative process is also of central importance. In this context, the consolidation of the practice of trialogues, of which the citizens know practically nothing, is destroying the necessary public control, which is inherent in the ordinary legislative procedure, favouring the hidden work of lobbyists who can, thanks to the leak of documents, have easier access to the information necessary to influence the decision-making process. Therefore, while acknowledging the importance and effectiveness of informal trialogues, we call for greater transparency of informal trialogues and, consequently, greater control by citizens. With regard to lobbyists, we also call on the Commission to present, without delay, its proposal for an agreement on the establishment of a compulsory interinstitutional register of lobbyists.  We also stress the need to ensure greater transparency in the negotiations for the conclusion of international agreements. The public should have access to as many documents as possible. We also believe that there is a need for greater transparency in the procedures for late payment and infringement of Member States. Then, with regard to the Structural Funds, data on procedures and beneficiaries must be made easily accessible, in order to combat and prevent abuse, fraud and corruption.  As I said at the beginning of my speech, the lack of transparency is one of the main causes of the loss of confidence in the European institutions and it would be a fatal mistake to turn a blind eye, trying to forget the growing abstentionism, the re-founding of nationalist sentiments, the risk of corruption and conflicts of interest.  As one of the founders of the 5 Star Movement, Gian Roberto Casaleggio, said: "It is not correct for someone to decide for citizens on the basis of inscrutable logics and without accountable. The Member is an employee of the citizens: he cannot escape their control. Otherwise, there can be no talk of direct democracy, or perhaps not even of democracy." As a Member of the European Parliament who believes in the values of freedom and democratic participation, I call on you to work together to ensure real public access to information.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, this Commission – as President Juncker committed to this House – has made democratic change and transparency one of its ten political priorities. Our decisions affect millions of European citizens and therefore must be taken as democratically and transparently as possibly. The Commission already applies high transparency standards, but we are always open to examining our tools and practices and to adapting them further where necessary and appropriate.  The Commission welcomes that the resolution calls for Members of the Parliament and the Council to follow the Commission’s practice regarding the publication of information on meetings held by top political leaders and decision makers. At the Commission, information on more than 10 000 such meetings has been published. This transparency standard should become part of the culture of all EU institutions, as far as bilateral encounters with lobbyists, elected politicians and top decision—makers are concerned. The Commission also welcomes Parliament’s clear support for our intention to present a proposal for an inter—institutional agreement on a mandatory transparency register covering the three main institutions. To this effect, the Commission launched a public consultation on 1 March 2016, with a view to submitting a proposal in the second half of this year.  The Commission is convinced that across the three EU institutions involved in law—making, the same standards of transparency should be applied. The Commission also strongly welcomes the new inter-institutional agreement on better law—making. In that agreement, the Commission together with the other two institutions committed itself to further improving transparency in legislative procedures, and to setting up practical arrangements for cooperation in future international negotiations. Similarly, the creation of a joint the register of delegated acts by the end of 2017 will further increase the transparency of acts impacting on citizens and businesses.  The Commission calls on the co—legislators to adopt its proposals on access to documents aimed at extending the right of access to documents to all EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. The Commission has consistently supported, and will continue supporting, the co-legislators in finding common ground on the two pending proposals updating and upgrading Regulation 1049/2001. As regards the proactive publication of documents, I would like to recall that the Commission has established a solid practice of document registration and publication in its document register. It actively supports the pilot project introduced by Parliament, which is aimed at providing easier access to a wide range of unclassified documents held by EU institutions. The overall success of the project depends on building consistency between the institutions’ document management systems, including the need to avoid duplication of existing tools.  The Commission also makes constant efforts to comply with its publication requirements as defined in the sectorial legal bases. We take the view that the current rules and practices strike the right balance between transparency and the protection of personal data. As regards the suggestion to establish the post of Transparency Commissioner, I can assure you that First Vice—President Timmermans, who regrets he is unable to be here in person, is the Commissioner who ensures compliance and improves administrative practices in the field of access to documents. I can also confirm that transparency is seen as an issue off paramount importance by the Commission as a whole.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, public access to documents is essential to enhance people’s trust in our work and to bridge the gap between citizens and the EU institutions. At a time where populists claim that Eurocrats decide from Brussels over people’s lives, undermining the legitimacy of the EU, the EPP’s message is very clear: we have nothing to hide. We are committed to transparency, openness and accountability. We should open the doors of the European institutions to show that decisions are taken democratically. The European Parliament is at the forefront, but more needs to be done, especially in the Council. I call on the Presidency to relaunch the negotiations on the regulation on public access to documents. Citizens have the right to know what their representatives do on their behalf and how EU funds are spent in a fast, simple and user-friendly way. For instance, a common search and access point between the three institutions, like we have with the Your Europe portal, could make it easier for the public to find information. The people of Europe should be able to be involved in, participate in and influence EU decisions. This does not mean direct democracy. In Europe, we live in representative democracies and, of course, openness goes with responsibility. Public access is not about Wikileaks and it is not about whistle—blowers. Privacy has to be respected, while ensuring transparency. And yes, Laura, the trilogues and international agreements must be more transparent, but we need to ensure a climate of mutual trust and the space to think. This is necessary to achieve results in negotiations. Personally, I committed to be open about my work. Reconnecting with people and gaining their trust in Europe is more important than ever, as we are confronted with common challenges that require a common European response.

name: Anna Hedh
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Access to documents is a fundamental right protected both by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and by the Treaties.  The report we are debating today states precisely that a prerequisite for a democratic political system is that citizens have the opportunity to know and examine how decisions are taken.  I am also the rapporteur for the legislative report itself on the regulation on access to documents, the so-called transparency regulation, where, unfortunately, there is blockage at the moment. In view of this blockage, I think it is particularly important that we clearly demand in the Ferrara report that all the European institutions and authorities apply the regulation and fair practices in force in full and respect the amendments made by the Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  A good proposal in the Ferrara report is that the EU institutions should facilitate the exercise of the right to access documents and promote good administrative practices. This should be done through a uniform set of principles for access to documents, which should provide greater clarity for citizens. In addition, the report also comes with the proposal to create an administrative law for the EU.  One issue that was discussed a lot in committee concerns rules for trilogues. They are important and effective from a legislative point of view, but they can raise questions about the transparency of the legislative procedure. The S&D Group believes that greater transparency in trilogues is important in order to strengthen democracy, but it is also important that the co-legislators be given sufficient space for reflection.  That is why we support the proposal to extend the reporting back to the responsible parliamentary committees on the state of play of the trialogue negotiations. Documents drawn up in the framework of trilogues, such as agendas, summaries, minutes and general positions in the Council should be made public to the extent that they exist.  The S&D Group will vote in favour of this report as a whole as a clear signal that we in Parliament are doing what we can to increase transparency in Europe.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Mr President, the right of access to information and access to documents is a fundamental right in a democracy. Without this right there is no democracy, there is dictatorship. People have the right to be informed and they need to be informed about how their money is spent, what is happening in the administration, in the legislature, what decisions we make in the European Parliament or in the European institutions, what policies we promote on their behalf. It means legitimacy for us and responsibility for us, for a democratic political system. Transparency and access to information also fill the gap in trust that exists today between European citizens and the European institutions. Yes, there are a lot of European citizens who no longer trust the European institutions, and let us give them information and try to fill this gap. There were colleagues who told me: but why put so much information on Parliament's website that people don't need? And the answer is: let's put them in and choose what information they need, not us decide what they need or don't need!

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on a job well done. I was her predecessor and I recognise much of the work we did two years ago.  A lot has been said about trust. The trust of citizens is at an all—time low and we need to get it back. At the same time, in this debate I often get the feeling that we do not trust the citizens because we are afraid to show the work that we are actually doing. I notice that, despite all the nice words, in all three institutions there is still not a culture of openness and transparency. There is a culture of secrecy and trying to disclose as little as possible. I know what I am talking about because I have carried out so many procedures trying to get access to documents and this even brought me to the Luxembourg Court twice. We should also realise that transparency is the rule. It is not a fancy liberal choice, but it is the law and we seem to forget that. Sometimes we say that we do not need to disclose this or that because we do not like it, it is awkward or we want space to think, but transparency is a legal obligation. If we do not want transparency, secrecy has to be justified specifically. I refer to the resolution that we adopted two years ago that I had the honour of drafting. I note that the follow up to that resolution has been wafer thin. I am actually quite surprised to see that, when it comes to transparency in trialogues, we are actually taking a step back compared to the text that we adopted in 2014. So we were more inclined towards transparency in 2014 than we are in 2016 when the trust of citizens is so low.  Finally, I think there are three things that we should do which were in the previous resolution: appoint a transparency officer in all institutions, including in the Parliament, and the Presidency of this House has so far refused to do so; secondly draft an action plan; and, thirdly, we need rules for the classification of documents and a lighter procedure for challenging classification so that we do not need the Court.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, an example so that we can assess the degree of transparency in the European Union: here I show you the statement they make us sign so that we can enter the secret room where the ATCI documents are locked. They remind us in this statement of the need to comply with the rules for the consultation of classified information: one, to ensure the security of classified documents; two, under no circumstances, by action or omission, allow the information given to be known to unauthorized persons; three, do not reproduce the classified documents or the information they contain. And they remind us when we sign this statement that if we do not comply with these rules, there will be disciplinary action or even legal action. That is, they teach us some documents in exchange for us swearing silence; silence in the face of an unprecedented attack on our democracy and our rights being negotiated between the European Union and the United States; silence as multinationals draft an agreement tailored to their interests. You impose silence. We demand a referendum for the people to speak.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the report is a great opportunity to bring the European institutions closer to citizenship. Transparency must be a major issue at European level. The Verts/ALE Group considers that it would be appropriate to have a Commissioner responsible for transparency and public access to documents.  And I point out only three important elements of the report: first, the single access point to the portals of the European institutions; second, the importance of making public as many documents as possible over the Internet, as well as documents of international agreements with third countries in commercial or other matters; third, the compulsory registration of interest groups, which will identify pressure groups with an influence on the development of European standards.  The report also urges the Commission to make Europe a comprehensive reference in terms of transparency.  Ringrazio qui la collega Ferrara per il suo buon lavoro.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Thank you, Richard; always good to see you in the chair. The European Union talks a great deal about democracy and transparency, and so its dealings should be open to the scrutiny of the European citizens that it claims to represent.  One issue that concerns many people is TTIP – the proposed Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership trade treaty between the USA and the EU. TTIP is being negotiated in secret. MEPs have no say in those negotiations; we cannot influence their outcome. So far I have had over 20 000 e—mails from constituents concerned about TTIP, which will open up our public services and the National Health Service to US corporations. Of particular concern is the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism that would allow private companies to sue governments in tribunals should those governments try to protect their national interests. Last week, President Obama came to London, where he threatened the British public against voting to leave the European Union in the referendum on 23 June. How low has Britain sunk when a foreign leader can come to threaten us in our own capital while our prime minister looks on approvingly? It makes one want to vomit. Obama said that we should vote not to leave the EU or there will be no trade deal with the USA anytime soon, and indeed that we would have to wait at the end of the queue. He overlooked the fact that the UK is a major trading partner of the USA and yet we have no trade deal. He overlooked the fact that the USA is one of the top ten trading partners with the EU, and yet it has no trade deal with the EU. When Britain leaves the EU, precisely nothing will change regarding our trading arrangements with the USA. Obama wants Britain to remain in the EU because he wants TTIP forced through on all of us. The British people should stop deluding themselves. We do not have a special relationship with the USA; we have a servile relationship. The American political establishment is not our friend; it only cares about big business and the interests of international finance. It is in the best interests of the British people to vote to leave the European Union on 23 June and to implement that decision as quickly as possible.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to Mr Ferrara for his work. Access to documents is an essential aspect of the transparency of the European institutions, as well as a right guaranteed by the Treaties. Unfortunately, citizens often encounter difficulties in accessing documents relating to the Union's legislative process and in being able to understand certain aspects of its administrative activity, not only because of the persistent lack of a coordinated interinstitutional approach in this area.  I believe that the motion for a resolution we are debating today, reiterating the need for greater transparency in the activities of the institutions and promoting a model of consistency of the principles governing access to documents, is a step in the right direction. At a time of crisis of legitimacy that Europe is going through, I believe that guaranteeing the right to know and control the activities of its institutions is a necessary measure to increase citizens' confidence and to ensure greater room for democratic participation.  That is why all the European institutions must move in this direction.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur, Mr Ferrara, for his good work. Transparency is important when we deal with joint decisions and common resources. But that alone is not enough. Public information must also be easy to find. A citizen, journalist or, for example, a representative of an NGO seeking information about the EU will not benefit from transparency if documents are buried behind difficult search systems. There is certainly room for improvement in all EU institutions here. Fortunately, this concern has also been taken into account in the Ferrara report, which calls, among other things, for better user interfaces for finding documents. Of course, there are limits to transparency. When negotiating international agreements such as the TTIP partnership, not all information can be public all the time. This would put the European Union at a disadvantage. However, these are exceptional cases. Transparency is the starting point for everything. It is one of the most important means of increasing public confidence in the EU and, as everyone knows, this is a confidence that we really need.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the apparent reason for this debate in plenary is the annual report on access to documents in 2014 and 2015. And contributions have been made which must be greeted and acknowledged by the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, especially in relation to the transparency of the legislative procedure and tripartite dialogues, in which the relevant amendments and documents must be transparent and, moreover, attempts should be made to transmit the relevant discussions of the legislative procedure by webstream. But I insist that this is only the apparent reason, because a protest has been revealed here, in the face of the danger of some European institutions practicing what we say in Spain is 'tell me what you presume and I will tell you what you lack'. Because transparency cannot be allowed to be proclaimed stronger than ever, under the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and ignored in practice by some institutions. I would therefore like to remind you that it is essential that the Commission and Council unlock at once the updating of the general rules on transparency and access to documents, which is long blocked throughout the last parliamentary term and still an unresolved issue today.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the process of European integration and institution-building has always been based on the ideals of participatory democracy and transparency – at least in principle. It is therefore most unbecoming for a number of EU institutions, including Parliament, that maximum public access for all unclassified documents, even nowadays, is not fully guaranteed. In the light of this, I support the idea of incorporating the European Council, the European Central Bank, the Court of Justice, and all other EU bodies and agencies within the scope of the regulation being discussed. Transparency for documentation related to delegated texts and negotiations on international agreements is of particular importance. The most basic reasoning for such change is quite simple. Those who, through their taxes, supply the bulk of the EU’s budget deserve to know what is actually happening behind the walls of each institution. Moreover, a higher level of transparency would directly and positively affect public interest in the Union itself.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, generating added value in the administrative and legislative procedures of the individual Member States and the European institutions passes, not only through proper political activity, but also, and above all, through the implementation of democratic sharing processes. Greater awareness ennobles both the legislative process and the related administrative procedure and reinvigorates the principle of full access to documents.  The latter, while protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, strenuously defended by the constant jurisprudence of the Court of Justice and the national courts, is a fundamental right put to the test by the lack of harmonised rules on aspects of access, privacy, correct and timely information for citizens, the classification of confidential documents, principles which are, moreover, only apparently antagonistic.  In fact, their definition is constantly changing, also thanks to the speed of the media and data transmission and escape classification by preventing the formation of a single code. There is also an urgent need for trialogue proceedings, for amendments in this House, for contact with lobbies and delegated acts which, if not fully shared and accessible, obfuscat the principle of representative democracy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, 'again in the same play spectators'! We are talking about transparency, public access to documents, when we, as MEPs, can access TTIP documents subject to signature for the examination of documents of a high degree of confidentiality. In a room where we are not allowed to take notes or photocopy documents when we are not allowed to make public the contents of TTIP documents, all this when senators in the United States do not have these restrictions, when their aides also have access to TTIP documents, when, in addition, 700 experts working for the U.S. Senate also have access to TTIP documents. , an agreement that President Obama is calling for to be voted on. A convention negotiated by the apotheosis of secret diplomacy.  What transparency are you talking about, Mrs Jourová? What democracy is the European Union talking about, when troikas and memoranda violate national constitutions, European treaties and overturn referendums without regard for popular sovereignty? The European Parliament, as the only body directly elected by the citizens, has a duty to take the lead in the democratic struggle for transparency and control of institutions.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me first of all say a word of greeting and thanks to the work of the rapporteur, our colleague Laura Ferrara.  Transparency in the functioning of the Institutions of the European Union is fundamental to its credibility vis-in to the citizens we all represent here. This transparency implies easy access to documents and information as a means of strengthening participatory democracy. The opacity and difficulties created in the implementation of political and administrative transparency are sworn enemies of democracy and the vitality of public institutions. It is imperative to facilitate access to TTIP-related documents, as well as access to documents, documents, trilogues. Those who should not, do not fear, are said in my country, that is, those who do what they should do not need to hide or hide their work.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I am not a deputy, I am an MP, but thank you for trying to always be so present and nice to the Members.  What I want to emphasize is certainly the support I want to give Mrs Ferrari on this report because it really is her goal to bring European institutions closer to the citizens. Bringing european institutions and everything we do closer, our work here in Parliament, but also in other institutions of the European Union and this is really the best and only possible right way to regain the trust of our fellow citizens because, let's put our hand on our hearts, today the idea of Europe still has serious problems, and one of the reasons is our bureaucratic system.  What I want to propose in the end is: let's remove from our vocabulary the word transparency, put in our dictionary the word openness. That's the right term to me. The openness of our institutions to citizens and the ability to get all that information they need.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, citizens' access to the documents available to the European institutions is fundamental. Confidentiality of documents should be the exception, not the rule. This is apparent both from the provisions of the relevant regulation and from the restrictive interpretation given by the Court of Justice of the European Union to the exceptions provided for in it. However, we too often see the phenomenon of the European institutions denying citizens access to their documents, circumventing the principle of free access.  A typical example is the transatlantic TTIR agreement, as little information has come to light because of the confidentiality of the documents concerned. European institutions must move directly towards a common policy of open access to documents in order to strengthen participatory democracy, transparency and accountability towards citizens.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Rapporteur, thank you for a very good report. I understand that you had to be diplomatic in drafting it, so you have only gently criticised the Commission and the Council. But maybe you were too small.  Personally, I believe that the European Parliament is doing a great deal of work in the area of transparency. I am not saying that there is no room for improvement, but I fully agree with the criticism for the lack of transparency that DiEM 25 primarily addresses to the Council and the Commission. After all, many times EVEN MEPs do not have an easy time accessing certain materials. Take, for example, the documents mentioned several times today on the TTIP treaty. Now we have another battle ahead of us. We will be asking the Commission for documents for the EMIS Committee of Inquiry, and I hope that the Commission will cooperate willingly, but I cannot hide my concerns. I would certainly like to join the request for the Commission to present without further delay its proposal for a central mandatory register of lobbyists applicable to all the institutions and bodies of the European Union. For example, lobbyists were more present in TTIP negotiations than non-profit organizations.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – (2) Mr President, the principle of transparency, which should guide public access to the documents of the European institutions, is another one of those principles which only seek to embellish the regulatory building of the European Union. This shows the systematic secrecy in which free trade agreements such as TTIP, CETA, TISA are concluded, without being able to access the contents of the progress of the negotiating processes. This is why it is perceived that access to documentation to scandals such as Luxleaks has been systematically limited to the public like members of this Parliament. This is clear from the assumption that structures such as the ECB, which, it is worth remembering, are not elected, position themselves above any democratic scrutiny or control, refusing to provide documentation and provide clarification on matters relating to banking supervision, even to Members of this Parliament, as happened this week in Portugal. Practice shows that transparency is not that a well opaque frosted glass is that it concerns the essential issues.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for all your comments and your support for transparency which we fully share. It is not by chance that our two institutions are organising a joint event on transparency on 2 May, which will contribute to the public consultation for setting the transparency register and reach out to interested parties in Brussels and beyond. As I explained, the revision of Regulation 1049/2001 is pending before the co-legislators and the Commission stands ready to help Council and Parliament find common ground. Irrespective of this process, the current handling of requests under this regulation is fully compatible with Articles 41 and 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. At the same time, the Commission is bound to observe the case law of the EU courts with regard to documents relating to infringement investigations against Member States.  The Commission looks forward to working with the European Parliament, the Council, the Ombudsman, the European Data Protection Supervisor, civil society organisations and all concerned stakeholders on shaping the future transparency regime. The Commission considers that in the areas where the EU is responsible for administration, the latter is governed by an extensive framework of rules, principles and practices. In that spirit, the Commission remains to be convinced about the opportunity of specific legislation providing for a horizontal framework of an EU administrative law at this stage.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commission, thank my fellow Members who have spoken for their support and thank the shadow rapporteurs once again. Transparency has as the ultimate objective to be achieved and at the same time as a means of bridging the gap between citizens and the European institutions, of involving citizens more, in accordance with the principle of participatory democracy, and in increasing the confidence that – I repeat – seems to be faltering towards the European Union today.  I was sorry to hear, sometimes in some discussions with colleagues, that citizens are not interested in certain types of documents or that they do not understand them. Well, it is also possible that certain information is not understood or that it is of little interest. In fact, by interfacing with the citizens, many things are not understood because of the technical terminology or the vastness of information and therefore the difficulty in orienting one's way between everything that is made available.  So the challenge facing the European Parliament, but also for the Commission and the Council, is precisely the increased involvement, making information more accessible to citizens, guaranteeing the right to information, leaving it to the citizens to decide what might arouse their interest and what is not to their attention. Making information accessible and more accessible: the difficulties still arise in finding their way around the different sites of the three European institutions, so the appeal once again is to create a single point of access in such a way as to facilitate the right to information.  International negotiations, such as TTIP, are also key points. What is most disrespectful to the citizens, even before the content, is the secrecy of these negotiations, the influence of lobbyists and the negotiations between the European institutions, the so-called trialogues, which still have darkness. I hope that, on the basis of this report by the European Parliament and also taking advantage of the reports presented in previous years, we will increasingly move in the direction of ensuring greater transparency.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 April 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Access to documents is a necessity for transparency and democratic accountability. The recent rise of Euroscepticism means we need to strengthen our citizens’ trust in the European administration now more than ever. Furthermore, transparency acts as a deterrent to corruption and other questionable behaviour. While the ‘revolving door’ remains a problem, only current members of the administration are within our remit. Yet it would still be a move forward if officials had to declare their meetings with people who now serve the private sector but remain in orbit around the institutions. An example of this would be Siim Kallas. Although, as a former Commissioner, Kallas has a duty to refrain from lobbying the Commission and/or its departments on behalf of Nortal, he has, in his position as Commissioner Dombrovskis’ special advisor, unfettered access to the Commission while being on the payroll of a software company on whose behalf he theoretically cannot lobby. We need even tougher transparency rules to prevent this kind of behaviour, which clearly erodes public confidence and trust in the EU. It is regrettable that current transparency rules are not fully complied with and that the Commission is not making progress towards adopting an instrument which would allow for more transparency.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on: - the oral question to the Council by Pavl Voboda, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Isation, and Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the cross-border protection of the best interests of the child in Europe (000027/2016 - B8-0359/2016) (2016/2665(RSP)). - the oral question to the Commission by Pavl Svoboda, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Rights, and Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions on the cross-border protection of the best interests of the child in Europe (000028/2016 - B8-0360/2016) (2016/2665(RSP)).

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: author. – Mr President, the Brussels IIa Regulation has undoubtedly been a successful Union instrument that has benefited EU citizens through the creation of a wide—ranging scheme of jurisdictional recognition and enforcement rules in matrimonial and parental responsibility cases. That being said, we are all aware of its shortcomings when it comes to child abduction cases. In this respect it appears that the regulation has been overtaken by events – that is to say, the growing number of transnational family dissolution proceedings, which has been aggravated by the increasing divergences between the legal rules applicable to family dissolutions. On top of this, family law, which is a competence of the Member States, has been fragmented into different types of family models: marriage; registered partnership; simple cohabitation. As a result, it appears that society has moved on, and that the regulation has been left behind. Members of the European Parliament are confronted with the shortcomings of Brussels IIa on a regular basis, not only in the Committee on Petitions, but also in correspondence and contacts with citizens who are at the end of their tether. We are all aware that the law is a blunt instrument when it comes to family questions, that judges and lawyers are not necessarily the persons best equipped to deal with such questions and that the courts are not necessarily the best or most cost—effective forum. We need to reflect on this and try to identify ways to help our citizens in these painful moments of their lives, while safeguarding and promoting the best interests of the child. The continuing success of the regulation will depend on its successful and targeted revision. Now that the main areas of complexity and malfunction have been identified, it is a high time that appropriate action is taken to tackle the last remaining insufficiencies.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues, both in my committee, the Committee on Petitions, and in the Committee on Legal Affairs, for their cooperation on this issue. It is our aim in my committee to improve our cooperation with the legislative committees to ensure that the citizens’ concerns and experiences are better taken into consideration in the legislative process. In addition to the testimonies of the direct experiences and problems related to EU law, the petitions that we receive also have an important role in helping to identify problems with the national implementation of EU law in the Member States. This is important when we discuss how best to protect the best interest of children across borders in Europe. In connection with the upcoming review of the Brussels IIA Regulation and also in light of the increasing number of petitions addressed to Parliament, I am happy that this debate is taking place here tonight. It is an issue of great importance because our committee has received a large number of petitions related to children’s welfare issues and their treatment by either judicial or administrative bodies in the Member States. This is definitely a testimony for more cooperation in family matters with trans—border aspects. There is not only an urgent need to review the legal instruments, but also to try to find a way to avoid the harmful situations described in the petitions that we have received.  We have ensured freedom of movement, but it is also our duty to take into deep consideration the consequences that citizens from different nationalities meet and decide to build a family, but as we know, couples can face problems and finally separate. That is why we must make all possible efforts to put instruments in place to handle the situation in the best way possible and, above all, with the best interests of the child as the paramount objective in all decisions. These two oral questions tonight have been raised in order to draw attention to the concrete problems that citizens are facing. Finally, on a more personal note, I am happy to see that my dear colleague, Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert, is here representing the Council tonight. I am sure that you will provide us, as always, with clear and fruitful answers to the question raised, and the same goes, of course, for Commissioner Věra Jourová. Thank you very much for your deep consideration on these important matters.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, honourable Members, many thanks to Cecilia Wikström for the very kind words. I would like to recall the importance the Presidency attaches to the work on civil law, in particular on family matters and e-Justice solutions, and I take this opportunity to thank the Chairs of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Petitions, Svoboda Pavel, and of course my former colleague Cecilia Wikström. I thank them for coming with these questions and ideas to complement the EU message already in place to protect the best interests of the child in cross-border situations. On adoption: as you know the issue of adoption of children is a matter which is not regulated at EU level but by national laws and by some international conventions, particularly the Hague Convention of 1993, to which all EU Member States are parties. This Convention aims at protecting adopted children in their countries, if possible by offering them a home in those countries. It provides for cooperation between the authorities of the different States. The Council may adopt measures concerning family law with cross-border implications following Article 81.3 of the Treaty, including in the field of adoption – but only on the basis of a proposal from the Commission. On welfare and child poverty: concerning the issue of the welfare of children, I would like to say a few words on the fight against poverty, which is a complex reality affecting many children unfortunately. The fight against poverty is one of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and it is also one of the Presidency’s priorities. Working closely with the Social Protection Committee, the Presidency has therefore tabled Council Conclusions on an integrated approach for combating poverty and social inclusion. In this document, which is to be adopted in June, the Council encourages Member States to address child poverty and promote children’s wellbeing through integrated strategies in accordance with the Commission recommendation ‘Investing in children’. The Council also invites Member States to intensify the exchange of knowledge, experiences and best practices in this field. Let me mention in particular the Roma children because, yes, we must also continue to address other longstanding challenges in addition to the situation faced by Roma children, and I thank the European Parliament for keeping this issue on the EU agenda, including on International Roma Day earlier this month, on 8 April to be precise. As regards mediation, the EU has put in place the 2008 Mediation Directive, which aims at facilitating access to alternative dispute resolution. It promotes the amicable settlement of disputes by encouraging the use of mediation and by ensuring a balanced relationship between mediation and judicial proceedings. Moreover, the Brussels IIa Regulation foresees mediation as one of the functions of cooperation between central authorities in matters of parental responsibility. There is common understanding in Council that the revision of Brussels IIa is a topic of great importance and, to be honest, it is about time. On e-Justice, on improving access to information in the justice field: you know that the e-Justice Portal was launched in 2010 in collaboration with the Commission and the Member States. The Council’s Second Action Plan on e-Justice stresses that information relating to minors should be included in the e-Justice Portal. A specific expert group is now examining the ways to expand information on minors already available on the Portal, and your specific question relating to adoption procedures could indeed be considered in this context. In closing, I wish to say that the Council awaits with great interest the Commission proposal amending the Brussels IIa Regulation, as this is the cornerstone of EU judicial cooperation in matrimonial matters and matters of parental responsibility.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) and the Committee on Petitions (PETI) for organising this debate which I very much welcome. As has been said several times already, the Brussels IIa Regulation is an extremely important piece of legislation for many families in Europe. It has been applied for ten years and has proved to be very useful, but the time has come to review it. The Commission intends to come forward with a proposal late June this year. Our assessment is that the Brussels IIa Regulation works overall well with regard to matrimonial matters. We do not envisage, at this stage, the need to revise it in this respect. On the other hand, there is clear evidence for the urgent need to revise the regulation as regards parental responsibility aspects. Parliament, better than anyone, is aware of numerous cross-border cases in which the judicial cooperation based on this regulation is not fast enough, to say the least. Children end up being hostage of lengthy legal disputes. The mechanisms put in place by the Brussels IIa Regulation have helped in determining parental responsibility or settling child abduction cases, but we have to take additional steps.  I intend to further clarify the rules on parental responsibility, to improve the enforcement of judicial decisions, to speed up the procedures and make sure that the best interests of the child are of primary consideration and effectively protected. More concretely we are considering measures on the following aspects. Firstly, to speed up the return procedure. There are still far too many child abduction cases in which parents with an enforceable return order are stuck in lengthy proceedings. Abducted children must be returned swiftly as passing of time can have irreversible consequences for the relationship with their parents. Evidence shows that in those Member States with specialised courts the return procedure can be much smoother and quicker. Secondly, to see whether the existing exequatur procedure is still needed and to define the grounds for refusal of the enforcement of judgements. It is unacceptable that currently a parent can be left without any possibility to see his or her child for years due to delays in the enforcement of judgments. Thirdly, to increase judicial cooperation and mutual trust between Member States, for example when it comes to the specificity of family proceedings.  Fourthly, to smoothen the differences in national rules governing the hearing of the child. Too often these rules are invoked to refuse a judgement from another Member State. I am convinced that while acknowledging different legal traditions we can – and must – do better to respect the child’s right to be heard. Finally, to improve the cooperation between national authorities with responsibility for child protection or parental responsibility matters. We need a strong network of these authorities to help parents in enforcing their parental rights abroad.  Besides these key changes to the Brussels IIa Regulation, we will also continue our awareness raising activities, targeting also child welfare and consular authorities. This is duly reflected in our funding priorities and calls for proposals.  To conclude, let me refer to the aspects related to adoptions. The Brussels IIa Regulation does not cover these aspects. The functioning of child protection and welfare services is governed by national law. The Commission has thoroughly examined the numerous petitions concerning adoptions without parental consent that you have recently received. None of them fall into the remit of EU law. However, the Commission is contributing to the elaboration of a common understanding of how the rights of the child can best be protected and promoted. For instance, let me point to the Ten Principles on integrated child protection systems, which were debated in the last European Forum on the Rights of the Child and which are also mentioned in your draft resolution.  We will continue to support Member States in implementing a child rights—based approach and I know that you also, through dialogue and awareness raising, can have a real impact on improving the situation on this very important matter. I am looking forward to our close cooperation on these files, in the best interest of children and for the benefit of families in Europe.
