name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is important that the Brussels II regulation, which dates back to 2003, is finally revised, especially because it is aimed at the relationship between two states, and that is often not enough. Cross-border cases cannot be limited to just two states, but can often include several states. This creates many legal problems. I have, for example, a case where a Hungarian woman who worked in Belgium has separated from a Frenchman and the custody dispute is now being fought in Belgium, even though no one lives in Belgium any more. There are many such cases involving more than two states. And the revision of the regulation must take this into account in particular. In the case of legal ambiguity and a long duration of proceedings, it is usually the children who suffer from it. I know from experience that in most procedures the best interests of the child are neglected. A very important demand, therefore, is that the regulation strengthens children's rights in such a way that children can also be interviewed separately from their parents and that the length of the proceedings is as short as possible. Every child has a right to the legislator drafting clear, clear laws that can then also clearly ensure what the future of a child means. In this context, this is usually very decisive for the further course of life.

name: Rikke Karlsson
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! People come together in Europe, and when people come together, they often fall in love, they often have children, and it's all beautiful and lovely. But it is also a fact that in many cases happiness does not last forever. You decide to leave each other again and share the children, and during this process, the machinery often creates a little more crunch. Furthermore, if parents come from different countries, the solutions to the problems are often much more complex. Unfortunately, in the Committee on Citizens' Complaints, we all too often see cases where the courts of each Member State disagree on the assessment of these cases, and there is some evidence that the courts of each Member State often represent the interests of their own citizens. Here, the children are taken hostage in an apparent tug-of-war between the different interests of two countries. This proposal is not about forcing countries into anything. It is an attempt to make proper agreements between countries to ensure that the children of parents of different nationalities receive fair treatment, and that must be in everyone's interest.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – This debate warns of the concrete problems faced by eu citizens on children's rights, involving jurisdiction in two or more Member States. Increased mobility within the Union inevitably leads to an increase in cross-border disputes involving children. It is therefore urgent to step up judicial cooperation between Member States in training and exchange of good practice between social services and courts in cross-border cases of adoption, child abductions and, in general, parental regulation. Given the particular sensitivity and social alarm of such cases, Union authorities should encourage Member States to set up specialised courts with exclusive jurisdiction over such situations. This is an area where there can be no hesitation or tergiversções, because what is at stake is the best interests of the child. The issue is not to impose a single vision to deal with family conflicts and the well-being of children, but to transform the territory of the Union into an area of free movement of persons and not only of goods, services and capital.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, there is something rotten about the kingdom of Denmark, around the protection of children. Complaints to the Committee on Petitions about the protection of children's interests, in the United Kingdom, Denmark, Germany, look like a storm, whether they concern the social services of minors, adoptions or foster care of children, care and visitation rights to parents who have even been accused of sexual abuse, and are complaints that shock us.  Many reports touch on the family crisis in the North, and we are unable to answer what happened to the 10,000 unaccompanied child refugees who were subsequently lost, as Europol complains. I ask you to commit ourselves to full support for children's rights, with decisions that concern not only the family crisis, but also the humanitarian crisis plaguing the South and the refugee crisis. And that's not politics, it's our moral obligation.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, I would like to thank Minister Hennis-Plasschaert, a former colleague, and Commissioner Jourová for their statements. I hope the Council and Commission will take on board our resolution, which was prepared just from studying the desperate calls for help addressed to our Committee on Petitions.  It is evident that, following the significant level of movement of workers between Member States and the increasing number of mixed couples, the number of cross—border child protection issues involving custody removal is growing as well. I will give only one number, showing how real this problem is for my country, Latvia. During only the first two months of this year, eleven children were removed from the families of Latvian citizens working in Britain and placed in British care families. Cross-border mechanisms are to be put in place when it involves determining the custody of children. We need to input the receiving state’s duty to inform the consular authorities of the state of which the child is a national. A clear, urgent, detailed and developed definition of the term ‘habitual residence of the child’ in the revised Brussels IIa regulation is needed.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Honourable Member, you have mentioned the case that your citizens have had their children taken from a Member State, and that is Great Britain. But your citizens are increasingly being taken from children in a non-EU country, and that is Norway. Do you think that the European Union adequately defends the interests of the citizens and children of the European Union, which are taken outside the Member States of the European Union?

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Also, Norway is not an EU Member State. We as the Committee of Petitions were hearing these cases in Nordic councils just last week. They are also giving a lot of attention to this – alongside the Swedish, Finnish and Danish cases, also the Norwegian situation. But the United Kingdom is only one state where adoption without consent is working, and that is the biggest problem now for EU Member States.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to improve judicial cooperation between Member States in cross-border cases involving children. We must ensure that judgments are recognised and respected between the different Member States and monitored over time to guarantee, for example, the rights of parents to visit and that minimum standards for the hearing of children in national civil proceedings and the training of legal and social workers are respected or even introduced.  I cannot help mentioning, among the dozens of petitions received, those concerning and reporting cases of abuse by the German Jugendamt. In a very recent case there is even talk of extortion against the mother-of-two by her German father! Clearly, these are unacceptable things. The concept of the child's best interests remains a vague concept, which applies on the basis of assessments that are too often superficial, if not instrumental. This Europe, which is so impeccable and rigorous in applying the rules to protect the market and competition, banks and finance, collapses miserably when it comes to protecting the rights of people and children.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the questions posed by the European Parliament raise two difficulties, in my view. Firstly, I am opposed to the automatic recognition of adoptions in other Member States. Such automatic recognition would inevitably extend, on the one hand, to adoptions made by same-sex couples and, on the other hand, to adoptions on children born of surrogacy (GPA). However, I do not accept GPA or adoptions by same-sex couples. Secondly, I am wary of the concept of the best interests of the child, which is being used to deconstruct the traditional family. Just as "living together" aims to legitimize communitarianism, the best interests of the child are to remove the child from its natural substrate. I am convinced that the best interest of the child is to grow up in a family consisting of a father and a mother.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Many complaints about children are received by the Committee on Petitions every year. The scale of the problem requires the urgent provision of tools to deal with cross-border cases, and the problems identified concern many areas. One is the inadequate implementation of the Brussels 2 Regulation, the other is the lack of coordination in the communication of information on the protection of children between Member States in cross-border cases. There are also complaints of non-recognition and non-enforcement of judicial decisions in another Member State.  The system built must be multidirectional, it must reach for different tools. I know from Polish experience that many problems arise, for example, from difficult access to information and legal aid. It is therefore necessary to establish a system of financing and supporting organisations for information and assistance in family matters. An important element of this system would be a single European intervention number. A simple and publicly available guide to the systems in place in each Member State and the rights available should be created as soon as possible. After all, many conflicts have their origin in ignorance of systems and laws. These but other measures should be taken urgently if politicians' declarations that the best interests of the child are paramount are not solely in the realm of slogans.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, I am sure you are convinced of the merits of Europe. Europe, where everything flows freely: goods, people, capital and... Love. Yes, love! Erasmus is also the Europe of love, which has enabled more than two million students to discover a new country and which, according to a Commission study, would have contributed to the birth of around one million Erasmus babies. Just for that, I mean "live Europe, long live love"! But you see, sometimes love lasts only a while, and sometimes the parents tear themselves apart around the child's place of life, each party obviously arguing for the best interests of the child. Europe is not just love, alas! It is also the social problems, the accidents of life that affect families, especially the most fragile. Here, too, we face the force of national laws, a justice that does not always cooperate with third countries when it comes to foreign families. All these situations cause the suffering of families and, above all, that of children.  Of course, no one claims that the various decisions made here or there go against the child, but one can be wrong in good faith. On the basis that there are more in many heads than in one, we must do everything we can to ensure that Member States cooperate and cooperate by studying the best possibilities, all possibilities, without taboos or biases.  This is the meaning of this resolution, which is humbly and does not claim to be the absolute key to all the problems encountered in Europe, but which wants to send a clear message to the Commission, the Council and the Member States: no borders for children's rights!

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – Although it is generally the case that it is best for a child to grow up in a biological family, this is not always the case. Children experience violence, abuse, are neglected, and that is when it is important that the competent social authorities intervene. However, there are often cases in the countries of the European Union where children are taken away from their parents, although there has been no real failure and with a little help these families could be functional. Instead of giving the immediate family the opportunity to take care of the children, they go into foster care, institutions, are given for adoption to strangers, while being prevented from maintaining contact with their parents and siblings. Since not every foster parent is primarily concerned with the child's happiness, but many are more interested in the financial benefits that come with them, it is difficult to talk here about a solution for the sake of the child. I therefore welcome this resolution, which aims to ensure the best interests of children in the countries of the European Union, not only in cases of forced removal and adoption, but also in divorces of mixed couples. Strengthening the expertise of social workers, providing interpreters and solicitors, making better use of mediators, as well as better cooperation between Member States can really bring about what we are calling for in this resolution – taking into account the best interests of the child.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF).
text: Mr President, today is an example of the pernicious manipulation of the law: the rights of the child and the cross-border issue.  On the pretext that there are situations, which I recognise are complex, of recognition and adoption of children, in this particular context, the European Union has the right to decide for States.  I will say no three times: no, the Union does not have to deal with family law issues; no, the European Union is not the sole guardian of rights, especially when we allow ourselves here to judge national problems under the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, when there is no clear violation of its principles, but only a legal tension between states; no, the best interests of the child is not to open the door, as some intend to do here, to European recommendations in favour of the recognition and authorisation of questionable medical reproductive techniques and the destruction of our natural family model. We're watching, and we're not going to let go.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, after that last intervention, let me just bring the debate back to its core this evening, which is about children in cross-border situations. I have to say, even though it is rather late in the evening, I have been very impressed by the contributions from Council and Commission. Very often you get criticised, but I thought you were very honest and open on this very sensitive issue. In my role as children’s rights mediator on this issue in Parliament and in the Committee on Petitions we come across the saddest of cases, and we try in my office to bring about mediation. We do it very rarely, because usually people come to us at the very end stage, and I would appeal to the Commission – and you have mentioned mediation – to do as many Member States are trying to do: bring mediation in early, so that it can fix problems without that tension and adversarial system that is the courts. I think if Member States do that and we look at it at a European level, it can be very helpful. Clearly, in the Brussels II review you have mentioned some important points that have got to be looked at. It is about timeliness: a child removed by one parent from the other needs to be returned to its home in a timely manner, and we have several examples of Member States who are not doing that. Lastly, as time is short: we need judicial cooperation to be enhanced. We need to have informal networks for this to work properly. It is a problem that will not go away, and it needs our eyes watching very carefully. But I have been pleased that this evening there is some talk of progress at least.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you have heard how the questions we are debating have summed up the meaning of the many petitions that have come to Parliament in recent times. They basically concern three blocks of problems, as my colleagues have repeatedly pointed out.  The first is the negative effects of a broken marriage law: these effects are accentuated by increased mobility between countries. The whole thing falls on the rights of children and their protection because they are the weak subject of the family unit, so much so that they often turn foster care into a kind of dispute that penalises them beyond imagination.  The second concerns the issue of adoption: we need a legislative framework with social protection. It is not simply a question of entrusting small people to someone – hopefully a solid family unit – but also of giving them the appropriate protections they need to live with dignity.  The third issue is the fight against poverty: poverty has increased in all European countries, including the richest countries, because there has been a gap between the most solid part of society, the one with the highest incomes, and the poorest; the people who pay for this gap in the first place are the children. I believe that any policy to protect and therefore combat poverty must be such that children are given top priority. That's where you have to start.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I am very glad that we agree on what is the best interests of the child. This is undoubtedly life with his parents, if this is not possible, then the custody of a wider biological family and then only substitute family care, possibly institutional care.  The European Union is allowing for increasing scope for mobility of individuals and families. It is therefore essential that judicial decision-making on children is also dealt with, coordinated and, where appropriate, minimum standards for decision-making are set at European level. I therefore very much support the proposal by the rapporteur, Mrs Wikström, which I consider to be very positive. We call here for improved judicial cooperation between Member States. We call for the creation of a platform to assist European Union citizens in addressing cross-border family issues. I consider prevention to be essential, which is why we are also asking for improvements in the work of social and legal protection and social services. We are aware of the crucial role of the Member States and are therefore calling on them to take a number of measures, such as specialised chambers, to improve the conduct of judicial proceedings. In the case of entrustment to foster care, of course, preference should be given to sibling relationships. Our question also indirectly concerns the protection of the best interests of children whose parents, citizens of the European Union, are deprived of parental rights outside the European Union and their children are decided in breach of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I believe that this situation, too, will be reversed and rectified.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, we have received hundreds of petitions, mostly from parents, about child welfare questions. We have heard first hand of the problems faced in securing the best interests of the child in cross-border cases from some very desperate parents. There are estimated to be up to two million British people living around the rest of the EU and an equal number of EU nationals living in the UK. Freedom of movement has brought our citizens unprecedented opportunities, but now we must ensure that our legal systems and judicial cooperation develop at a similar pace, especially when families find themselves in a difficult situation. The concerns raised by citizens demonstrate the clear need to enhance and develop cooperation and information exchange across borders. We have heard calls for a more common understanding on the best interests of the child in line with the UN Convention on the rights of the child, which must always be paramount, and I would like to hear from the Commission what is intended in this respect. Family law is a national competence, and Member States therefore have a strong responsibility to ensure that they address the increasing pressure on social workers and social services by ensuring that family courts and social services are fully supported and well resourced and that parents and children receive the support needed to understand the legal proceedings they are engaged in, and their rights. Finally, we need to stay at the table to negotiate, to ensure the rights of British children and other children in Britain, and that means we need to remain inside the EU.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, investing in children is, in fact, an investment in the future of our society, and raising and educating them, in decent and safe conditions, must always be in everyone's attention, no matter where they are. The Commission and the Council must find the necessary levers to ensure that sufficient guarantees are found that the child's interest is protected in the event of cross-border adoption. It is extremely important that, in such situations, children have the opportunity to keep in touch with the cultural background, to learn and to use the mother tongue. The authorities involved in childcare procedures must make every effort to avoid the siblings being separated. But the Commission and the Council must identify mechanisms that ensure the protection of the interests of children, European citizens, and I stress, European citizens, also when they live outside the European Union. We are talking in particular about third countries, but which are beneficiaries of economic and trade agreements with the European Union, such as, for example, Norway. This country blatantly violates the moral and social values of the European Union regarding the family. Thus, a child of only three months, who is in the period of breastfeeding, can be separated from his biological family and placed in the care of another family without a court decision and only on the basis of an administrative decision on grounds, often unfounded, which, of course, is inadmissible.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, there are many problems that arise when applying the Brussels IIA Regulation. Many problems that affect many families and the interests of their children. I'il focus on three of them. First and for all, I call on the European Commission to take the necessary measures to stop the vicious adoption practices of children without the permission of their biological parents in the European Union. We have a lot of cases like this in the UK that have become business. Secondly, we need to promote cooperation and exchange of information both between adoption courts and between social services and member states' national administrations. Finally, I would like to emphasise the need to respect the cultural and social traditions of the different Member States, because it is in the best interests of the child to remain in the circle of his or her family, even if it is not in the habitual residence of the child. This is particularly important for young children who cannot express their position and for whom the concept of 'habitual residence' is relative.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, indeed, in the Committee on Petitions we have received many requests about problems arising when there is a separation in an international family. This is logically because there is more mobility and because there are a growing number of families from different countries. Indeed, what prevails is the interest of the child.  There is a Regulation, which is the 2003 Regulation, the Brussels IIa – the Commission has said so. After a few years of operation, its gaps have been detected and, in some ways, what it suffers from. And so this debate is very good for a revision of this Regulation.  And basically it seems that we have to guarantee, first of all, what the authority and the rule are so that no one is left without a reference and there is legal certainty; second, the free movement of judgments because sometimes a court decision of one country does not apply as quickly as it plays in another country; third, that the executions of judgments are real, because there is now also a long delay and, in some cases, there are appeals – in others no – that delay the procedure; fourth, that in the case of child abduction there will be agility – it will be six weeks, but this deadline should really be met; and, fifth, make the return effective and fast.  In short, I have full confidence, as Mrs McGuinness said, in the Commission, which has taken on the nail what we have to do, what needs to be done quickly, because we are playing the future here.  One observation: some colleagues have used this debate to attack same-sex couples and I want to make a claim that this discrimination will never occur.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: Għal ħafna familji maqbuda f'tilwimiet familjari, l-aħjar interess tat-tfal jidher qisu xi leġġenda. Il-protezzjoni qiegħda hemm imma donnu ħadd mhu ħert x'inhi. Xi ftit minn din l-in-a.m.  Bħala membru tal-Kumitat għall-Affarijiet Legali, ninsab serjament imħassba però dwar il-falliment fl-attentati tal-Unjoni Ewropea biex ikun hemm ħarezza u erħtezza fil-pro大eduri li jiddeterminaw l-aħjar interess tat-tfal. name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, when I was studying in Rome, I received a card from a Bishop of Chicago that said, "Every child who is born is good news from God that we have not stopped entertaining him." And I think there's some truth to that. A lot of cases have been mentioned here. I want to mention one case. It is the case of Eva Michaláková, which has been resolved in Norway for five years. Five years ago in Norway, a child was taken from a mother and father on suspicion of abuse. This suspicion has not been demonstrated, Commissioner. It's never been proven! And the baby hasn't been returned to this day. Eva Michaláková and her children are citizens of the European Union. And what has the European Union done to get these children back to their mother? Why does the European Union take into account that children are to be adopted in Norway? I think these are crimes that our children will not forget, and crimes that we must address immediately.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protection of minors is one of the great challenges facing contemporary society in legal regulation. The solemn international declarations made in recent decades give children special ownership of rights and interests, especially in view of their status as trainees. However, cross-border cooperation on child issues needs to be strengthened, promoting measures such as mediation and conciliation before a child is adopted and always taking into account his or her superior interests. Policies to support families, in order to reduce the number of children entrusted to care services or given for adoption, are urgent and can no longer be postponed. It is essential for Europe to work to ensure the effective protection and protection of the rights and interests of those who face life. This is now more than ever a top priority from which no one can feel exempt.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask the Commissioner and the relevant authorities to make particular efforts to involve children and young people more fully in decisions affecting them. Participation is also a children’s right, but it is frequently infringed and poorly promoted. Working with organisations experienced in child participation is, in my view, a good way to develop institutional practice that would better protect the best interests of the child.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, I have dealt with hundreds of petitions in relation to the protection of children's interests. Firstly, in the area of transnational adoptions, it is necessary to ensure legal certainty in order to protect the rights of parents and children and to comply with european Union legislation on Union citizenship. After all, many citizens have expressed concerns about adoption practices followed by specific Member States of the Union, with implications for children and their families when they move to those countries. At the same time, each Member State of the Union should remove procedural and bureaucratic obstacles to child custody procedures in order to ensure the proper implementation of the 1993 Hague Treaty. Finally, the Commission should strengthen the dialogue and exchange of best practices between the various parties involved, as well as appoint specialised courts dealing with child abduction cases, with cross-border elements, and ensure that the procedure for their return is effective.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, in a conflict situation when there is a problem between married couples, parents, as a rule, children are hurting. As a rule, parents are selfish and simply often protect only their self-interest or their love for the child, but it often does not have to be just.  That is why what we least need to do when we already have mobility and when we already have the life of different families from different countries or when it comes to different countries and when we have our mobility, we must really do everything to have the right legal regulation at the European level.  That's where I want to emphasize another detail. There are a lot of situations in the area I come from, in the Balkans. The override of people living in countries that are candidate countries with member states is an additional problem and I ask that it be taken into account in future negotiations with candidate countries and this regulation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank Members very much for this debate which, as I expected, brought here many sad and serious true stories which we see in Europe and where, as has been said, the children suffer. It is our duty to address the situation with the proper legislative act.  Several of you mentioned adoptions without parental consent. Let me repeat that adoptions are regulated at national and not EU level. Adoptions are therefore not also in the scope of the Brussels IIa Regulation. But it can be generally noted that Article 21 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child imposes on participating countries to ensure that the best interests of the child is the paramount consideration with regard to adoption. But the Convention does not preclude adoption without parental consent. On Norway – and yes, I expected to be asked about the situation and about the position of the European Union – I can only repeat that due to the fact that Norway is not a Member State of the European Union and moreover, as I said already before, the functioning of child welfare services is not governed by EU law, but by national law , the Commission does not have any competence to intervene with the Member States and it is even more difficult in the case in Norway, when it comes to the functioning of child protection and welfare services. This is the dry answer. From the legal point of view, I can only assure you that I try every time when I am contact with the regional authorities to raise this problem informally, and the answer is always the same that everything is happening according to Norwegian legislation. In cases where the right to family life or the rights of the children involved are allegedly violated by the Norwegian child welfare services, it is for Norway – including its judicial authorities – to ensure that fundamental rights and especially the rights of the child are effectively respected and protected in accordance with their national legislation. The parents concerned can seek redress at the national level only, through the competent national authorities, such as through an ombudsman or through the courts – and at the European Court of Human Rights, once they have exhausted domestic remedies. Just a short note on what Mrs Ward said on the need to cooperate with children’s organisations. I can assure you that we are now in very intensive contact and cooperation with them in trying to ease the situation for children in migration, where we, together with UNICEF and others, have prepared comprehensive material which addresses the problems from various angles. Thank you very much again for this debate. We all agree that the best interest of the child belongs among our highest priorities, and that the Brussels IIa Regulation tries to tackle the situation of cross—border disputes and the cross-border scope and character of the problems, which fully authorises the European Union to take further action and well-targeted legislative solutions, as well as other actions like improving the functioning of the judicial systems in the EU Member States so as to increase also the trust between the Member States and the judiciary. I am convinced that the proposal which we are preparing, and which I will soon submit, on the amendment of the Brussels IIa Regulation provides such a well-targeted solution, which will improve the situation.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me underline once more tonight that it is important to stay true to our founding values. It is our duty to protect those most vulnerable, including adopted children. At the same time – and I repeat – it is important to understand that the issue of the adoption of children is a matter which is not regulated at EU level but by national laws and by some international conventions. As I said earlier, the Council awaits with great interest the Commission proposal amending the Brussels IIa Regulation. I am convinced that the amendment will further improve the functioning of this regulation, particularly with regard to the rules on parental responsibility. Clearly we share the same goal: strengthening the rights of the child in the EU. This is an investment not only in their future but also in the foundations of the Union. A reference was made to unaccompanied minors disappearing upon arrival in Europe, and I think it is important to stress that as well. First of all, it is important that we get the facts and figures straight and that these things are further investigated, but clearly the thought alone sickens me already. Unaccompanied children are among those most vulnerable, and it is deeply troubling that professional gangs might exploit them. The question is: what is the EU doing? I will give you just a few examples. More than EUR 200 million is being earmarked to target the protection of children. Europol and Eurojust are active in helping to dismantle networks involving the smuggling of children. The European Asylum Support Office works on best practice guidance on the assessment of the best interests of the child. The EU helps Member States to be better equipped to deal with the specific needs of child victims of trafficking. Outside the EU, we earmarked EUR 120 million for protection programmes for vulnerable Syrian refugee children, working with NGOs in, for example, Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq. To conclude, it is important that EU Member States work together to prevent children falling into the hands of criminals. Overall there is, I believe, ample opportunity to improve the sharing of information between Member States. This is one of the focal points of the Netherlands Presidency.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. I have received a motion for a resolution submitted in accordance with Article 128(5) of the Regulation to close the debate. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – We must protect the rights and interests of children throughout the European Union. The best interests of the child must be considered to be the most important in all childcare decisions. It should be stressed that increased migration in the European Union has exacerbated problems of cross-border protection of children, including the abolition of custody. Firstly, we need to talk about the role of social services in the protection of children's rights, and we must call on the Member States to provide adequate support to families, as they are primary carers, especially in vulnerable communities where there is a threat of social exclusion. Member States should also be urged not to apply austerity measures to improve the quality of social services. In addition, it is essential that social workers and all other professionals working on cross-border cases involving children receive specialised training and education. In legal proceedings relating to children, it is necessary that Member States provide parents, from the outset and at each stage of the proceedings relating to the child, with full and clear information on the proceedings and its possible consequences.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am concerned by the large number of petitions Parliament has received on child-related cases. I therefore call on Member States to increase and improve cooperation between their judiciaries in cases involving child proceedings. The Commission and Member States must provide for specialised training and education for social workers and law enforcement professionals who deal with cross-border cases involving children. I strongly recommend the setting up of a single European helpline for cases of child abduction or abuse, and I call on the Council to conclude the relevant cooperation agreements on establishing child abduction alert systems with cross-border implications. Last but not least, I emphasise the importance of offering children the best possible opportunities to maintain links with their cultural background and to learn and use their mother tongue. As a member of the EPP, I believe that we must, by every means, guarantee the child’s right to family life and that we must give priority to the best interests of the child in all decisions related to childcare issues at all levels.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I agree with the spirit and the text of the oral question tabled by the Committee on Legal Affairs: we need to take a step forward at European level in order to give more legal protection to children in Europe. We call on the Council to put in place concrete measures to strengthen cooperation between states on issues such as custody, adoption and procedural guarantees for children. The interests of the child must always inspire European action in this area. We therefore call on the Council to strengthen cross-border mediation mechanisms, with the aim of reducing disputes and cases of abduction of children which, as we know and as we see from the many petitions received, have been steadily increasing in recent years.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The increase in mobility in the EU has led to an increase in cross-border child protection cases, as is evident, inter alia, in mass petitions to the European Parliament. In the light of the forthcoming revision of the Brussels II Regulation, the Commission should draw attention to the clear problems with the implementation of the Regulation and consider strengthening its provisions.  Furthermore, it would be important to remove the current procedural and bureaucratic obstacles to the care of minors. The best interests of the child must prevail in all custody decisions at all legislative levels. All child protection systems should have transnational and cross-border mechanisms that take into account the characteristics of such disputes.  In this context, I am pleased that the Council has called on the Member States to establish monitoring and evaluation systems within the framework of the national framework for the coordination of cross-border cases concerning children. Furthermore, it is necessary to oblige the national authorities, as set out in the Brussels IIa Regulation, to recognise and implement judgments given in another Member State and to step up and improve judicial cooperation in all cases concerning children.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the number of children deprived of parental care entrusted with institutional care varies from country to country. Unfortunately, the proportion of such children in Europe is small, despite recommendations made by UNICEF to deinstitutionalise care. This is due both to socio-economic factors and to some extent to the different legislative frameworks of adoptions in Europe, providing for different rules and deadlines. Unfortunately, adoption procedures are often very cumbersome, especially in the case of transnational adoptions, where there is insufficient prior information on the related requirements, deadlines and procedures. I believe that the Commission must do its best to improve awareness of adoption procedures and to assist Member States by exchanging good practices in this regard. I also believe that the Commission and the Member States need to take particular care of prevention by developing policies to support families to raise children with the greatest possible concern for their well-being, especially with regard to families at risk of social exclusion and poverty, so as to reduce the number of children being put up for adoption. Because it is the opportunity to grow in a healthy, family environment that is in the best interests of the child.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, there are no uniform rules applicable in all EU countries for child adoption (every country applies its own rules and procedures). Therefore, in the best interest of the child, we should promote cooperation among Member States in cross-border matters relating to children. In particular, we should focus on adoption practices in cross-border cases and on the sharing of best practice by child welfare services across the Member States.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – European children should enjoy the same rights and the same protection across Europe. Building a common legal framework in Europe is in the best interests of children and can only help families and parents to understand better how they can protect and support their heirs. A closer and stronger European Union pre-supposes that children will enjoy the same rights across the Member States. In the light of Article 24 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Commission should introduce common minimum standards for the hearing of a child in national civil proceedings in cross-border cases. To that end, dialogue and the sharing of best practices between stakeholders and the Member States should be reinforced, and appropriate legal training should be provided for social workers, judges and police officers. A good solution would be the development of specialised chambers within family courts or cross-border mediation bodies, thus allowing fairer and speedier proceedings in the Member States. In the meantime, the European Union should support Europe-wide initiatives aimed at launching a web portal for common users and legal operators, containing clear and easily accessible legal information on national adoption procedures and indicating the authorities to turn to in cases involving cross-border abductions.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Kostadinka Kuneva's report on domestic workers and caregivers in the EU (2015/2094(INI)) (A8-0053/2016).

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we trust our homes, our children, our parents, our sick. These people, who provide us with the opportunity to continue our careers and enjoy our social life, are "invisible", undeclared, uninsured, socially excluded and are, above all, women. Two and a half million domestic workers in Europe, 88% of whom are women who work endless hours without leave without medical cover without pensions. They work in conditions that cannot be controlled because there are no appropriate inspection methods in place to identify and protect them where necessary. Our ageing population and women's entry into the labour market create greater needs for domestic and care staff. Member States are aware of this but allow gaps to be filled through the shadow economy. They reduce public spending and exploit waves of migrants as a new cheap workforce that fills such shortages. It is necessary to: - immediately record the situation in the Member States; - adequate legislation on human working conditions; - ratification and implementation of International Labour Organisation Convention 189 on domestic workers; to collectively address their needs; - recognition of these services as a professional activity and certification; - adoption of good practices - France and Belgium are examples in a different way; - approach by trade unions because these workers do not know where to go; - checks with respect to privacy; - updating the workers for their rights and employers for their obligations. I would particularly like to thank Tania González Peñas for the cooperation we have had in drafting the opinion on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, as well as all the bodies that have helped to raise the issue. We need their support, especially now, before the vote on the report tomorrow because the conservative side of the European Parliament has called for a separate vote on many important points in the report so that, by voting against them, it will weaken it. If the Conservative majority does not want any binding measures, if it does not want the profession to be recognised, if it does not want workers to be entitled either to a specific working time, to medical cover or maternity leave, if they do not want the Convention of the International Labour Organisation to be ratified, then they must admit that they want undeclared workers without rights. To state clearly that they lead to the discrimination of citizens into privileged and second-class citizens. To state that they are not bothered by the exploitation of migrant women.  Europe is collapsing socially and that is why it is moving away from its citizens and the European Parliament has a share of the responsibility for this. The issue we are discussing today is primarily a matter of respect for human dignity. Anton Chekhov wrote to his brother: "Civilized people must, in my opinion, meet the following criteria: respect human beings as individuals...". And it's the personal opportunity of each and every one of us to prove what our culture and respect is.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – It is true, I agree with the rapporteur, Mrs Kunevo. Statistical indicators show a very unfavourable picture. A lot of people, especially women, work in the household. But it's not just migrant women. Women who have been employed stay at home, often so they can take care of their family so they can take care of their elderly parents so they can take care of their children. Because there are simply no other options: because kindergartens are too expensive, because nursing homes are overcrowded. However, these women are neither paid nor paid for this responsible work, nor are they adequately socially insured. This is, of course, intolerable. Individual countries are already implementing certain measures. Among them my country, Slovenia, this area is well regulated. Yet we need action at systemic level. And I agree that professionalization would do a lot of things. We'd like to get into another area we're avoiding. We'd cut back on black work. This is not only good for individuals and individuals, but for society as a whole.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for this report and other colleagues too who have taken a very progressive and compassionate view. It is important that we say loud and clear in this debate that the situation of women carers is affected directly by harmful austerity policies, by cuts to public services across Europe, and notably by the Conservative Government in the UK. When women are forced to take up care duties and they are not recognised or supported, we experience a regression: a return to less gender equality. We never talk about the day-to-day hardship that women carers face, or their mental health – and indeed that issue is not really addressed adequately in the report. We need the Commission and Member States to consider sharing best practice on mental health support for formal or informal carers who are left in situations of poverty or hardship with no support. We need to empower local civil society organisations who work on these issues to act and take every step to help the needs of the most vulnerable.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, after thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Kuneva, for her report, I would like to point out that women employed as domestic workers are faced with precarious working conditions every day since domestic work is carried out in the form of undeclared work and is not covered by labour law. Moreover, there is often no social protection and coverage for their labour rights, so women's wages in these sectors are low and do not guarantee them a decent standard of living, especially in countries such as Greece which has been impoverished by the Memorandums. In view of the rights of women workers trampled by the economic crisis and the lack of legislation in certain professions, the countries of the European Union should recognise the professional rights of women employed in domestic work and include them in their national legislation. At the same time, the European Union must stop povertying the countries of the South and thus harm women's rights, both at work and at social level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to thank the rapporteur, Madam Kuneva, for her report on domestic workers and carers in the EU. I personally submitted 17 amendments to our opinion in the Employment Committee, and I am very pleased to see that virtually all of those ideas are included in the final report. In particular my call on all Member States to ratify Convention 189 of the ILO is included. This is the Domestic Workers’ Convention. In that context I am happy to say that my own country – Ireland – has in fact ratified that Convention, but 22 other EU Member States have not, and they need to do so urgently. I am pleased also that my idea on ensuring the professionalism, or the professionalisation, of the sector to foster the creation of decent jobs leading to quality employment is included. And I am also pleased that might call for a carers’ leave directive is included in the final report. Finally, I support the campaign ‘Make them visible’, which highlights the need for proper working conditions and decent work for domestic workers and carers in the EU.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, domestic work is characterised by the absence of a work contract and overdue wages, the expansion of working hours without due remuneration, the non-respect of the right to leave and rest, the non-payment of holidays and holidays, the absence of payments to Social Security. In essence, it is characterized by the deepening of the precarious work, the deregulation of labor and the attack on collective hiring. We do not turn off the difficult condition of these workers from the increase in poverty that in Portugal already affects 30% of the population, or the worsening inequalities that have deepened with macroeconomic policies and austerity measures imposed by the European Union in response to the economic crisis. Policies that have promoted the privatisation and destruction of the public network of services and infrastructure for children, the elderly and the sick, forcing many women to give up work to be able to provide such care. This is the result of the neoliberal policies of impoverishment and exploitation that the European Union sponsors and imposes on the Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would first like to thank Kostadinka Kuneva for his enormous work with this report and for his close cooperation with the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, for which I have taken care of my opinion on this report. Domestic workers and caregivers are one of the most unprotected working groups in the European Union, and as early as 2011 the International Labour Organization tried to provide us with an international framework, with its Convention No 189, to ensure the decent work of domestic workers, without great success in the European Union, since only six member countries have ratified it. These workers suffer from conditions of absolute unprotection and vulnerability: very long days, very low wages, and have no guarantees of safety and health at work. We need a legislative framework that ensures the professionalization of care and, moreover, we need public investment to develop active information and professionalization policies. As we know, it is 88% work done by women, which makes us think that there has not been much interest in regulating it. Their professionalization would be an impetus for women's equality and an opportunity to create jobs and put care at the heart of our societies.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kuneva, for her report, which sheds light on a sector that employs at least 53 million people in the world, with around 2.5 million in the EU, according to the International Labour Organisation’s figures. As is rightly stressed in the report, this is a highly feminised sector: 83 % of all domestic workers are women. I have read the report carefully and I share several concerns: for example, the need for recognition of the profession of domestic workers and carers, reducing undeclared work in the sector, promoting labour market integration and raising awareness and sharing good practices among Member States. Given the rapid ageing of the population, the demand for care and household services is expected to increase in all Member States. I am glad that Parliament welcomes our approach for a ‘New start for working parents and care—givers’ because our aim is to take account of recent developments and the needs of the families – those with elderly or dependent relatives, not only parents – and make more equitable use of family-related leave arrangements between partners. Several Commission studies show the importance of the professionalising of domestic work and care. In this regard, the Commission financed three projects to explore the cost—effectiveness of public support for this sector, the quality of services and the productivity gain. The European Quality Framework for long-term care services, launched in 2012, aims to improve the quality of life for older people in need of care and assistance. I also note the request for further analysis on the added value of a professionalisation of the sector of domestic work. I agree that the professionalisation of household service workers and care workers will increase the attractiveness of the sector and the quality of the service provided because it can create jobs. The Commission staff working document on ‘Exploiting the potential of personal and household services’, published in 2012, recognised the potential for job opportunities for the relatively low skilled, in particular as far as housework services are concerned, at a low cost for public finance. To this end, the provision of housework services in the formal economy, rather than in the shadow one, should be encouraged. Some Member States have already put in place a policy on personal and household services: for example, France and Belgium with service vouchers, Finland with tax credit for domestic help or Sweden with tax deduction for service acquisition. Promoting the professional recognition of skills and qualifications is also a priority for domestic workers and carers. All people in Europe must have the right skills for jobs. This can improve their life opportunities. This is why the upcoming Skills Agenda will have a particular focus on improving the transparency of skills and qualifications. This could be very relevant for people with a migrant background or for refugees’ labour market integration.  As regards the International Labour Organisation Convention on fair and decent work for domestic workers (No. 189), the Commission has regularly promoted its ratification. In December 2015, together with the Luxembourg EU Council Presidency, we invited Member States to an expert meeting on the ratification of this Convention.  We acknowledge the plea for an appropriate level of health and safety at work for the workers of this sector. The question of the exclusion of domestic servants from the scope of Directive 89/391/EEC on Safety and Health at Work will be examined in the light of the outcome of the ongoing evaluation of the EU acquis in the area of occupational safety and health. As is mentioned in the report, there has been an increase in recent years in the proportion of female domestic workers who are migrants. I also take note of the recommendation, both to the Commission and the Member States, to ensure the availability of legal avenues for migration to the EU and to introduce targeted legal migration programmes. The Commission has launched a global action programme on migrant domestic workers and their families, which entails pilot projects supporting migrant domestic workers including in Europe. I share the concerns about undeclared work, which is particularly high in this sector and has a negative impact on these people’s working conditions, the quality of their services and, more broadly, the economy. The formalisation of their work would provide adequate social protection and create additional revenues for public finance. It would also increase the quality of their services, which is strongly linked to their working conditions and the recognition of their qualifications. I am confident that the newly—established European Platform to Enhance Cooperation in the Prevention and Deterrence of Undeclared Work will contribute to raising awareness and sharing good practices, analysis and experiences to find solutions to the challenges faced by this sector. I am glad that Parliament stresses the important role social partners can play in addressing sector—specific challenges in the care work sector. We will be interested in following their activities in that domain, while of course respecting their autonomy. In conclusion, I would like to recall that it is the Commission’s firm intention to steer the Union more strongly towards social fairness. No one should be left behind, and that includes domestic workers. The report is therefore both timely and helpful to move forward on several policy files and help us connect the dots between them.

name: El Presidente. –
text: This point is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – There are 2.5 million domestic workers and caregivers in Europe (88% are women). The vast majority do not list social security, do not enjoy retirement, do not have health coverage, charge a meager black salary and work long days, without the right to rest or paid leave. Many are irregular immigrants. Others are relatives who care for dependents without pay or rights. The EU must resolve this unfair situation by introducing a legal framework for the professionalisation of domestic work and care, and by presenting a directive to regulate the situation of non-professional caregivers assisting dependents. States should define a specific legal framework for the regular recruitment of domestic workers and caregivers and establish the rights and duties of employers and workers. These people take care of our dependent children and relatives and also of us so that we can develop our jobs and vocations outside the home, which they care for. What are they going to live on when their retirement age comes? When will they be able to enjoy the rights of the Welfare State? When are they going to stop being second-rate workers without labor rights?

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Demographic changes in recent decades and the combined evolution of the family model have meant that many of the homework and care work is now carried out in the context of an employment relationship. Unfortunately, people employed to do housework and caring work may be exposed to discrimination. Firstly, they are often people employed in the grey economy, deprived of workers' rights, irregular status and working hours. This makes them devoid of job security and social security.  Secondly, there are also cases of gender discrimination, harassment and harassment. This makes it necessary to take certain measures to lift the sector out of the grey economy and to empower its people.  However, I believe that the situation in the various Member States varies so much that it is up to governments to take responsibility for solving this problem. Interference by the Union would very clearly infringe the principle of subsidiarity in this case. Member States, knowing their specificity, are able to prepare much more effective action programmes to reduce pathologies in the homework and care sectors. The European Commission should focus primarily on collecting and spreading good practices and innovative solutions in individual countries.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – More and more people are employed by domestic work and care in the European Union and around the world, and we can expect their numbers to increase as our population ages. Nine out of ten of them are women. They often carry out their work directly in the households of the employer, where they also live. However, their employers must realise that they must respect their labour and social rights, such as working hours or privacy requirements. Moreover, their work is often undeclared, which complicates the possibilities for their protection and leads, among other things, to the high risk of poverty for these women in old age. Compliance with basic labour standards is also ensured by the International Convention on Domestic Workers of the International Labour Organisation. I would therefore like to support my colleague Kuneva's report and call for the ratification of this convention even by those States that have not yet done so. Closing our eyes to the problem of domestic workers and carers is very shortsighted and does not address the situation of people who are in a vulnerable position in the labour market and whose importance to society will continue to increase.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Smuggling and exploiting people abroad and forcing them to work are problems that urgently need to be eradicated. The people who are in this situation are mostly women doing work related to caring for disabled or elderly people, or doing homework in their profession. It should be our duty to give this group of people the opportunity to give them official legal status. Illegal people smuggling is a misdemeanor. Financial exploitation and intimidation are sufficient reasons to make changes.  The European Union respects values such as respect for human rights and dignity, which is why the resolution on this issue rightly refers to the laws of individual EU Member States. The introduction of bilateral agreements between the country that accepts the worker and the country of which the worker is a national will certainly be a beneficial change. The creation of a single rule will contribute to reducing the increase in illegal people smuggling and undeclared work.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Terry Reintke's report on gender equality and women's empowerment in the digital age (2015/2007(INI)) (A8-0048/2016).

name: Terry Reintke
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the report empowering women in the digital age breaks with two very stupid, yet still very widespread, stereotypes. The first is that digitalisation is only about technological development. It is not. Digitalisation will completely shape our societies and will have an impact on all areas of our lives. So digital policies are in fact societal policies, and that is exactly why gender equality should be at the core of this debate.  The second stereotype is that women are not interested in the digital revolution. I must tell you that they are. Working on this report, talking to many women who are already active in the digital sector today, I became convinced of this myself. The problem is just that they very often face obstacles in the ICT sector or in STEM education. What we need to do is to create the right preconditions for them to fully conquer the digital arena. These stupid stereotypes are not our fate. We can challenge them and that is exactly what this report is doing. The report does indeed show the challenges, but it also gives concrete tools to overcome them and the amazing potential that the digital world holds both for women and for the enhancement of gender equality in our societies, be it the Bulgarian game developer who is facing everyday sexism in her job, be it the French Cameroonian digital entrepreneur who does not get access to funding because she is not considered creditworthy , or be it the Irish mother of two who is being stalked by a troll on Facebook. This report provides answers to all of these examples. It calls for more efforts to make the educational sector more inclusive and e-skills attainable to all. It calls for more funding opportunities for female entrepreneurs, and it asks for better cooperation between police authorities to combat stalking and harassment online European-wide. So we can see that the tools are there. Now we will just have to make them reality. Ms Jourová, I hope that not only you, but the whole Commission, will stand behind this and push this in the future. All this great work and the great results that we see in this report could not have been possible without input from great activists, civil society, female entrepreneurs and many other people who have given input, and the great work of all my colleagues who have shadowed this report and contributed a lot to making it such a success. I thank you all for your constructive work.  I think that we can really build a digital agenda together in the European Union that will be inclusive and that will give equal chances to both men and women. I hope that this report will be a starting point and that it finds a broad majority tomorrow because actually that is the best day to work on it as tomorrow is Girls in ICT Day.  So I hope that it will find your support.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a strong digital economy is vital for innovation, growth, jobs and competitiveness – and so are women. Recent studies show a decrease in the number of young people, in particular girls and women, studying and choosing careers in ICT, and most Member States also have a skills gap in this sector. Yet Member States and the EU look at the digital sector as a socio—economic boost. Consequently, Member States must recognise that compulsory education is to include a relevant ICT education from the earlier stages of education that will enable women and girls to obtain the necessary e-skills to fully participate in socio-economic development, as well as to foster amongst them the understanding that they, too, are contributors to digital innovation and are able to obtain skills for employment in the digital sector. An education policy – be it for compulsory education or in lifelong learning – that provides women and girls with skills to participate and contribute within the digital economy will also bring about further empowerment and continue to break down barriers based on gender.

text: ECR). Mr President, strengthening women in the digital age and reducing gender inequalities in the field of Information Technology are as necessary as ever. Firstly, in the Member States of the Union, we note that only 9% of programmers are women, while only 19% of employees in the field of Information and Communication Technology have female managers, compared to 45% of workers in other sectors. This, of course, is the result of the significant gender gap in access to professional and educational opportunities related to the field of Information Technology.  Of course, gender discrimination can also be seen in the workplace in general, since the wage and pension differences are quite large, whereas in countries such as Greece, which is affected by the Memorandums, women are the group of the population most affected. It is therefore necessary to promote gender equality in the digital economy, to increase the proportion of women in leadership positions and to eliminate any gender pay gap at work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report and this debate on equality and empowering women and really would like to echo the points that the rapporteur has made. They were from Europe and they had gone to the US, because they felt that was where the opportunities were. name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am happy to have the opportunity today to discuss with you the current situation regarding gender equality and empowering women in the digital age. This is a topic that deserves our undivided attention. The fact that women are under-represented throughout the ICT sector is a key challenge that we need to tackle. The report by Mrs Reintke very much contributes to raising awareness of this challenge and offers solid recommendations that are aimed at strengthening women’s participation in the ICT sector. The report brings us a step closer to closing the gender gap in the sector, and for this reason I would like to thank the rapporteur of this excellent and forward—looking report. The Commission is fully committed to take further action in this area, as outlined in the ‘Strategic Engagement for gender equality’. The Grand Coalition for Digital Jobs, for example, is a multi-stakeholder partnership, which tackles the lack of digital skills in Europe. Some of the pledges target only women. The Strategic Engagement includes a key action that focuses on using the Grand Coalition for Digital Jobs to support measures enhancing digital skills among women and girls and promoting female employment in the ICT sector. The Commission has been active in promoting opportunities for girls and women in the sector as well. The ICT sector is rapidly growing, creating around 120 000 new jobs every year. In view of the good job and salary prospects, we would like to see more women take advantage of this situation and consider a career in the sector. Women active in this sector generally enjoy higher flexibility to arrange their working schedules and will be less susceptible to unemployment. When considering economic arguments for increasing female participation in the ICT sector, the Commission’s study on women active in the sector found that more women entering the digital jobs market can create an annual EUR 9 billion GDP boost in the EU area. Furthermore, women working in the sector earn almost 9% more than women in similar positions in other service sectors.  In order to increase women’s opportunities in the digital age, it is of the utmost importance to tackle women’s under-representation in the sector. At this moment, only nine in 100 European app developers are female; 19% of ICT managers are women and less than 30% of the ICT workforce is female. When we look at the educational aspect we see that, today, only 29 out of every 1 000 female graduates have a computing or related degree.  The Commission supports several initiatives that promote getting more women into digital jobs and encourage girls to pursue ICT-related subjects. For example, the European Network of Women Web Entrepreneurs Hubs (WeHubs) is the first network of partners which specifically supports women to create and scale-up their web enterprises, building links between women entrepreneurs, investors and the web entrepreneurship ecosystems.  The Digital Single Market with its e-society dimension constitutes a great opportunity for women in digital. But we need more role models, mentoring, greater engagement of business and industry by offering even more targeted programmes to study and work in the ICT sector. More grass-root initiatives like the Code Week are needed – during the 2015 EU Code Week half of the almost half a million young coders were young girls! We also need to get men involved in the debate on diversity. I strongly believe that tackling gender stereotypes will contribute to creating equal opportunities in the workplace and will attract more women to the sector.  As also highlighted in the report, the increasing digitalisation of society also poses some threats to gender equality, including cyber—bullying, cyber—harassment, cyber—stalking and sexist forms of hate speech. The Fundamental Rights Agency survey on women’s experiences of violence shows that one in ten women has experienced sexual harassment or stalking through new technologies. All forms of violence against women and girls, including cyber-violence, are rooted in gender inequalities and reinforce them further.  The EU is committed to fighting against such violence as affirmed in a number of strategic documents. An important action that the Commission has undertaken in this area is the proposals for the European Union to sign and conclude the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention, a comprehensive international treaty on combatting violence against women and domestic violence. This includes provisions to encourage the participation of the information and communication technology sector in combating this phenomenon, also in the online sphere. Considering the excellent recommendations outlined in the report, it is clear that there are significant challenges ahead of us. Let us take advantage of the new and great opportunities and explore ways to advance women’s empowerment in the digital age. I look forward to tackling the challenges together in order to break down gender stereotypes and use the technological innovations as drivers of progress towards gender equality.

text: Writing. – Digitalization is changing our world of work. What it does not change is the inequality of women and men – especially in well-paid jobs. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to urgently promote equality in this area. We need to increase the visibility of women in digitised professions. To do this, we need more incentives for women to study computer science or pursue a career with a focus on computer science. In addition to training, continuing training and lifelong learning must also play a central role. We need visible female role models. For this, a gender quota on the boards is long overdue. The Commission and the Member States are called upon to finally implement the directive introducing a Europe-wide quota for women in supervisory boards as a first step. In addition, greater attention needs to be paid to the gender aspect in the implementation of the Digital Agenda, including from the social partners. We need to analyse the new forms of employment. They can, of course, contribute to a better work-life balance, especially for women. However, basic workers' rights and social protection must be ensured. Digitisation must not lead to a continuation of the gender pay gap!

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The information society and information and communication technologies (ICTs) can serve as springboards for women's empowerment and gender equality. I regret that women are currently under-represented in the ICT sector. It is therefore necessary to remedy this situation. To do so, it is essential to guide the Digital Single Market Strategy in this direction, and to insist that the next Strategy for Gender Equality proposes specific measures to support the integration and participation of women in the information society and to actively promote women's networks online. I am thinking in particular of education, which should promote digital culture as well as the education of women and girls in the ICT field through the integration of new technologies into curricula of all levels, I am also thinking of lifelong learning, which must pay special attention to women aged 50 and over, in order to protect them from exclusion from the labour market. , and I am finally thinking of the fight against violence against women in the digital world, in particular the issues relating to harassment on the Internet.

The Commission must work to make trade flows and raw materials from abroad public, in order to make it transparent to all European consumers which companies use ingredients that are dangerous to human health.

text: – Mr President, those in the British Government and on the right who represent the North of Ireland and here advocate a ‘leave’ vote in the upcoming Brexit referendum are being irresponsible and reckless. name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, last week hundreds of people returned to the Castilian town of Villar de Cañas in Cuenca to call for a stop in the construction of a nuclear waste warehouse. In response to questions I have submitted to the European Commission, it has been acknowledged that this draft does not have the mandatory reports required by the Euratom Treaty, which has been signed by Spain. Nuclear Security Council technicians also denounce political pressures and the adoption of reports they disagree with. And, if that were not the case, the site is considered inadequate by many experts. And I ask here: Is Castile also Europe? Can the European Union contemplate the construction of a high-risk nuclear facility, in this way, and not get involved? Castile wants security, wants respect and wants investments that stop the bleeding of its population and not become the dumpster of what no one wants.
