Meanwhile, with Russia dismantling the Mejlis, the national representation of the Crimean Tatars, the community that is the best barometer of freedom in Crimea, at which time the French government invites the Russian President to make an official visit to their country. This invitation, this gesture, that is, I ask you, not only – as Minister Ayrault said – a sign of an age-old tradition, it is really a sign of the direction in which the mainstream of the European Union is going, whatever its leaders say.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, President Juncker has said that we should have equal pay for equal work in the same place. So indeed, like Commissioner Thysson, most European citizens would believe that equal pay for equal work is guaranteed at EU level. However, in Ireland we have a discriminatory two-tier pay system for nurses, gardaí and teachers – they get paid different salaries at the same point on the salary scale, and young teachers are on a much lower scale. One teacher emailed me and said that those who began teaching after February 2012 were earning over EUR 220 000 less over a 40—year career than those who began before 2011. I wrote to the Commission, but they said there is no EU law that applies to pay scales. Nevertheless, the outcome of these discriminatory pay scales is that in Ireland we do not have equal pay for equal work over a career. How can we say to that teacher who earns EUR 220 000 less over a 40—year career that equal pay for equal work is guaranteed under EU law? We can’t. And we need to look at it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this is Mary Boyle, Ireland’s longest missing child case. Six-year-old Mary disappeared in 1977, and the man whom her twin sister believes is responsible for her disappearance still lives in that community and has never been formally brought in for questioning. Allegedly, a still-sitting politician directly intervened, and that intervention led to one of the worst police cover-ups we have seen in Ireland. Almost one year ago, I brought Mary’s twin sister Ann to this Parliament seeking justice. Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees the right to life. Six-year-old Mary was denied that right. Article 20 of the Charter guarantees the right to equality before the law, Mary was denied that right. To this day there has been no inquest into Mary’s death, no commission of investigation, despite a formal request from the legal team. In fact, it has never even been debated in the Irish Parliament, which is why I am forced to raise it here tonight. Six-year-old Mary Boyle has been failed by the Irish State.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, in order to meet the deficit set by the European Commission for 2016, last week the Spanish Ministry of Finance called for self-governments to take on all the necessary cuts.  Centrifugating the deficit is unfair in terms of territorial equity. Autonomous communities account for more than 50% of social spending in Spain, and the Catalan budget, for example, more than 60% is devoted to this chapter. These cuts would cost Catalonia 1 billion euros, which is like closing prisons, the entire administration of justice and three large hospitals for a year.  Yes, it is necessary to keep public accounts balanced but, under no circumstances can further cuts in education, health or social services be accepted.  Why does the Spanish Government not consider lowering its public spending on defence, currently more than 1% of Gross Domestic Product? Does it make sense for the Ministry of Culture to maintain, when autonomous communities have competences in this area?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Today we are outraged when Turkey interrogates and holds Mrs Ebru Umar, a journalist accused of insulting His Excellency Tayyip Erdoğan. I agree that heads of state must not be offended, but the Turkish President has announced that he will fight hatred towards Turkey, for its history. Okay, but why does the German Government agree to indict Jan Böhmermann, who is doing the same. By the way, contrary to Angela Merkel, the prosecutor's office in Germany is not independent, because it needs the consent of the government to prosecute the perpetrators and got it.  Then why did she not get it ten years ago, when a German satirist from Tageszeitung insulted then-President Polish Lech Kaczynski, because the government declared, "freedom of the press is a high-ranking good and action against it is not possible because of the constitution."  And why did Mr Schulz wrongfully kick General Elefterios Sinadinos out of the Chamber of Parliament, who did not offend any president, only quoted the opinions of the Turks of the sixteenth-century Arab historian. Double standards are unacceptable, and besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on Sunday I visited Belgrade to have a closer look at the Serbian parliamentary election. It is an important signal that a clear majority of the Serbian people voted for a pro-European course of their country. Belgrade’s reform agenda and the constructive approach to relations with neighbouring countries have enabled substantial progress in both regional cooperation and close relations with the EU. Serbia can now focus on implementing economic reforms, strengthening the rule of law, reforming public administration and guaranteeing media freedom. Europe is faced with challenging times ahead. Serbia’s voice counts in defining the future of our continent. In order to help Serbia to continue on its European path, I believe the fundamental chapters 23 and 24 concerning judiciary and fundamental rights, as well as justice, freedom and security should be opened as soon as possible.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I, like 30 million Sikhs across the world, was deeply shocked by the terrorist attack at the Nanaksar Satsang Darbar Gurdwara in Essen, Germany, last week. As the only elected Sikh parliamentarian in Europe, I condemn this atrocious act and offer my heartfelt sympathy to those injured, and to the worshippers there. No faith, no religious group or community should be targeted in this way. It is completely incomprehensible as to why radicalised youngsters would target a place of worship of a religion that shelters the homeless and feeds the hungry across Europe. I can only guess their objective was to sow mistrust amongst us. It is now vitally important that the German authorities act with haste and deal with the perpetrators with the full force of the law, to give confidence not just to Sikhs in Essen, but also in Europe, that any threat against them is taken as seriously as any other terrorist atrocity that has occurred in Europe.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL). –
text: Mr President, Latin America and the Caribbean are experiencing difficult and important moments. We note the progress of the negotiations between the European Union and Cuba, a step towards the end of an infamous blockade and which requires the Council to ratify, as a matter of urgency, the repeal of the common position of 1996. We note the deadlock in the peace process negotiations in Colombia and the lack of positive contributions from the European Union to the conclusion of this process, in particular by the non-withdrawal of the FARC and the ELN from its list of terrorist organisations. We note the continued interference of imperialism on democracies of the South American continent, of which are examples of the destabilization processes recently carried out and underway in Brazil and Venezuela. Finally, a message of solidarity with the people of Ecuador, which is dealing with the worst tragedy in the last seventy years, following the earthquake that has left hundreds dead and thousands of victims and requires the rapid and substantial mobilisation of humanitarian and financial support from the European Union.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have a contribution similar to that of my colleague Štefanec. This, too, is proof of how big a problem the proposed amendment to the Arms Possession Directive is in some Member States. I wanted to call on the Commissioner from here to pay particular attention to this issue and to see how sensitive the issue is and how much storms and resentment sparked the european commission's original proposal in each Member State.  In the Czech Republic, for example, this proposal by the European Commission was rejected by both the Parliament of the Czech Republic and the Security Council of the State, which is essentially a government body. I therefore very much ask the Commissioner to reconsider how much all the provisions of this directive are really needed in the fight against terrorism, and to omit from this proposal those parts that merely bully legal arms holders and do not help much in the fight against terrorism.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention to an extremely dangerous phenomenon that is manifesting itself in the countries of Eastern Europe and, in particular, in Romania, namely the grabbing of agricultural land by so-called foreign investors, who are in fact speculators. Taking advantage of low prices compared to those in Western countries, it has come to be that more than 40% of Romania's agricultural area is in the hands of these speculators, who in fact only farmers are not. The consequences for these areas are dramatic. The unemployment rate is rising, small and medium-sized farms have disappeared, and the silence of old is deeply disturbed by tomorrow's uncertainty. This is particularly due to the fact that land is rarely cultivated and then formally, in reality pursuing the subsidies provided by the European Union and in no way the development of agriculture in those areas. The Commission cannot ignore this state of affairs and must intervene urgently to regulate this inadmissible situation for the European Union.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as always, I am the last one here today. But the topic I want to talk about is very important. It is a subject that is very often forgotten in debates on migration, and I personally consider it very important. It's the psychological health of refugees. Refugees fleeing syria's war zone and seeing loved ones die have experienced many traumas caused by either the Islamic State or the Assad regime. They are being put through further traumas in Europe and there is no doubt that these traumas have manifested themselves and will manifest themselves in their lives. I would therefore like to call on you here, Commissioner, because you are the only one present here, to stop dealing with pseudo-problems, such as the debates on quotas, but to move on and start addressing problems that are real. One of these problems is precisely the refugee problems they have in integrating into European society.

name: El Presidente. –
text: This closes this point.
